results.description:
Are you curious about programming or thinking about pursuing a career in software engineering? 

Then RSVP on this meet-up page for this 2-hour Intro to Coding class happening in the Boston area at CIC Boston. Learn the basics of programming, do hands-on exercises, and meet new people. All for free!

The class is being taught by MakerSquare, which runs some of the top coding schools in the country.

Class officially starts at 1:30pm, but please arrive at CIC Boston by 1:15pm to mingle with your fellow classmates and settle in. We will end at 4pm, with the last 30 minutes being an optional Q&A session.

What will I learn during the class?

This beginner ­level class will contain several instructor-guided exercises. The class will cover the following topics:

   1. Overview of programming 

   2. Intro to data & data structures

   3. Basics of functions

We ask that you read the Prerequisites section before the start of class and bring your own laptop (Windows, Mac or Linux) with Google Chrome installed.

What is MakerSquare Boston?

MakerSquare is a three-month full-time school for software engineering. By teaching computer science fundamentals and modern web languages like JavaScript, we prepare students to join top flight engineering teams.

We have campuses all over the country, and are excited to be opening a campus in Boston. The free Intro to Coding class is to introduce more people to the wonderful world of programming and to get the community excited about the launch of our full-time class in Boston in July 2016!

Questions? Email us at [masked].
results.name: Free Intro to Coding Class (Sat April 23, 1:30-4pm)

results.description: General admission tickets, just $5 on Goldstar at this link!  If we meet by 1:30pm we can buy tickets together, I'll email my cellphone to "Yes" folks the day before. Unlike any other puppet show you've ever seen before, the hugely popular musical Avenue Q is strictly for grownups. Full of humor and hummable tunes, Avenue Q is a hilarious look at life in New York, featuring a fantastic cast of people and puppets. In its Broadway debut, Avenue Q scored the "Triple Crown" of Tony wins, grabbing honors for Best Musical, Best Score and Best Book. The lovable cast of characters, both flesh and felt, includes recent college grad Princeton, who moves to NYC's rent-controlled Avenue Q full of hope for the future, Kate (the girl/monster next door), and a colorful collection of neighbors who all struggle together to find jobs, dates, and their ever-elusive purpose in life. While the show draws inspiration from a certain beloved children's show, you'll definitely want to leave the kiddos at home for this one -- these puppets have quite the potty mouths on them, and there's even some "full puppet nudity" involved. Head to Rogers Center for the Arts for a night of very adult laughs as you get schooled on topics such as unemployment, relationships, one night stands and casual racism.

We're doing a new 4-week endurance series! All levels are welcome, and you don't need to be able to make it every week.


The 4 weeks will help you keep swimming for longer without getting as tired, whether you're training for a triathlon coming up or just working on your swimming. We'll talk about and practice pacing yourself. If there's a race you're targeting and want to work on that distance or event, let us know and we can help tailor the workouts for you.

We go across the street for pizza (or other food if you don't eat pizza) every week after the swim. Save time to join us! We usually finish up by about 4:30pm.


---------------


The pool opens at 2pm, so we meet to go in at 1:45 so that we can be out on the pool deck by 2. $6 to get in, Cambridge residents $5 (or you can buy a 10-pack for an approximate 10% discount, and we do these weekly so you'll have the opportunity to use them up).

Street parking is available but stressful, and the 69 bus drops off down the block, or you can bike or run there and do 2/3 of a triathlon :)

Hello friends!

Have you ever wondered what exactly bonds are? Have you looked at the stock market and thought to yourself, self, "the u.s. Market might be a little overvalued right now. How do I protect a portion of my assets?" Have you wondered why interest rates and bond prices move in opposite directions? Maybe you are concerned about rising interest rates and what you can do to protect your portfolio from such an occurrence. All these answers and more are contained in "The Bond Book" by Annette Thau. We will be discussing chapters 1-6. We discussed chapters 1-5 last time, but attendance left something to be desired. I'm assuming that you all had hot dates. I hope they went well. Ha! Again, all levels of investing experience are welcome from novice to expert. We look forward to meeting you!

P.S. Please feel free to join even if you haven't read the book. We use the book as a framework to talk about the investment environment in general.

results.description:
"Imbeciles: The Supreme Court, American Eugenics, and the Sterilization of Carrie Buck" by Adam Cohen is story of one of the most notorious US Supreme Court decisions. Many people rank with Dred Scott and Plessy v. Ferguson. Unlike those cases, Buck v. Bell is still the law of the land.

In 1927, an 8-1 decision written by Justice Oliver Wendall Holmes Jr, notoriously ruled that "three generations of imbeciles is enough" while upholding the forced sterilization of Carrie Buck, a young woman of above average intelligence who demonstrated her low moral character and imbecility by being an unwed mother, bearing the child of her rapist, a nephew of her foster parents. The three generations were her mother, Carrie, and her child who was too young to be evaluated.

The case was the pinnacle of the American eugenics movement and an inspiration for Hitler's similar laws. It was even cited by the defense in the Nuremburg war crimes trials as justification for the Holocaust.

It is becoming increasingly relevant with the rise in immigrant bashing and pseudo science raised to national policy.

For more information, see the editorial reviews and comments (including one conspiricy-minded anti-vaxer) on the Amazon page: http://www.amazon.com/Imbeciles-Supreme-American-Eugenics-Sterilization/dp/1594204187
results.how_to_find_us: Room 169 (the doors are locked on the weekend but we put up post-its with a phone number to get access).
results.name: Boston Skeptics' Book Club: Imbeciles by Adam Cohen

results.description:
This shoot will feature Spring 16' looks and trends. Some of the reoccurring fabrics that we are seeing are lace, see through lace, net looking fabrics, and pleating.

For the color pallet I want to use the less saturated colors for example Rose Quartz, Peach Echo,  Serenity, Lilac Grey, and Iced coffee. See the following like for reference.

Spring 16' Color Pallet

I would like to do this shoot outside on a nice spring day. I will put in a tentative date but keep in mind this may change depending on the weather and participants. Since it is still March I am going to date this out till the end of April. I still want to find a great location for this shoot.

I will be visiting different parks, I also think in a field (not a green field) more of a grain field with tall grass. Overall I want this shoot to read bright and effortless.

I am hoping to get pieces that will read high fashion but keeping within this trend. With that being said for this shoot I want to push the envelope with hair trends. I'm thinking the use of braids and the half high mini pony. I'm hoping the creative use of braiding with help elevate this shoot to read more editorial.

Here is a link to all pinned photos of inspiration. The first couple of photos are in reference to hair and makeup with the next few in reference to overall mood and location of shoot. The final images are geared more to the fashion looks and trends I am trying to achieve.

Spring 16' Board

If you are on pintrest and are interested in adding some images to this board please respond within this meetup, with your pintrest name. I can invite you so we can share ideas.

Also check out some of my other boards as these will  become meetups in the future.  I love seeing what other people are inspired by so lets be friends on pintrest so we can get new ideas going!

Please start messaging below for ideas for locations with pictures would be amazing. If you think you skills would be best suit for this shoot for example hairstylists that are good at braiding or photographers that are used to shooting with a high level of brightness. Also I would really like to use a blonde model for this shoot.

Keep in mind that you must comment or share some of your ideas to be apart of this meetup.

Cant wait to hear what you guys think of one of the first posted meetups!

results.description:
Update on April 23 Saturday 

Please notice that the time has changed to

4:00P.M. - 6:00P.M. due to the weather.  

Rain has already stopped  earlier this morning at Acton area, which is about 23 miles West from Boston.   But, a few members living in Boston area say it's still raining at 9:30 A.M.   The weather.com or other weather forecast service says it will be cloudy by 12 P.M.  and will be sunny by 4P.M. 

I think the ground in the park will be dry by 4P.M.  

So, we will start Ohanami later today and may go to eat dinner together  if you like to.  

Ohanami (お花見) is a Japanese traditional picnic in Spring in which you and your friends, family, or colleagues watch cherry blossoms together over eating and drinking under cherry trees. We are going to Arnold Arboretum in Boston for Ohanami. This will be also a farewell party for Ryan who will leave from Boston next month. Please bring foods, snacks, and drinks (no alcohol ) if you can. Or, maybe we will just order pizza and share the cost. If you have a good idea for the food, let us know. I have a big tarp which is good for 20 people sitting on the ground and will bring it. Please notice that if it's rain, this event may be cancelled or rescheduled.

Update on April 21 Wednesday:

The cherry trees in the park has started to blossom, so this weekend should be a good time to go there to watch it.  A bad news is that we can not picnic in the park although the park seems to be not very strict.  You can eat foods like sandwich, but basically no picnic allowed, a park officer told me.  There is a nice cafe by the park entrance and can have meals.  So, we do not bring pizza or big lunch boxes.  If you want to bring snack and a food like sandwich, I think it's fine.  

Any opinion or suggestion? 

Directions:

By Car: Parking is available outside the main gate, along the Arborway, and around the Arboretum’s perimeter. More parking information.


By MBTA:  Public Transportation: Take the T to Forest Hills. Exit the upper level of the station and cross South Street. Turn right on South Street and head uphill, parallel to the exit ramp, to the Forest Hills Gate.

By Bus:Take the #39 bus to the South Street and Custer Avenue stop in Jamaica Plain (just after the monument stop). Walk back a few feet to the intersection and turn left on Custer Street. At the end of Custer Street (three blocks) you’ll be facing the Arboretum. Turn right and proceed to the pedestrian crossing. After the crossing, turn right. The Arboretum’s main gate will be 10 yards ahead, on the left.

For more information: http://www.arboretum.harvard.edu/visit/directions/


Arnold Arboretum is big, and I have not found the place where we can sit and watch Cherry blossoms yet.   So, it may be easier to meet at MBTA Forest Hills station.  Thank you for Ken who provides the local area's information.  

Konbanwa, Sam-san. I'm sending you MBTA links, with info about Forest hills. The first link concerns the Orange Line, and shows how the Green and Red Lines connect to Orange Line.http://www.mbta.com/schedules_and_maps/subway/lines/?route=ORANGE This second link has info about all the bus lines to and from Forest hills. http://www.mbta.com/schedules_and_maps/subway/lines/stations/?stopId=11788 If you guys still plan the event, I think you should meet at Forest Hills, and walk together to Arboretum, because there's a lot of construction going on, and it could be confusing, even though the park is across the street. I hope this is helpful, Ken
results.name: お花見, Ohanami at Arnold Arboretum in Boston

results.description:
Hello Friends And Seekers, 


Better World Meditation will be holding a unique evening activity highlighted by a 45 minute workshop led by Life and Business Coach Rob Kanzer. Rob brings to us his continuing good energy. Now in his 36th year of service, Rob works with those who want happier and healthier lives at home, more profitable and engaging interactions at work and bringing betterment to the world. Rob Kanzer, Creator of WSCA-FM's Radio Public Affairs program, "What can I Say?" Rob holds a Master's Certificate in Dispute Resolution, Past and current Certifications in Mediation, Personal Training and Crisis Intervention Counseling. Rob is a Successful Business Man and owns Rob Kanzer Seminars LLC.

The evening will start off with a Calming Meditation by Steven Kriger, founder of Better World Meditation. Steven brings over 40 years experience in Yoga, Meditation, and Holistic Health. Our mission is to "Create a Better World Through Spiritual Practice.

Date: Saturday, April 23rd from 6:30-9:00PM

 Location: Theosophical Society, 21 Maple Street. Arlington, MA . 

Admission: $15 (Includes Workshop and Meditation)

RSVP: click on the green box "I'm Going" (Please note that our event is being advertised on 3 different Meetup.com pages as well as many other sources. We will be having attendees coming from outside of Meetup.com. )

If you are inviting friends not on meetup, they can find us at the following link: www.meetup.com/thebenefitsofcoaching

For More information on the event:

 Call Steven Kriger (617)[masked]

Visit: www.betterworldmeditation.com

E-Mail: [masked]

For More Information about Rob Kanzer 

Call Rob Kanzer: (617)[masked]

Visit: www.RobKanzer.com

E-Mail: [masked]

Much Peace and Gratitude
results.how_to_find_us: Our building 21 Maple Street is behind 19 Maple Street down the driveway to the left. Parking is available directly behind our building and on Maple Street. Please do not park in neighbor's parking lot to the left.

results.description:
The </a><a href="http://www.meetup.com/BostonVolunteer/">Boston Volunteers are a 501c3 nonprofit! 

Once in a while the Boston Volunteers have a social event. 

The purpose is to bring people together and inspire people to get more involved. 

It's a hassle-free opportunity for you to meet new people who share your values. 

For this event we will need 3-4 people to help. 

Can you help: 

1. Setting up/ breaking down

2. Greeting people and making sure everybody feels welcome

3. Collecting donations

Help the Boston Volunteers. Only 4 spots. Get in FREE!

We're expecting more than 125 young professionals. 

Learn more: http://www.meetup.com/AwesomeBoston/events/229897507/

Can you help? 

Thank you in advance, :)
Josh and friends

P.S. Can you please post on the wall which are your top two choices to help with? 

P.P.S. A couple other young pros groups will be joining us.

Do you like to do good too: Boston Volunteers

Do you live near Brookline: Brookline Area 20's & 30's Adventurers


Are you a Foodie: Favorite Boston Restaurants<a href="http://www.meetup.com/BostonAdventurers/"></a>

results.description:
Full Moon Gong: with Dharam Singh, Guruatma Kaur, and Siri Tapa Kaur

New Moon Gong: with Guruatma Kaur

 What to expect: Preparing ourselves with a Kundalini Yoga set we will create a body-mind balance for change and healing. While in this state the sound waves of the gong and bowls induce an extended state of effortless meditation and relaxation that facilitates the movement of prana through the body and psyche for healing. In this way, the gong is a tool that magnifies and focuses the power of the yoga experience.   


We will finish with tea, treats, and joy! 

Please bring a thick blanket or cushion to lie on and a shawl to cover with!   

“The Gong is the first and last instrument for the human mind, there is only one thing that can supersede and command the human mind, the sound of the Gong. It is the first sound in the Universe, the sound that created the Universe. It’s the basic creative sound. To the mind, the sound of the gong is like a mother and father that gave it birth. The mind has no power to resist a gong that is well played.”  -Yogi Bhajan, Master of Kundalini Yoga   

Yoga & Gong: Guruatma Kaur: An IKYTA certified teacher and devoted student of Yogi Bhajan, Guruatma Kaur has been enthusiastically teaching Kundalini Yoga since 1979. She is lovingly dedicated to encouraging clarity, excellence, and relaxation into one’s True Self.  

Gong:  Dharam Singh began an exploration of sound as a saxophonist and flutist in the Bronx, NYC - an environment immersed in the rich music and culture of Africa by way of the Caribbean, Boriqua, African American and the counter culture, which gave him a multicultural perspective on musical language.   His passion for the transformative power of sound and music has found a place in the use of the Gong as he came to develop a unifying aural language that removes the separation between Head and Heart, Body and Soul. It is these frequencies, tones and harmonics, already given by Nature that he simply lives to share.  Dharam is a long time student of Yogi Bhajan and a resident of Guru Ram Das Ashram, where he is the go-to guy for anything related to Gong Yoga, including buying one - www.gongsongs.com He is part of the 'three-some' that leads the monthly Full Moon Gong event 

Meditation: Siri Tapa Kaur, a Reiki Master, Sat Nam Rasayan Practitioner, and certified Kundalini Yoga Teacher lives a life committed to being healthy, happy, and available to all. Everyone who knows her is touched by her open-hearted, compassionate mother energy. 

Note: in case of any date discrepancy between this Meetup and the website, please believe the website!
results.how_to_find_us: Yoga at the Ashram is located at the Baba Siri Chand Yoga Center at Guru Ram Das Ashram, 368 Village St in Millis, MA 02054
results.name: Full and New Moon Yoga, Gongs, and Meditation

results.description:
Yulia Applewood talented Psychic Medium presenting:

Séance/Medium Gallery Saturday April 23rd,[masked]:00pm - 9:00pm

Join us for a powerful and moving evening with Psychic Medium Yulia Applewood, as she connects with your loved ones who have passed into spirit. Experience the opportunity to reminisce with and receive messages from your dearly departed friends and relations or your ancestral spirit guides in a safe, positive environment. Yulia will conclude the gallery with a short, informative discussion regarding how you can access spirit in your daily life; followed by a question and answer session. Although not everyone is guaranteed a message, everyone will be able to witness the phenomenon of spirit communication and is invited to ask questions and share their experiences.
As a natural medium, Yulia has communicated with the spirit world throughout her lifetime. She is also psychically gifted and has been offering guidance to clients for years using a variety of different modalities such as: palm, tarot card, oracle card, tealeaf and bone readings as well as crystal ball gazing. Yulia uses her gifts of energetic healing, folk magic and common wisdom to bring hope and empowerment to her clients in a compassionate and empathetic way. Each reading and remedy is confidential and uniquely tailored to the client's needs. She also offers dream interpretation and intensive spiritual counseling. Cost: $25.00 (advance signup)
PAYPAL USERS.... PLEASE BRING YOUR PAYMENT RECEIPT. THANK YOU. PRE REGISTRATION REQUIRED

Private sessions available Call[masked] for more info.
results.name: Connect with loved ones that had passed away and the Spiritual World

results.description:
Join us for a high energy, fun evening to celebrate drumming, community, dance. Fine for beginners as well as experts. We're in a great space with lots of room for dancers - so come and try both drumming and dance if you wish. Bring friends, extra drums to share, maybe some snacks. MINI-CLASS at 6:30 sharp. A good introduction for beginners, and a tune-up for experts.

The Framingham Drum Circle will now only meet with a minimum of 14 YES rsvp's.


Admission $10 children under 12 Free

If you never drummed - welcome - we make it easy, and have drums to share.

Please log in to meetup group and "RSVP" so we know how many are coming, and how many drums to bring.

If you have NOT filled out the "bio" questions, please do so by logging in at Meetup group and editing the "profile", where you can let us know if you have a drum, or need one.

THANKS!!

John & Andra & Alan & Fanta& Lillian... and you and you and you, were there!
results.how_to_find_us: Entrance is from parking lot behind the church. If lost call me at 617-967-2962  - John Tracy

results.description:
Let me ask you something...

• Have you ever gone to a social gathering and met someone you were really interested in, but you didn't know how to let them know?

• Do you have lots of polite conversations that never really move beyond small talk?

• Have you ever met someone who seemed to have a knack for being outgoing and flirtatious, and you wished you had a little bit of that magic too?

If you answered "yes" to any of these questions, then you're going to love this!

************************************************* 
REVEALED:  THE "SECRET" LANGUAGE OF FLIRTING 
*************************************************

What if I told you that there was a "secret" language that men and women use to communicate romantic interest in each other?

And what if I told you that if you knew this language, you'd be able to make the people you're interested in feel attracted to you instantly ... but if you didn't know this language (and many people don't), the people you're interested in are likely to "turn off" and move on to someone else... never looking back or giving you a second chance?

Here's the bottom line.  If you tend to have lots of polite conversations that fizzle out and go nowhere, then this is going to change your life!

Why?  Because once you understand how flirting really works (and how to use it yourself), you'll find yourself effortlessly attracting the people you desire as if it was the easiest and most natural thing in the world!

In this unique event, I'm going to pull back the curtain and give you an inside look at what flirting really is, how to recognize it, and how to use it to let someone know that you're interested in them (but do it in a safe, fun, and effective way).

************************************************* 
HERE'S A SMALL SAMPLE OF WHAT YOU'LL LEARN: 
*************************************************

• Revealed: The "invisible language" being spoken in every flirtatious interaction.  This has been hidden from you all your life, but now you'll always be able to spot it, and use it to attract the people you really want to date.

• How to instantly tell if someone is flirting with you (and what to do if they are).

• A simple technique that compels people to flirt back with you (and automatically makes them more interesting dating you).

• How to let someone know that you're interested in them without saying it directly (they'll be so glad you let them know in a way that puts no pressure on them to respond right away).

• The #1 mistake that automatically kills any attraction a person has for you.  Hint: If you've had someone suddenly "go cold" on you and stop returning calls, you might have done this without realizing it.

• How to flirt with someone using text messages.  This works amazingly well whether you're just starting out with someone, or you've been dating them a long time and want to spice things up.

• A step-by-step template for asking someone out once they're interested in you.  This method works for every single time, and is almost completely rejection proof.

• And much more!

************************************************* 
HOW TO GET INVOLVED 
*************************************************

Where is it? The seminar is conveniently located at the Watertown Center For Healing Arts which is a beautiful facility for an event like this.

What time? Please plan on arriving by 6:45pm so you have time to settle in and meet the other members. We start promptly at 7:00pm and go until 9:30pm (with a break in the middle).  There are plenty of bus lines that go to the center, and there is also lots of parking both on the street and in a big parking lot near the center.  The bottom of this page has details:

http://watertowncenter.net/directions-2/ 

<a href="http://watertowncenter.net/directions-2/"></a>How much? Cheap.  If you took a class like this through an adult education center, you'd easily pay more than $50 to attend, and that's assuming there even is a class that could offer you all this, which there isn't. 

No other class offers you this kind of cutting edge training that's based in real world results.  This stuff WORKS!  What if one small change is all it takes to immediately and effortlessly begin attracting high-quality friends and dating prospects into your life?  I've seen it happen many times in this group, and it can happen for you too. 

So how much? Because I want to help as many people as I can, I've decided to keep the price very affordable so that anyone who wants to come will be able to.  The cost for this event is only $20, which is very low considering the quality of training that you'll be getting.

Think about it... that's 67 cents a day for a month.  What else do you spend 67 cents on every day that makes no difference in your social life (or love life) whatsoever? I promise that this will be well worth your time.

How big is the class? In order to make sure I can personally help as many people as possible, the class is limited to the first 50 people who RSVP.  I'm listing this in six groups, so there are over 14,500 people seeing this. If you want in, then be sure to put in your RSVP right now in order to lock in your spot.

I'm looking forward to seeing you there.

Warmly, 
Jason

P.S. - Take down my cell number in case you have any questions about the event or if you get lost. The venue is extremely easy to find, so you should have no problems, but just in case, my cell is[masked]-8871.
results.how_to_find_us: Go through the front door, up the stairs, and follow the signs that say SEMINAR.  It's easy to find.
results.name: DATING SEMINAR: Flirting 101 - How To Create Instant Sexual Attraction

venue.name: Watertown Center for Healing Arts (Charles River Room)

results.description:
Hey fellow Social Fun members, 


Do you want to meet new people who share your values? 
Do you want easily meet interesting new people? 
What's our celebration going to be like (see pictures) 

Join us for our popular Mix & Mingle celebration. The purpose of this Meetup is for you to meet people who are different from you. Discover new communities. 
Discover who else is coming. 

For this event we will be joining one of Boston's most popular nonprofits. 
Learn more:  Boston Volunteers

Space is very limited b/c the room is small. This event will fill up very soon. We'll get lots of the regulars and lots of new members. 

A couple other groups will be joining us including: 

Don't you like to do good: Boston Volunteers

Do you live in the Brookline area: Brookline Area 20's & 30's Adventurers 

Are you a Foodie: Favorite Boston Restaurants

We will be providing lots and lots of food for you. We will serve the food at close to 7:30, so don't miss it!   

Please bring a 10 bill with you to help cover our costs for the event, Meetup costs, and to provide more volunteer events for you in the future. Please bring a 10. There will be a long line, and we want to keep it moving fast. 

Oh, and by the way, we'll also be providing a drink ticket (good until 8:30) for you. Good for one refreshing and ice-cold spirit to quench your thirst. Complimentary! :) 

What a Hassle-free way to meet new people who share your values. 

JWe hope you can join us, :) 
Josh and friends

P.S. How to get to Sissy K's: The Boston Volunteers strongly supports public transport to get to all our events. Especially for this event b/c parking is very challenging near Faneuil Hall.

What are our favorite ways to get to Sissy's. 

1. What's the popular and reliable Boston bus that everybody's using: Bridj. Bridj stops right next to Sissy's. 

Learn more Bridj.

2. Easily bike here with Hubway

Learn more: Hubway

3. Need a car? My favorite is renting a Prius with ZipCar

Learn more: ZipCar
results.how_to_find_us: We'll have the entire room exclusively for us. I'll provide my cell closer to the day of the celebration!

results.description:
Scenergy Dating is bringing a bit of mystery, anticipation, and excitement into your dating life with our signature "Mystery Cards" icebreaker. You may have heard of Speed Dating events but Scenergy Dating is unlike anything you've experienced. For starters, we emphasize a "dress to impress" atmosphere where professional singles of all backgrounds are welcome to mix and mingle under one roof. Our professional staff understands the jitters that come with attending a singles event and they do a great job at calming your nerves and welcoming you in.

Once you enter, instead of spending time texting friends, you will be encouraged to make new connections while also enjoying our signature icebreaker in a trendy environment hand selected by your coordinator.


WHAT MAKES SCENERGY DIFFERENT:

- We're a full dating solution that also provides personal matchmaking, online dating, and a variety of events.
- Our events are "Shaken not Stirred"!
- Event Coordinators not only check you in but are actively engaged in ensuring you have a good time and feel safe.
- We host seminars, dance lessons, dating workshops, and many types of icebreakers to keep you entertained.


HOW "MYSTERY SINGLES" WORKS:

- Singles will receive an index card
- They will fill out information according to the coordinator's instructions
- Coordinator will then pass around the cards
- Attendees will be encouraged to find their "Mystery Single", while also mixing & mingling
- The more you play the more chances you have in winning grand prizes!


WHAT TO DO/NOT TO DO:

- DO get your money's worth and approach as many singles as you can!
- DO bring your friends but DO NOT stay in your comfort zone!
- DO focus on socializing and making new friends DO NOT just focus on looks!

ENTRANCE FEE:


* Limited to the first 20 men and 20 women so it's important to pre-pay. In order to have a close number of men and women we will sell tickets in increments of 10, when both genders are sold out we will release more tickets accordingly.
- $25 at the door
- $15 pre-paid by RSVP by CLICKING HERE
- $15 at the door "Tag Along Special" (Bring a friend and both save $5)

PERKS:

- Huge drink specials for Scenergy attendees only.


RAFFLE PRIZES:

- FREE passes to future Scenergy Dating events, cash prizes, and so much more!
results.name: Scenergy Dating Presents "Mystery Singles" (Mid 30's - 50's)

Brickroad Productions - Presents Gangsters in Love - A Comedy Dinner Show

At the Wakefield Elks

April 23rd, Doors open at 6pm


Dinner 7pm show to follow

Proceeds go to MA Eager Fund 

First come first serve with ticket purchase (they do expect to sell out)


Please only rsvp once you are ready to mail in your payment:)

Tickets can be purchased at the Wakefield Elks (bartender) or by mailing me a check.  Checks payable to Wakefield Elks in the amount of $25.00  you can get check to me or mail it to me:  Sue Collins, 25 Shady Ave., Wakefield MA  01880 Again NOTE checks payable to  Wakefield Elks please:) NOT ME...thanks


APRIL 17TH LAST DAY TO BUY TICKETS!!!

Let's plan on four tables of 10

Hope you will join us.

Well, sort of in love. You will love the laughs, the fun and the mystery that erupts at Vinnie and Maria’s Jack and Jill party. And with best friends like Sal and Louis, known more for their criminal tendencies than for being especially bright, this party can only be delightful. A dastardly deed, numerous suspects, a tangled web of clues and lots of chances for audience participation are definitely included. Don’t worry if you don’t remember any of these characters, they will definitely remember you.

*Saturday, April 23, Doors open at 6pm, dinner at 7pm

*Wakefield Elks, 63 Bay State Rd., Wakefield

Show is subject to change.


Please avoid fragrances, perfume etc. we do have members with severe allergies.

<a href="http://watertowncenter.net/directions-2/"></a>How much? Cheap.  If you took a class like this through an adult education center, you'd easily pay more than $50 to attend, and that's assuming there even is a class that could offer you all this, which there isn't.

No other class offers you this kind of cutting edge training that's based in real world results.  This stuff WORKS!  What if one small change is all it takes to immediately and effortlessly begin attracting high-quality friends and dating prospects into your life?  I've seen it happen many times in this group, and it can happen for you too.

So how much? Because I want to help as many people as I can, I've decided to keep the price very affordable so that anyone who wants to come will be able to.  The cost for this event is only $20, which is very low considering the quality of training that you'll be getting.

Think about it... that's 67 cents a day for a month.  What else do you spend 67 cents on every day that makes no difference in your social life (or love life) whatsoever? I promise that this will be well worth your time.

How big is the class? In order to make sure I can personally help as many people as possible, the class is limited to the first 50 people who RSVP.  I'm listing this in six groups, so there are over 14,500 people seeing this. If you want in, then be sure to put in your RSVP right now in order to lock in your spot.

I'm looking forward to seeing you there.

Warmly,
Jason

P.S. - Take down my cell number in case you have any questions about the event or if you get lost. The venue is extremely easy to find, so you should have no problems, but just in case, my cell is[masked]-8871.

results.description:
Come join us at this great coffeehouse for a wonderful night of music! Forever Young is a group of performers that pay tribute to the SONGS of Neil Young. No one in the band tries to imitate Neil Young.  All of the musicians performing in Forever Young are staples of the Rhode Island music scene and veterans of
many national and regional tours. In addition, they are all fans and have been influenced by the music of Neil Young. Drawing on the 40+ year career of Neil Young; the show highlights many of Young’s popular songs and a few of the more obscure numbers. The show is presented with the full seven-piece band
doing both the acoustic and electric songs that Neil Young is famous for. The show is reminiscent of the "Four Way Street" live album recorded by Crosby, Stills, Nash and Young, and of Neil Young with his many different back-up bands.

Listen to some of Forever Young's music HERE!


It is best to buy your ticket far in advance, they sell out often. The tickets are general seating for $20 and can be purchased online here.

The doors open at 7:30 and there is usually a line at that time. Let's try to get there early so that we can find seats together! The show starts at 8:00pm.

There are light refreshments and homemade goodies for purchase before the show begins and during intermission.
results.how_to_find_us: The coffeehouse is at the First Universalist Church in Franklin, Look for the white sign for the church and follow the driveway.....it is tucked back in off the road

results.description:
Daniella Miraglia / Opened by Steve Marchena


Danielle Miraglia comes armed with a strong steady thumb on an old Gibson, an infectious stomp-box rhythm, and a harmonica. Her songs range from heartfelt to socially conscious and will move both your heart and hips. On her latest release "Glory Junkies," she's joined by a killer cast of musicians blending the classic rock vibe of The Rolling Stones and Janis Joplin with Danielle's signature lyrical ability to explore human nature at its best and worst.


Danielle was nominated for a 2015 Boston Music Award for Singer-Songwriter of the Year, and keeps touring major venues across the United States and beyond, shining in both the folk and blues circuits. She has shared the stage with the likes of Johnny Winter, Sonny Landreth, Robert Cray, and many more.

"See this rising star as soon as you can." http://www.daniellem.com/epk

Steve Marchena is an American classical, rock, jazz guitarist, and harmonica player. He has shared the stage with Al Di Meola, Nuno Bettencourt, J. Geils and many other famous guitarists. In addition he has toured with musical theater productions such as: Beehive, Leader Of The Pack, Smokey Joe's Cafe, Footloose, A Closer Walk with Patsy Cline, Always... Patsy Cline.

This event is collaboration between the Dedham School of Music and Mother Brook Arts and Community Center. All are welcome!


http://www.motherbrookarts.org/concert-daniella-miraglia

results.description:
We will have a series of meetups throughout the year to visit specific neighborhoods in Boston and Cambridge, and perhaps later branching out into other towns and cities. This is meant to be both about getting to know parts of the city better, as well as being a photography challenge, because these are unglamorous targets compared to, say, the Zakim bridge, and force you to find opportunities to portrait the neighborhoods and architecture in a compelling way. Use this as an opportunity to create a project for yourself (Boston brownstone entry stairs? Night street photography?)


Neighborhoods to be visited will include Beacon Hill, East Boston, Fenway, Backbay, Harvard Square and others. If you have suggestions or requests, please email me or post a comment. Mattapan, anyone? :-)


The paradigm for these meetups will be to provide you with basic information and some images about the neighborhood, meet as a group to briefly discuss the opportunities, but then spread out to investigate the area, rather than moving in a group. If you do not feel comfortable walking on your own, make sure to tag along with someone in groups of 2-3.


Our first neighborhood will be South End, an area of little glamour, but there are two parks (Blackstone and Franklin Sq), a burial ground, an almost-abandoned building (with shops on the bottom), the very impressive Cathedral of the Holy Cross, Boston Medical Center spanning across Mass Avenue, some industrial looking structures and views on the highway, if you venture far enough. And, of course, a plethora of Boston's brownstone buildings with its neat stairs and doors.


Suggested equipment: hiking shoes, you will be walking quite a bit, tripod, intervalometer, camera and a variety of lenses, from fisheyes, wide angles to medium zooms. Tilt-shift lenses or lens babies will be very applicable, if you have those. Dress appropriately for the weather and walking around.


Weather forecast will be updated as we get closer. Parking is available on the street or google the nearest garage. Sunset will be at 7:35, we will meet at 8 with a little light left and this is a full-moon evening. Watch the comments for updates.
results.name: Boston Neighborhoods: South End

This is it! Another edition of Boston A-List's Best Night of Comedy, THE MENDOZA LINE!

This and every Saturday night live from the back room of the The Dugout Cafe (722 Comm Ave), John Baglio, Julia Claire, and Zach "Zack" Armentrout bring you a different lineup stacked with the biggest, baddest, and bestiest comedians from Boston and beyond. And guess what? Its only FIVE DOLLARS! With drink specials as far as the eye can see and free popcorn, this intimate atmosphere is the perfect place to take in some meaningful and quality laughs!

This week is John Baglio's last show as a coproducer, as he is leaving is behind like an idiot to follow his comedic dreams and head to NYC!

Here's the link to buy your tickets now to guarantee a seat as room is limited. Our shows have frequently sold out, and we'd hate to break your little heart and turn you away: https://www.eventbrite.com/e/the-mendoza-line-bostons-best-weekly-comedy-showcase-tickets-15228587114

results.description:
Having spent a few years of my life living in Manhattan I am always keen to go back and re-visit my old haunts. This time I am looking to take a very small group of people with me for a whole long day of photography in the Big Apple.  I will take you on a guided tour of some  well  known and lesser known  photogenic parts of the City  and assist you in getting some great shots.

We will leave at 6am from Staples Parking lot in Weymouth (close to route 3) and I will drive you to New York City where we will spend the rest of the day exploring and photographing.  We will  leave in the evening and head back to Weymouth. I can take  people in relative comfort in my Van.

The standard  cost of a three hour guided workshop with a professional photographer in Manhattan ( in a group of 15)  is $150 and up.  For just $175 I will be your personal chauffeur and guide for the day in a group limited to  just four participants. We will park the van when we arrive in New York so there will be lots of walking involved.  Please be sure that you are able to be on your feet for several hours (we will take a couple of breaks but expect five to six hours on your feet). 

The Detail

The price for the guided tour and workshop is far less than I often charge for a six hour one day workshop in Pembroke, and you get the advantage of being able to pick my brains for many hours.   The car pooling to New York and back with me is free of charge and is not part of the workshop which begins and ends when we are out of the van and on the streets of New York.

You will be responsible for your own food and refreshments.  We will most likely find a suitable cafe or deli for lunch and/or dinner while in New York.

You must be willing to meet in Weymouth by 6am and travel with the group. We will not be making detours or meeting up with people who wish to travel independently.
results.name: New York, New York (and back) - a guided workshop

venue.name: The New England Center for Homeless Veterans

results.description:
I volunteer a couple of times a month serving lunch at the shelter. Great group of men and women who have served our country and have come back needing a little help. The Center, which was started by a Veteran, provides housing, health care, social services, food, as well as a multitude of other services for our returning heroes. They have volunteer groups come in on weekends and do breakfast service. We don't provide the food, just smiles and friendly faces. The serving starts at 7:15am and we would be done by around 9.  We have gone as a group several times and hope to keep this up monthly, there's a limit to 6 servers each time. It's really a wonderful time. Some of the ladies asked about baking/bringing something. I also spoke with the head of the kitchen....just avoid things with nuts because of allergies. Hope to see you all then! We can carpool, it's near the Orange line and if you drive in you can park right in front. Also remember a hat, you need to have your head/hair covered to serve.

 My telephone number if you have any questions or have a last minute change to status is[masked]

2 things:
1. Since this is a popular event, I'd like to ask that you only sign up only if you are able to get up early on a Sunday.  There will be several Sundays throughout the year I'll actually take myself off as well so that opens up one spot. On the days I cook, I'll also open it up to have 7 servers so that more can come.
2. To prevent the # of no shows we've had, I'm going to just let everyone know that if you know show, I will remove you from future volunteer opportunities with the Center. I've hated the times when due to no shows, the Vets have had to step in to help, especially because there are often individuals that were on the wait list and didn't have the opportunity to show. If you cannot attend, please RSVP no ahead of time, or at the very least, just call or text me if you aren't well the morning of the shift, just so I know and can get them to provide help when I get there. My telephone # is[masked]-1526. Those letting me know that they can't make a day ahead of time won't be considered a no show.

Thank you for your ongoing support. I appreciate it and I know that the Veterans do as well.
results.name: Volunteer and serve breakfast at the New England Center for Homeless Veterans

results.description:
By signing up and/or attending a Boston Area Photography Group meetup you agree to the Boston Area Photography Group Disclaimer below.

No guests are permitted on Boston Area Photography Group events. Please have your guests join our Meetup. 

MEETUP DESCRIPTION:  I drove by there this morning and things are starting to pop. Next weekend should be amazing. Of course that also means amazing crowds so I suggest we get there when it opens. Unfortunately that isn't until 8:00 am but that's probably still early enough to feel like we own the place once we get back into the grounds. As many of you know this is also a world renowned birding location so bring that long glass if you've a mind to.

Lets meet inside, right at the main entrance/gateway. There's some construction going on there but it's probably better to congregate there instead of at the chapel in case there is a service scheduled. As I recall there's some parking in front but if there is a service going on you'll have to drive into the cemetery to park and walk back to the front.

Link to the website for maps, etc.:

http://mountauburn.org/

GEAR/CLOTHING/FOOTWARE SUGGESTIONS: Tripod, circular polarizer, macro.

Remember: we are volunteers. You are responsible for your own safety and enjoyment.

Boston Area Photography Group Disclaimer: As a condition of your voluntary participation in this activity you acknowledge and agree to the following: 
By using this site, you hereby RELEASE and DISCHARGE it's owners, principals, affiliates, presenters, organizer, hosts and participants from any and all liability, claims, demands or causes of action that you now have, or may have in the future, for injuries, damages, death and/or economic loss of any kind or nature, arising in whole or in part out of the activities, advice or information contained herein. results.description:
Event Organizer: Michael Blair @ (978)[masked]


=====

Read the entire description before you RSVP and answer all of the questions that are part of the process. Failure to answer them will result in your removal from this event.

Answers DO NOT carry over from one event to another so you must answer them for EACH EVENT. Also, questions might not show up if you RSVP from a phone or tablet so if you don't see them you will need to use a computer.

If you underestimate the demands of this event; overestimate your experience, knowledge, skills or abilities; or come unprepared you put yourself and others at risk. Consider this before you RSVP.

=== What We're Doing ===

The plan is to hike to one of the 4,000 footers in New Hampshire - Carrigain. We will use Signal Ridge Trail to reach the summit and then turn around to retrace our steps to get back to the trailhead.

If you are interested in participating in this event sign up for the waiting list. I will add people that (1) answer all of the questions that are part of the RSVP process and (2) have done similar hikes within the past three months.

RSVPs close 24 hours before the event.

The maximum group size for this trip will be 12 people. 

Guests aren't permitted.

Dogs are only permitted with prior approval of the event organizer.

=== Trip Summary ===

We start as a group, hike as a group, and finish as a group. Our pace will be that of the slowest hiker. This trip isn't for you if you are faster than the group and don't want to stay with us, if you want to head off on your own, or if you are slower than the group and expect us to constantly wait for you.

On this moderate pace (~2.0 MPH) trip we will hike about 10.2 miles and climb about 3,700 feet. It should take an average hiker about 7 hours to complete (this doesn't include time taking breaks). This event is considered INTERMEDIATE because of the pace, distance, and elevation gain.

Use this link for more information about where we are going and how we will get there:

• http://trailsnh.com/peaks/nh/4000/13-Mt-Carrigain-4700

Dangerous weather conditions will cancel this event - I will post an update and/or send an email to all confirmed participants.


Use this link for the current weather forecast:

• http://forecast.weather.gov/MapClick.php?lat=44.0933966660005&lon=-71.44757652599964&site=all&smap=1#.VBuboUtNZ_Y


=== What to Bring ===


While I don't think that we will need snow shoes we might still need traction - either Kahtoola Microspikes or Hillsound Trail Crampons.

Use this link for a list of items needed for a three season day hike: 

• http://files.meetup.com/492954/Three_Season_Dayhike_gear_list.pdf

Do not rely on others to have extra items to share with you at the meeting spot or on the trail. You should know how to use all of your equipment - test and adjust it prior to this trip. 

=== Directions ===

results.description:
Directions:

Route 2 to Route 32 North, exit 17, in Athol, MA.

Take Route 32 north for about 11 miles.  The parking for the Trustees of Reservations for Royalston Falls will be on your right.  If you cross into NH you've gone too far!

The coordinates on the Trustees of Reservations Webpage for Royalston Falls Parking are correct.


This is the year that the BSOT will hike the M&M/New England National Scenic Trail from north to south, at least to the Connecticut border, starting at Grand Monadnock.  The plan is to hike one section every 2-3 weeks over the course of the spring, summer, into the fall.  We’ll see how far we get!

The M&M Trail, named for the Metacomet Ridge and Mount Monadnock (not the candy. Not the rapper, either. Sorry).

For Section 2 we'll start from the train depot in Troy, NH and continue southeast, over Little Monadnock, through Rhododendren State Park, over Grassy Hill, crossing Route 119 in Richmond, NH, then make our way south to Royalston Falls in Royalston, MA.

We'll hike about 10-11 miles.  The trek is rated Moderate with a  1900' + elevation gain. Time, including carspotting, of 8+ hours.   This is a daytrip!


Check out the ratings guide I use:


http://hikenewengland.com/LegendRating.html


From the weblink:

The New England National Scenic Trail (NET) is a 215-mile trail route that has been in existence for over half a century. It travels through 39 communities in Connecticut and Massachusetts, and is comprised primarily of the historic Mattabesett, Metacomet, and Monadnock (M-M-M) Trails.  The route showcases classic New England landscape features: long distance vistas with rural towns as a backdrop, agrarian lands, un-fragmented forests, and large river valleys. The trail also travels through important Native American and colonial historical landmarks and highlights a range of diverse ecosystems and natural resources: trap-rock ridges, mountain summits, forested glades, vernal pools, lakes, streams and waterfalls.

https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/New_England_National_Scenic_Trail

http://amcberkshire.org/netmm

http://www.hikesafe.com

Directions to Royalston Falls can be found at:

http://www.thetrustees.org/places-to-visit/central-ma/royalston-falls.html


For those of you tracking this series via the AMC Webpage, we're hiking the trail in reverse order, sections 20 and 19.

Carpooling is welcome.  If you would like to carpool you're welcome to post that request in the *Comments* section of this event's page.  But please respond to those posts via *Meetup Messenger*.  You do that by clicking on a member's profile, then clicking on *message*..

Cell Phones and Electronic Devices:  I ask that while on the BSOT events that I host you limit your use of electronic devices to the following activities:

Map My Hike or other Hiking Apps, Location Services, Cameras, Weather Apps.

Of the many pleasant features of being out and about is that we all get away from the constant distractions of cell phones and electronics.  I ask that while on the events I host you:

Do not use your phone (of course! I make exceptions for emergencies and calling a taxi/Uber if you can't make it back on foot!)

Do not listen to the radio.

Do not play music.

Thank you in advance for respecting this request.


The Fine Print: 

No dogs or guests are allowed on BSOT hikes. Have your guest join the group so they can agree to the liability waiver and attend an event.

You need a recognizable facial photo as your profile picture in order to participate in this and all Trekkers events.

Duration: Approximately 8+ hours. However, any time estimate given by an Event Organizer is just that. Actual times vary greatly according to weather, trail conditions and the group itself. Don't sign up if you've scheduled something later in the day. The Organizer is not responsible for getting you back in time.

There is no way of knowing trail conditions ahead of time. Use your own judgment. Anyone with recurrent "No Shows" or about whom we have received complaints from fellow hikers will not be accepted. If you haven't hiked with us before, add yourself to the list if you can adhere to these basic prerequisites. Please don't RSVP "Yes" unless you really intend to come. We are committed to being there for you. If you are not equally committed to being there then please don't sign up.

This hike is rated Moderate.  You should be able to stay with the group going at a pace of 2+ mph. This is a group event and participants are expected to follow the lead, stay together, stop at junctions or summits, and support all participants should circumstances require teamwork. We start together and finish together. If you decide to leave the group at any time, you are on your own. We hike in light rain or showers, but heavy snow or extreme cold weather cancels. Bring water, hiking boots (not sneakers), bug spray and lunch/snacks. Protect yourself against deer ticks and dress in layers.

No dogs and no guests are allowed on hikes. Have your guest join the group so they can agree to the liability waiver and attend an event. 

Please remember that your Event Organizers are volunteers, the event is free and we are all adults. The people who have the best times on these hikes are those who stay loose and roll with things as they happen. If you are expecting Daniel Boone as your leader, you’re barking up the wrong tree (woof!). If you need everything to run perfectly, this hike is not for you.

By clicking the "Yes" option on the RSVP link you are agreeing to the Liability Waiver as stated below: 

Remember: Your Event Organizers are volunteers. You are solely responsible for your own safety and enjoyment. As a condition of your voluntary participation in this activity you acknowledge and agree to the following: this activity involves inherent risks that can cause property damage, injury, illness, disability, and/or death to participants and/or others; you assume all risk associated with this activity; you are responsible for having the necessary knowledge, skills, abilities, clothing, and equipment to safely participate in this activity; you have read and agree to adhere to the safety standards detailed @ http://www.hikesafe.com/; the organizer(s) of this activity is a volunteer; and you for yourself, your heirs, executors, and administrators release, hold harmless, and indemnify organizer(s) and all members of this group from any and all claims for property damage, injury, illness, disability, and/or death - including those caused by negligence and/or other reason.

Soooooo Boston Frisbee will once again be running the Spring Cambridge Classic 5K! The fall classic was such a blast why not do it again!? Like all Boston Frisbee events all experience and effort levels are welcome. The course is very flat and beginner friendly. Feel free to run/jog/walk. results.description:
This is a 5 mile loop around Hickory Hills Forest and Lunenburg conservation land. It takes approx 2 hours.   It is a nice hike mostly on Cart paths with rolling hills mixed in.. We will meet at 156 S. Row Road, in Lunenburg. Walk over to the trail head and make our way around the forest. Wear sturdy shoes or boots, sneakers are not recommended.  We do encounter streams, wet leaves and rocks, from time to time,. We will not leave anyone behind.  Socially behaved dogs are welcome, please bring your own doggie bags. 

NEW !!!!!! PLEASE TAKE NOTE: The time has changed and sneakers are not recommended.
Directions.
From the center of Lunenburg
Rte 2A East Approx 3/4 mile turn left onto Townsend Harbor Road.
Travel approx 1/2 mile on Townsend Harbor Road to the stop sign. Turn left at the stop sign to continue on Townsend Harbor Road.
Travel approx another 1/2 mile at the fork stay left onto South Row Road. Follow South Row Road for approx 1/2 mile.
My house is on the right.
Uturn Driveway, Brown house. Pull right into the driveway.

We meet for 9:00 and try to take off promptly.  

IF YOUR PLANS CHANGE, PLEASE CHANGE YOUR RSVP!

Thank you, I look forward to another successful hike.

results.description:
If interested in the following, please put yourself on the established waiting list.  A yes list will be provided as soon as possible.

All attendees must read, understand and agree to the waiver/liability as outlined by this website.

=== Random Group of Hikers Disclaimer ===

As a condition of your voluntary participation in this activity you acknowledge and agree to the following: this activity involves inherent risks that can cause property damage, injury, illness, disability, and/or death to participants and/or others; you assume all risk associated with this activity; you are responsible for having the necessary knowledge, skills, abilities, clothing, and equipment to safely participate in this activity; you know and will follow the Hike Safe Responsibility Code; the organizer(s) of this activity are volunteers; and you release, hold harmless, and indemnify the organizer(s) and all members of this group from any and all claims for property damage, injury, illness, disability, and/or death - including those caused by negligence and/or other reasons.

Do not rely on others to have extra items to share with you at the meeting spot or on the trail. You should know how to use all of your equipment - test and adjust it prior to this trip. 

Guests aren't permitted.

Dogs aren't permitted.

Distance Time Elev

Change

Trail / Waypoint Latitude Longitude

starting at Mount Stanton Trailhead 44° 05' 42" 71° 12' 49"

To reach the relocated east trailhead (the west trailhead is at Mt.

Langdon Shelter), leave the north side of US[masked] mi. west of

its junction with NH 16 in Glen and a short distance east of the

bridge over the Saco River. Follow a paved road (Covered Bridge

Ln.) west, bearing left at 0.2 mi. The road swings right (north), and

at 0.9 mi. the trailhead (sign) is on the left where the road swings

right again to head east as Hemlock Drive. Park on the roadside,

taking care not to block any driveways. (The new trailhead is 0.1

mi. west of the old trailhead, which was on Hemlock Drive.)

1.20 mi 1 hr 0 min +769 ft on Mt Stanton Trail

1.20 mi 1 hr 0 min +769 ft This trail passes over the low eastern summits of the Montalban

Ridge and affords many views from scattered ledges.

The yellow-blazed trail follows the left edge of a driveway for 80

yd. and enters the woods. It swings right, passing around the

house and climbs, turning left onto the older route of the trail. It

turns sharp left where the red-blazed WMNF boundary continues

straight ahead. It climbs moderately, levels briefly, then ascends a

steep gravelly section with poor footing. At the top of this pitch it

turns left and ascends at an easier grade, and the first of several

outlooks from White’s Ledge. The trail climbs steeply again, with

gravelly, slippery footing, after passing a large boulder on the right

of the trail, and it turns sharp right on a ledge, where there is a

good viewpoint just to the left of the trail and climbing becomes

easier. It passes about 15 yd. to the right of the true summit of Mt.

Stanton. The summit area is covered with a fine stand of red

(Norway) pines, and there are good views from nearby scattered

ledges.

to Whites Ledge 44° 05' 49" 71° 13' 23"

4.00 mi 2 hr 57 min +363 ft on Mt Stanton Trail

5.20 mi 3 hr 57 min +1132 ft The trail descends past a north outlook to the Stanton-Pickering

col, then ascends steadily, crosses a ledgy ridge and descends

slightly, then climbs steeply and passes 30 yd. to the right of the

true summit of Mt. Pickering. It then leads to ledges on a slightly

lower knob, where there are excellent views. The trail descends to

a minor col, then crosses over several interesting small humps

sometimes called the Crippies. These humps have scattered

outlook ledges, and the best view is from the fourth and last

Crippie.

After the last Crippie, the trail may be less well cleared and harder

to follow. It descends somewhat along the north side of the ridge

toward Mt. Langdon, then climbs north moderately with a few

steep pitches, passing a restricted outlook to Carter Dome, Carter

Notch, and Wildcat Mountain. The trail passes about 35 yd. to the

right of the summit of Mt. Langdon, which is wooded and

viewless, then descends easily to a gravel slope, turns right, and

continues downward to a brook that is crossed 60 yd. east of Mt.

Langdon Shelter, where the Mount Stanton Trail ends.

to Mt Langdon Shelter 44° 06' 53" 71° 16' 56"

0.40 mi 16 min +137 ft on Mt Langdon Trail

5.60 mi 4 hr 13 min +1269 ft This trail runs to the Mt. Langdon Shelter from the road on the

north side of the Saco near Bartlett village, meeting both the Mt.

Parker Trail and the Mt. Stanton Trail, and thus gives access to

both the higher and lower sections of the Montalban Ridge. It

should be noted that despite its name this trail does not get

particularly close to the summit of Mt. Langdon, which is crossed

by the Mt. Stanton Trail. Most of this trail is either within or close

to the boundary of the Presidential Range–Dry River Wilderness;

Mt. Langdon Shelter is just outside the Wilderness. In 2011 the

lower part of this trail had been disrupted by logging, and may

require considerable care to follow through the logged areas.

The Mt. Langdon Trail and the Mt. Stanton Trail both begin at the

WMNF Mt. Langdon Shelter, capacity eight. Some care is

required to follow the trail near the shelter. Water may be found in

a brook 60 yd. from the shelter on the Mt. Stanton Trail, although

in dry weather the brook bed may have to be followed downhill for

a distance. From the shelter, the Mt. Langdon Trail ascends

gradually southwest to a junction with the Mt. Parker Trail on the

right.

to the junction of Mt Parker Trail 44° 06' 50" 71° 17' 22"

entering wilderness area

2

Distance Time Elev

Change

Trail / Waypoint Latitude Longitude

2.20 mi 1 hr 13 min -1058 ft on Mt Langdon Trail

7.80 mi 5 hr 26 min +211 ft The Mt. Langdon Trail turns left (south) at the Mt. Parker Trail

junction in the Oak Ridge–Mt. Parker col. The trail ascends,

steeply at times. It then crosses Oak Ridge and descends with

gravelly footing, passing through an unusual stand of red oak. It

descends more steadily, bearing sharp left twice as the trail

begins to follow an old road. The trail crosses a brook and leaves

the Presidential Range–Dry River Wilderness. It then leads

through a recently logged area, where it may be difficult to follow

through a confusing network of skid roads. In general, the trail

follows the main road south. Directional arrows and some blazes

are found

at the major intersections, but great care must be taken to follow

the correct

route.

to the junction of Cave Mtn Path 44° 05' 16" 71° 17' 10"

leaving wilderness area

0.30 mi 9 min -155 ft on Mt Langdon Trail

8.10 mi 5 hr 35 min +56 ft The trail passes the path to Cave Mountain (marked by a small

sign and pink flagging in 2011) on the right and continues to follow

logging roads. It terminates at the trailhead parking area on River

Street just north of US 302 in Bartlett village.

to Mount Langdon Trailhead 44° 05' 03" 71° 17' 11"

Despite its name, this trail does not get close to the summit of Mt.

Langdon, which is crossed by the Mt. Stanton Trail. From the four

corners at the junction of US 302 and the Bear Notch Rd. in

Bartlett village, follow River St. (the road that leads north) across

a bridge over the Saco to a T-intersection at 0.4 mi. and bear left

a short distance to the trailhead parking area (sign) on the right.

The trail follows a logging road, bearing left at a fork at 75 yd., and

the path to Cave Mountain (unsigned and easily missed) diverges

left. The road gradually becomes older and less evident. The trail

enters the Presidential Range–Dry River Wilderness just before it

crosses a brook.

8.10 mi 5 hr 35 min +56 ft Totals

results.description:
Event Organizer: Steve Blum


THIS HIKE IS A SPECIAL OFFERING TO ACCOMODATE THE LARGE NUMBER OF PEOPLE ON THE WAITING LIST FOR THE SAME HIKE ON THE SAME DAY STARTING AN HOUR EARLIER THAN THIS ONE. PEOPLE ON THE WAITING LIST FOR THE EARLIER HIKE WILL HAVE FIRST PRIORTY. IF IT TURNS OUT THAT EVERYONE CAN GO ON THE ORIGINAL HIKE BECAUSE PEOPLE'S PLANS CHANGE THAN THIS HIKE WILL LIKLEY BE CANCELLED AND GROUPS MERGED INTO ONE.

=====

Read the entire description before you RSVP and answer all of the questions that are part of the process. Failure to answer them will result in your removal from this event.

Answers DO NOT carry over from one event to another so you must answer them for EACH EVENT. Also, questions might not show up if you RSVP from a phone or tablet so if you don't see them you will need to use a computer.

If you underestimate the demands of this event; overestimate your experience, knowledge, skills or abilities; or come unprepared you put yourself and others at risk. Consider this before you RSVP.

=== What We're Doing ===

The plan is to hike to one of the 4,000 footers in New Hampshire - Carrigain. We will use Signal Ridge Trail to reach the summit and then turn around to retrace our steps to get back to the trailhead.

If you are interested in participating in this event sign up for the waiting list. I will add people that (1) answer all of the questions that are part of the RSVP process and (2) have done similar hikes within the past three months.

RSVPs close 24 hours before the event.

The maximum group size for this trip will be 12 people. 

Guests aren't permitted.

Dogs are only permitted with prior approval of the event organizer.

=== Trip Summary ===

We start as a group, hike as a group, and finish as a group. Our pace will be that of the slowest hiker. This trip isn't for you if you are faster than the group and don't want to stay with us, if you want to head off on your own, or if you are slower than the group and expect us to constantly wait for you.

On this moderate pace (~2.0 MPH) trip we will hike about 10.2 miles and climb about 3,700 feet. It should take an average hiker about 7 hours to complete (this doesn't include time taking breaks). This event is considered INTERMEDIATE because of the pace, distance, and elevation gain.

Use this link for more information about where we are going and how we will get there:

• http://trailsnh.com/peaks/nh/4000/13-Mt-Carrigain-4700

Dangerous weather conditions will cancel this event - I will post an update and/or send an email to all confirmed participants.


Use this link for the current weather forecast:

• http://forecast.weather.gov/MapClick.php?lat=44.0933966660005&lon=-71.44757652599964&site=all&smap=1#.VBuboUtNZ_Y


=== What to Bring ===


While I don't think that we will need snow shoes we might still need traction - either Kahtoola Microspikes or Hillsound Trail Crampons.

Use this link for a list of items needed for a three season day hike: 

• http://files.meetup.com/492954/Three_Season_Dayhike_gear_list.pdf

Do not rely on others to have extra items to share with you at the meeting spot or on the trail. You should know how to use all of your equipment - test and adjust it prior to this trip. 

=== Directions ===

We will meet in the parking lot on the east side of Sawyer River Road about two miles south of Route 302. According to Google Maps this meeting spot is 174 miles from Boston and it should take about 2 hours and 56 minutes to drive there. Use this link for customizable driving directions:

https://www.google.com/maps/dir/Boston,+MA/Signal+Ridge+Trail,+Bartlett,+NH+03812/@43.3102315,-72.3608498,271120m/data=!3m2!1e3!4b1!4m13!4m12!1m5!1m1!1s0x89e3652d0d3d311b:0x787cbf240162e8a0!2m2!1d-71.058...</a>

<a href="https://goo.gl/maps/NhpBuQBan5R2">

While carpooling is encouraged you are responsible for coordinating your own rides. Use the comments section below to communicate with others who may also be looking to share a ride.

=== Random Group of Hikers Disclaimer ===

As a condition of your voluntary participation in this activity you acknowledge and agree to the following: this activity involves inherent risks that can cause property damage, injury, illness, disability, and/or death to participants and/or others; you assume all risk associated with this activity; you are responsible for having the necessary knowledge, skills, abilities, clothing, and equipment to safely participate in this activity; you know and will follow the Hike Safe Responsibility Code; the organizer(s) of this activity are volunteers; and you release, hold harmless, and indemnify the organizer(s) and all members of this group from any and all claims for property damage, injury, illness, disability, and/or death - including those caused by negligence and/or other reasons.

Meet to paint the model for a five week pose- Members (those paying the $25 monthly membership fee) may reserve a spot for $75, non-members for $90.    Three hours each Sunday morning, 9:30-12:30.  You can come individual days by paying $15 (members) or $25 (non-members) for a single drop-in, but please consider paying for the full amount and committing to come!  It will help us to keep these long sessions going, and even if you pay for the whole session and don't come to all of them (often happens), you're getting a pretty square deal.  If you would like to pay online please do so at


http://damonlehrer.com/damonlehrer.com/payment.html 

PLEASE TRY TO BE ON TIME-  folks who come later than 10:00 am will be admitted ONLY at the convenience of the host (who is busy painting). PLEASE NOTE THE PRICES BELOW- They are deliberately a bit higher than for drawing sessions as we keep the studio less crowded for painting, and it's more work to put together a four week pose.  

----- IF THE CAPACITY REACHES 12, whether or not that number shows up on the RSVP list, we may have to close the session to further drop-ins to preserve breathing space for those who reserved ahead. ------

 Please consider that for $75 or $90 (non-member) you can reserve ahead for the whole month, which helps us stay open for business.  If you want to drop in, you can RSVP and pay online- simply change the amount of the payment at the payment stage to reflect the drop-in rate above.

results.description: Join us for a winter hike/snowshoe at Harold Parker State Forest. The area we will explore is situated at the west edge of the park and includes the areas around Collins Pond, Brackett Pond, and Delano Pond. The trailhead parking is located on Harold Parker Road about 1/3 mile on the left off route 125. Please remember to bring appropriate clothing, base, insulation, and shell layers also appropriate footwear, waterproof hikers. Other items include small daypack/fanny pack, water, snacks, sunglasses, and trekking poles.
results.how_to_find_us: From I93 take exit 41 onto Route 125 toward Andover/N Andover turn right onto Gould Rd and continue straight onto Harold Parker Rd the Trailhead parking is approx 1/3 mile on the left
results.name: Hike or Snowshoe Harold Parker State Forest

results.description:
Every Sunday at 10:30 AM we gather in our Sunday Circle, a time for gratitude,  prayer, song, and reflection.  Anyone is welcome to simply come as you are to any of these gatherings.  Please join us if you are seeking a time of centering, transformation, and connection with other people on their spiritual journeys. 

In the Sunday Circles we embody a rootedness in a Christian faith that is open to all faiths.  Our minister, Rev. Dr. Ian Mevorach, often preaches a dialogue sermon that invites the insights and wisdom of all who are gathered.   Other ministers, members of the community, or special guests also take turns leading our circles. Themes of spirituality, social and environmental justice, openness and love are at the core. We often engage in interfaith dialogue. We discuss scriptures from the Bible and other sacred texts, as well as explore poetry, music, and other sources of inspiration.  Every first Sunday of the month we celebrate an inclusive communion that is open to all.

Ou Sunday Circles are a time and place where people come together in a sacred way and where various threads in our community are often woven together into a greater whole.
results.how_to_find_us: Our building is located on Common Street overlooking the town green in Natick Center.  Parking in side and back lots.
results.name: Join us for our Sunday Circle time of gratitude, reflection, song and prayer

group.name: Building Community @ Common Street Spiritual Center

results.description:
Hello Boston Professionals!

My name is Bill Wapenski from American Bocce. I contacted Erin about our bocce league, and he allowed me to post this message to the group. I'd like to take this opportunity to explain what will be happening, and what needs to happen, before April 24th in you would like to be involved in our Sunday Bocce Brunch at The Sinclair. I'm sure you probably don’t have any idea what I’m talking about, so I want to make sure you understand everything and act quickly to be a part of this fun social event.

Here's a quick video of a league in Chicago so you can see what our weekly events at the Sinclair will be like. This particular event was sponsored by Tiger Beer;

https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=gO_cParGkH8­

The league at the Sinclair will be 7 weeks. (6 regular season, and one playoff championship). It will start on April 24th, and end May 12th. (No games May 8th - Mother's Day bye week). Each team will play 2 games each week. The games will start around 11am depending on the amount of teams entered. Games should end around 1:30pm.

The 7th week will be a championship round where all the prizes will be awarded to the winning teams. Much of this is still TBD, but I can tell you The Sinclair has offered tickets to an upcoming show as part of the championship team's package. There will also be other prizes donated by our sponsors.

Teams will be comprised of 4 to 8 players. If you have a group of 4 people that will be there every week, then you may have enough players for a team. If you feel you won't be able to make it every week, then you should be on a team with more members so each week your team can have at least 4 players present.

The easiest and cheapest way to create a team is for a team captain to log onto the American Bocce Co website and pay a $260 team fee. They will also pick a cool team name & slogan too. Then after the captain creates the team on the website, the rest of the players on the team join, and pay the team captain their share. This works out to $65 each for a 4 player team, down to $32.50 each for an 8 player team. That's somewhere between $9 to $5 bucks a week. Quite a bargain for such a fun, professionally run social sports league! Couple this with the fact that The Sinclair will also be offering brunch specials from their kitchen for all bocce players, and you have one heck of a deal!

If a team pays in increments they will pay transaction fees which equate to about $4 for each player.

Note: No matter how a team pays, or how many players there are, every player needs to be registered on the American Bocce Co website. This can be done here for our league at the Sinclair;

https://americanbocceco.com/joinleague/29/

Weekly stats for each team and player will be kept, along with game schedules posted each week so you know exactly when your team will be playing. This is another example of the quality entertainment we're providing.

If anyone has any questions at all before signing up, or any problems during please feel free to reach out to me and I'll be glad to help you through the process any way I can. Even if we get on a call and I walk you through it. We want as many people there as possible so again, don't hesitate to reach out to me. Here's my Meet Up group & email;

http://www.meetup.com/Cambridge-Bocce-Meetup-Sunday-Bocce-Brunch-At-The-Sinclair/events/230015939/

[masked]

Well that's it for now. I just wanted to reach you all, and I hope to see you all at The Sinclair on April 24th!

Cheers-

Bill
results.name: Sunday Bocce Brunch At The Sinclair April 24th!
