results.description:
Hi Soccer Comrades!  

Why not come and kick the ball around for an hour or so beginning at 11:00 AM Sunday?  We will do this at the BASEBALL field of Belmont High School, as we did last week.  (We ended up on the baseball field because lacrosse teams kicked us off of the soccer field and the turf field. The baseball field is located to the right of the turf field (when viewed from the street).

Here are a few things to remember:

·  This is the small-sided, "kinder and gentler" friendly, coed, game for people of all ages and nobody should get too serious: we want to avoid any injuries.  That said, we highly encourage all players to wear shin guards to protect against accidental knobbling.

·  Each player should bring a WHITE shirt and a BLACK or DARK BLUE shirt, so as to make team formation easy. 

·  Everybody should bring some water or something to drink, even in this cold weather

·  Somebody should bring a ball and some cones to mark the field.  (I always do, but I hate everybody to rely on me).

You can find the location at Google Maps with the link: https://www.google.com/maps/@42.39523,-71.1674112,466m/data=!3m1!1e3

The BASEBALL field is located just to the right the turf field (which is itself next to the Viglirolo Skating Rink (when seen from the Concord Ave).
results.how_to_find_us: https://www.google.com/maps/@42.3951655,-71.1690104,466m/data=!3m1!1e3
results.name: Play "kinder and gentler" coed small-sided pickup soccer

results.description:
***If you would like to attend as a GROUP---meet at 1pm. At the Entrance of  Charles Street @ Beacon Street. I will have a Meetup Sign with me. Thanks, Kim***

This is just an information post!
Our group is not affiliated with the festival, but feel free to RSVP and discuss your plans to attend!

Description from the Japan Boston Festival website:

"Dedicated to preserving the Japanese cultural tradition of “festivals” and “fairs”, the Japan Festival Boston has grown since its humble beginnings in 2012. It is now the largest festival promoting Japanese culture in all of New England, with more than 30,000 visitors attending last year’s festival. With the goal of a creating a Japanese cultural festival that will thrive for the next 100 years, the Japanese and Japanese-American community in Boston has come together to create an event that introduces many forms of Japan, including its traditional and pop culture, business and industry, and much more.

Compared to last year, the festival will be even bigger. We hope to welcome over 40,000 visitors to this event which can be enjoyed by friends and families alike. Please join us at this year’s festival!

日本古来の独自文化である『祭り』や『縁日』を中心とした日本文化の祭典として2012 年に初開催したボストン日本祭りは、今年は来場者数が30,000人に達し、ニューイングランド地方最大の日本祭りとなりました。今後100年続く日本祭りを目指し、ボストンの日系コミュニティが一丸となって、日本ならではの「おもてなし」の心で、日本の伝統文化やポップカルチャーなど、さまざまな日本の姿を紹介していきます。

第5回となる来年のボストン日本祭りの開催日が、2016年4月24日に決定しました。昨年同様にBoston Commonにて、開催スペースを拡大し、40,000人以上の来場者を見込んでいます。家族や友人をお誘いの上、是非ご来場ください。"

For more information, check out the Japan Boston Festival website:
http://www.japanfestivalboston.org/ (English)
http://www.japanfestivalboston.org/ja/ (日本語)


You can also find the community page on Facebook:
https://www.facebook.com/JapanFestivalBoston/
results.how_to_find_us: At 1pm I will gather members as a GROUP. I have will a Meetup Sign with me at the entrance of  Beacon Street  @ Charles Street.
results.name: 5th Annual Japan Festival Boston (For Information Only)

results.description:
Dedicated to preserving the Japanese cultural tradition of “festivals” and “fairs”, the Japan Festival Boston has grown since its humble beginnings in 2012. It is now the largest festival promoting Japanese culture in all of New England, with more than 30,000 visitors attending last year’s festival. With the goal of a creating a Japanese cultural festival that will thrive for the next 100 years, the Japanese and Japanese-American community in Boston has come together to create an event that introduces many forms of Japan, including its traditional and pop culture, business and industry, and much more.

Exhibits will include food booths (approx. 30) and non-food booths (approx. 100) introducing Japanese culture, activities of the local Japanese community, and other Japan related information and events. Stage performances will showcase many aspects of Japan, including Japanese culture workshops, cosplay, and musical performances. There will also be a raffle and prize giveaway.

http://www.bostoncentral.com/events/fair/p46117.php

results.description:
April marks the two-year anniversary of the group! Many thanks to all those who have supported the meetup through it's muddy parks, snow storms, and everything else that has stood in our way. From our humble beginnings, your passion for all things corgi has increased the group to 650 members and climbing!

Please join us this month at Cold Spring as the parking is ample and the space is ample.

As always, please be mindful of the weather to make for safe travels. If the weather turns for the worst, there will be no rain date and we'll just reschedule the following month.

All are welcome, corgi or no-corgi. If you have any specific questions, please don't hesitate to post to the group. We're a friendly bunch.

Park Reminder: There is ample parking available. To get to the dog park, there is a 5-10 minute walk through a wooded path to get to the dog clearing.

Corgi Reminder: Don't forget to bring water for your pup and a towel for your car.

Have a park suggestion? Pass along any dog park suggestions for future consideration. Amenities that most owners appreciate are parking, fully-fenced, large grass field (since our group has gotten so big, we want to be respectful of the local dogs), no specific tags needed, and access to water.
results.name: April Corgi Meetup - A Tradition Unlike Any Other

results.description:
CLICK HERE TO PURCHASE A SPOT TO THIS DATE, MORE INFO, ETC.


Introducing Scenergy Blind Dates – an alternative to your dating life. Instead of spending hours responding back to online dating and app messages, you can simply reserve your spot to share a table with someone similar in age and aspirations. Some of the Scenergy Blind Dates will include various interests, body types, ethnic, religious, and educational preferences - our intent is not to offend. Our goal is to offer a diverse mix of Blind Dates you can choose from, if one is not your type you may find another that is.

“Words are the Best Foreplay”


* Both parties are encouraged to bring a book to discuss as an icebreaker/topic of conversation.The area is perfect for coffee or lunch after meeting at the bookstore, all meeting details are sent privately to those that purchase this date.

Male:

Ages – 25-36

Body Type: average, athletic, and/or muscular

Interests: reading, research, coffee, audio books, etc. Female:

Ages – 25-36

Body Type: average, petite, and/or curvy (not overweight)

Interests: reading, research, coffee, audio books, etc.


Guidelines:

1.  This is a date and not an event, there will only be one ticket reserved for a male and one for female.
Both parties will receive the address of the establishment once both tickets have been sold.


2.  Since these are private dates that do not require any Scenergy staff to be present, there are currently no refunds once both tickets have been bought. If the date is not set (both a male and female purchase tickets) by the day of the date, a refund will be processed for the one person that purchased a ticket.


3.  Those that are at least 20 minutes to a date or do not arrive can be subject to being banned from future Scenergy Blind Dates.


4.  Any emergencies that resulted in not being able to attend a Scenergy Blind Date must be verified and validated by Scenergy Dating staff via contacting us at [masked].


5.  The subjectivity of a date cannot be predicted and is dependent on the attraction and connection of both parties. Scenergy Dating LLC serves as a connector and is not responsible for the safety and actions of both parties after meeting in a public location. It is highly recommended that the Scenergy Blind Date remain public in nature through its duration until further trust, communication, and rapport has been established.


6.  We encourage attendees to not publicly announce they will be coming to this event. This is done to protect privacy and build anticipation, failure to do so may result in removal from meetup groups, newsletters, etc.
results.name: Scenergy Book Store Blind Date - (Age 25-36)

results.description:
Hello Members of The Boston Japanese Anime & Films Social Group! 

Let's meetup at 11:00AM outside of PARK STREET STATION above ground on Sunday, April 24th for the 5th annual Japan Festival Boston. The festival will take place at the Boston Common at the corner by Beacon Street and Charles Street from 11am-6pm. You can reach me via text at[masked] if you can't find us!

FOR MORE INFO ON THE JAPAN FESTIVAL PLEASE VISIT:  
japanfestivalboston.org

http://www.japanfestivalboston.org/

Come join us on Sunday, April 24th for the 5th annual Japan Festival Boston. The festival will take place at the Boston Common at the corner by Beacon Street and Charles Street from 11am-6pm. We are confident that this year the festival will be bigger and better than ever, with more Food, more booths, more performances and more cosplay! There will be plenty of new experiences and activities for the whole family. We hope to see you there! Dedicated to preserving the Japanese cultural tradition of “festivals” and “fairs”, the Japan Festival Boston has grown since its humble beginnings in 2012. It is now the largest festival promoting Japanese culture in all of New England, with more than 30,000 visitors attending last year’s festival. With the goal of a creating a Japanese cultural festival that will thrive for the next 100 years, the Japanese and Japanese-American community in Boston has come together to create an event that introduces many forms of Japan, including its traditional and pop culture, business and industry, and much more.

results.description:
Think of this as a creative mini-retreat. It's designed primarily for writers—of all experience levels, working in any genre. Although we've booked the space for 6 hours, you're welcome to arrive and leave whenever you like. 

WHAT WE'LL DO: 

• Noon: Doors open.

• 12:30 p.m.: Write to easy creative prompts (if there's interest). 

• 1 p.m. sharp: Begin writing.

Although we'll be in the same large room, we'll be writing in companionable silence, talking only during breaks. If you'd like to have a conversation with someone, you're welcome to step into another room upstairs or head to a nearby coffee shop.


• About 4:30 p.m.: People will be invited to briefly share from their work, if they wish. (Sharing is optional and time will be limited.) No one will critique anyone's work unless the writer requests feedback. 

• 5:30-6 p.m.: Clean up and depart. 

AMENITIES: The Braintree Community Arts Center is a newly converted two-story house about 3.5 miles south of South Shore Plaza on the road (Route 37). We'll have the house all to ourselves for the day. It's bright, pleasant, and equipped with tables, chairs, restrooms, a coffeemaker, a fridge, a countertop range, free parking, and Wi-Fi. I will provide a few books for inspiration, and an extension cord and power strip for power.

WHAT TO BRING: Yourself, your writing projects and writing implements (computer or  writing notebook and pen, or journal). Bring your own beverage. Feel free to bring a snack to share—but that’s entirely optional.

COST: $15 (cash or check), regardless of how long you stay. This goes toward space-use costs and our Meetup fee.  

HOW TO RESERVE A SPOT: RSVP "yes" using Meetup's RSVP function. The RSVP list is our official headcount for the day, so it's the only way to sign up—emailing the organizer or posting messages on the site won't hold a spot.

CANCELLATIONS: If we need to cancel due to weather or any other reason, we'll post a message on the Web site and e-mail all "yes" RSVPs as far in advance as possible. 

REMINDER ABOUT ABOUT RSVPs: Your RSVP is a reservation, and we're trusting that you'll honor it. If you can't make it, please change your RSVP from "yes" to "no" at least 24 hours in advance. If you cancel with less than 24 hours notice, or if you RSVP "yes" and then don't show up, you'll be asked to pay the fee anyway to help cover our costs for the day. 

Looking forward to seeing you!
results.name: Meet to write in companionable silence

Join more than 1,500 racers and spectators who take part in North America's largest canoe and kayak race! Volunteers will be helping as timers for the event and helping sell T shirts. Proceeds of this race go to support The Charles River Watershed Association. Volunteers will be helping at Finish Line Festival, DCR’s Aretsani Park, Allston. Volunteers will receive an event T shirt. Please let us know your T shirt size when signing up.

The Charles River Watershed Association is one of the country's oldest watershed organizations, Charles River Watershed Association (CRWA) was formed in 1965 in response to public concern about the declining condition of the Charles. Since its earliest days of advocacy, CRWA has figured prominently in major clean-up and watershed protection efforts, working with government officials and citizen groups from 35 Massachusetts watershed towns.

results.description:
You know what you want, you know your capability. You even know how to get it. And yet, something is blocking you. You are being held back by all of the "what if's" that come with fear of the unknown. 

Fear Inventory is a writing meditation designed to explore this territory, understand what's going on beneath the surface, and convert it into fuel. 

Adapted from other techniques, OneTaste Fear Inventory is specifically intended to name the fear, get it out, and unblock the potential and desire that lie below.

In the Fear Inventory class, you will be given the tools to begin this practice skillfully. You will also have an opportunity to do the practice in class & receive adjustments to take you deeper from teachers who have been writing inventory for years. 

Special guest, Kati Brennan, will be in town from OneTaste Philadelphia to lead the session.

Register right here, $35  http://tinyurl.com/KatiBClass

We will begin promptly at 12:00 noon so please arrive by 11:45. No one will be admitted after 12:10 pm.


Free parking on Sundays in any resident permit spaces, or meters on Mass. Ave.

Any questions, contact us at [masked]

TurnON Boston is a lifestyle/wellness company that teaches a consciousness practice called Orgasmic Meditation (or OM for short). All of our events are designed for people to experience connection, meet like-minded people, and learn more about the practice. We welcome singles and couples, adults of all ages, genders, and orientations!
results.name: Unblock Potential & Passion: An Introduction to Fear Inventory with Kati B

Join Greenbelt's Director of Land Stewardship and Osprey expert Dave Rimmer to learn more about this extraordinary bird of prey and its successful return to the waterways and shorelines of Essex County.

Dave will provide a slide presentation about Osprey, their characteristics and habitat. Dave will then lead a walk to the Cox Reservation osprey platform, and discuss the highly successful osprey program which includes platform building and management, observation and monitoring, and public education and outreach. We expect our Cox nest will be occupied by a nesting pair at this time.

results.description:
Hello fellow Scoots! It seems Spring may arrive early this year, and therefore I thought it would be a good idea to schedule a meetup in early April to get together and organize a few rides for the upcoming season.
At this meetup, we will discuss possible new logo designs for our group that can help us attract a wider range of riders in the South Shore area. We'll also discuss any necessary changes to the dues policy and group riding etiquette while on rides, among several other topics. Please consider joining us for this all-important organizational meeting for the continued success of our group. I am told that some members have had problems paying their annual dues, please bring your dues with you to the meeting, and I'll see to it that your membership is renewed.
Weather permitting, we'll take a leisurely ride together immediately following the meeting. There are several beautiful coastal towns near our meeting point in Hanover. To name a few: Scituate Lighthouse, Cohasset Harbor, Brant Rock, etc. Ride suggestions are encouraged!
results.name: 2016 Season Opener: Meeting and First Ride!

results.description:
In this FREE mini-workshop, you'll learn specific tools that you can use right away to master intimate connections that are meaningful and loving.  

Spend your Sunday Creating More Love In Your Life with a group of like-minded friends (old and new!)


If this feels scary to you and you've been holding yourself back, this workshop is for you! 

Discover what's in your way of having the most satisfying  relationships including effective communication, and great sex. 

This workshop will focus on our innate ability to open to a greater love inside ourselves - that can be shared with others: a skill that when learned and practiced, enhances all of our relationships.  Feeling deeply connected to yourself and your heart provides a deep sense of peace. 

You’ll learn specific tools that will:

• Enhance your ability to identify core wants, needs and desires 

• Cultivate communication for healthy relating

• Become more intimate with yourself and others - with ease! 

• Stay in a place of love when it’s most difficult

In this free mini-workshop, you’ll have the opportunity to connect with others through a variety of exercises designed to open your heart and support you in sharing authentically with one another.

Come and get a taste of what you’ve been craving in a totally safe, warm, loving and non-sexual environment.  Learn more about what the Human Awareness Institute has to offer.

Finding love and being in love every day is something I personally never dreamed was possible (only for 'others' and not for me!)  Well, I'm happy to say I was wrong and am really excited to share what I've learned with you.

Each event begins promptly at the scheduled time. Please arrive at 12:30-12:45 pm so you can settle in, register and meet a few folks before we begin promptly.   

There will be no admittance after the scheduled start time so as not to break the continuity of the workshop.  



We look forward to seeing you there!  Even if you've been to a mini-workshop before, please join us again!  There's no limit to how many you can attend!  

** Please note there are cats in the farmhouse **

Rayellen:[masked] (phone/text), [masked]. Directions: tinyurl.com/Rayellen-Daron (or Use Google GPS for correct directions)
results.name: Communicating and Connecting for Intimacy

Enjoy the 5th annual "Japan Festival" in Boston!

The location is the Boston Common at Beacon Street & Charles Street from 11am--6pm.

results.description:
Host: Claire P. cell @[masked]
RAIN CANCELS THIS EVENT!

This will be my first time there, so anyone who is okay with exploring with me, then please sign up!  I am told this is a scenic area and is a fairly flat surface. So this would be an easy hike.

Weather permitting, I think it would be fun to go hiking on the trails at The Tom Paul Trail in Westford MA.  Please know that my intent is to enjoy the view of the area, and to chat along the way.  This event is meant more to have fun than to get a workout.  I thought that we would enjoy nature for about two or three hours, with a few breaks/stops along the trail.  This park is just full of beautiful views, so come and enjoy some fresh air, beautiful views, and all this while in good company of friends

We will meet at 1:00 pm at the Westford Town Hall 55 Main Street, Westford MA.

Below is the link with more information.

http://westfordconservationtrust.org/tws_holding/tom-paul-trail/

DIRECTIONS: From Route 3 South, take Exit 34 (Westford Rd,Tyngsboro) got to Tyngsboro Rd, then Depot St onto Main St.

From I495 South, take Exit 32 (Boston Rd, Westford), continue on to Main Street,

 Look for the meetup sign or my white Toyota Corolla.

Please remember to bring plenty of fluids and to dress in layers so that you will be comfortable the whole time we are out on the trails. 

If anyone cares to, we can then go grab a bite to eat or enjoy a hot chocolate, at a restaurant nearby.

This event is at no cost.  I hope to see you there.

Please RSVP or call my cell @[masked]-0897.  If you do not plan on coming, do not RSVP no.

What comes next in the sequence? (HINT: The name is a hint!)

The look-and-say sequence has many names - audioactive decay, Gleichniszahlenreihe, among others. John Conway studied it intensely in the 1980s, leading to the naming of Conway's constant. We'll explore the many unexpected properties of this sequence, play around with its variations, and investigate Conway's and others' discoveries.

results.description:
In the recent book Geography of Genius it is argued that the eruptions of genius that appear unexpectedly throughout human history arise most of all from place. Salem in the 19th century was The Place, experiencing a true eruption of genius. This walk will visit and view sites associated with three 19th century Salem geniuses – Nathaniel Hawthorne [masked]), Nathaniel Bowditch [masked]), and Alexander Graham Bell [masked]).

Hawthorne, born and raised in Salem, was a direct descendent of the Salem Witch Trials judge John Hathorne, and Nathaniel  could not escape the legacy of the witch trial era. His renowned books (The Scarlett Letter, The House of the Seven Gables) often featured moral conflicts arising from Puritan doctrines. We will pass and view many sites associated with Hawthorne – the House of the Seven Gables, the Custom House, his birthplace house, his childhood home, and more.

Bowditch, also born and raised in Salem, was the premier mathematician of his time, and is considered the founder of modern maritime navigation. His most famous work, The New American Practical Navigator, first published in 1802, is still in print and is carried on board every commissioned U.S. Naval vessel. We will pass and view sites associated with the life of Bowditch – the Bowditch House where he lived most of his adult life, his birthplace home, the Maritime Historic site from where Bowditch made his many sea voyages.

Although Bell spent most of his life outside Salem, he spent the critical years when the telephone was first conceived and created living in Salem. There he tutored deaf students during the day, one of whom was to later become his wife, and tinkered at night in a small lab next to his Salem home, commuting between there and a larger laboratory in Boston. The first ever ‘long-distance’ phone call, between Salem and Boston, was made Feb[masked] from the Salem Lyceum, which still stands. That call convinced attending investors that Bell was onto something, and so Salem can be considered the birthplace of Ma Bell.

This walk will be shorter than the previous walk, staying in downtown Salem. Parking is available nearby at Ferry Wharf, home of the Sculpture Garden (another Salem genius?) visited on the previous walk.
results.name: Geniuses of Salem Walking Tour

results.description:
PLEASE NOTE: As of 04/03/2016, our weekend MJ sessions have moved to Danvers -- we are no longer meeting in Saugus. The Danvers location is only about 7 minutes from Saugus and right off Rt 128 so hopefully Sunday attendees can still make it.


Please RSVP for this event so we can be sure to grab enough tables and bring enough Mah Jongg sets! 


Newcomers to American style Mah Jongg are welcome, provided that you have already learned the basics, as described on our About page! Thanks!


Note that MJ is usually played with 4 people, although it can be played with 2 or 3 as well, with some adjustment to the rules. If the number of RSVPs is not a multiple of 4, then we can decide whether to have multiple tables or have some sit out of some games and observe OR play a rack with another person. (This is a great way to learn!)
results.name: Sunday afternoon, in Danvers

results.description:
Here's the game plan:

1:00 - Toss the disc around, meet folks, be merry

1:10 - Overview of the rules, safety, etc - then divide into teams

1:20 - Play!!!!!!

3:00 - Conclude the meetup with snacks and socializing


Here's what we humbly ask of you (works great as a checklist):

Dress for the weather

Bring a white t-shirt and a colored t-shirt. Grey is evil. If you wear grey you may be asked to wear a dark or white "pinnie of shame."

Arrive on time to be guaranteed a spot in a game

RSVP is recommended so you can be notified if the game is canceled

Bring WATER!

This meeting on 4/24  is the first event of this group.  This will be an intro session and we'll discuss some theory, and then get right into movement drills. We will be covering material from a Z-Health movement template call "R-Phase". The goals are restoring end ranges of motion in all joints, rehabilitating any stiffness/pain/movement compensations, and training the brain/nervous system to be smarter about movement - increase coordination, contractile capacities of muscles, etc. 


Come experience how this can help you move better and increase your athletic performance.  This system is designed to work for people across a broad spectrum, from sedentary folks to elite level athletes.  All skill levels are welcome.

results.description:
In honor of Earth Day, the Hub is excited to hold two events: 

During our normal Sunday program, MIT's Professor Larry Susskind will discuss with participants the climate change impacts the City of Cambridge and Cambridge residents are likely to face in the coming years, focusing specifically on implications for public health. He will also present on the ongoing work of the MIT Science Impact Collaborative to engage Cambridge residents in the climate planning process and to present their input to the City through the use of scenario-based role play games.

On Thurday, April 28, the Hub will host the MIT Science Impact Collaborative for an evening event (more info coming -- pre-registration required).

Lawrence Susskind is Ford Professor of Urban and Environmental Planning at the Massachusetts Institute of Technology, and the Founder and Chief Knowledge Officer of the Consensus Building Institute. He has served on the faculty of MIT for over 35 years and currently directs the Graduate Program in Environmental Policy and Planning. He is also Vice-Chair for Instruction at the Program on Negotiation at Harvard Law School, which he helped found in 1982, where he heads the MIT-Harvard Public Disputes Program and teaches advanced negotiation courses.
results.name: Earth Day: Lawrence Susskind: Climate Change & the City of Cambridge

Acting Games (10 mins)

Get comfortable, warm up and focus

Bring the script you love, act with a partner you choose, and get feedback from the audience

play this dialog with your imagination of who, when, where, how, why; bring your inner dialog in acting

results.description:
Lets sketch the public gardens!


I know i'm probably getting a little over-excited for Spring to arrive, but I propose outdoor sketching in the garden. We will most certainly have a repeat of this meetup when the foliage comes back full force, but this will present it's own challenges of transparency and barren trees. We will meet at 2pm by the George Washington statue, disperse to sketch, then reconvene at the statue at 4pm to share our work and chat. 

WARNING: it will probably not be warm, but it will hopefully be sunny! Pack accordingly. I'll keep an eye on the weather to decide if we need to move indoors prior to the date.

BONUS SKETCH CHALLENGE:

Join me in attempting to create 10 drawings in this two hour period. The idea here will be to draw quick and gesturally. That comes down to approximately 10 minutes per sketch with 2 minutes per sketch to walk and select new material. This, of course, is not mandatory, but it will be an interesting exercise.

To plan for this, have 10 sheets of paper ready to go, and drawing/painting implements that are easy to move, unless you decide to draw the same thing 10 times! 

I hope to see you there.

Sunday, APRIL 24 at 2:00pm at Kingston Gallery for an inclusive discussion about painting as an idea, and paint as a tool, medium, action.

We get the conversation started with
Luanne E Witkowski, whose solo exhibition "New Observations," is on display in the main gallery, Julie S. Graham, whose students at the School of the Museum of Fine Arts are a group exhibition, "Twenty by Ten," in our center gallery, and gallery director Shana Dumont Garr.

Look here for more info and details: http://bit.ly/1Sk8IHd
and here: http://bit.ly/1SHgt4b
http://www.kingstongallery.com/ 


ARTIST BIOGRAPHY

Luanne E Witkowski is an American artist working in a wide range of media and reflective and social practice, with works in collections throughout the United States and abroad. She is a member of the Kingston Gallery, Boston, MA; represented by Hutson Gallery and AMP Gallery both in Provincetown, MA.  She exhibits regularly and produces environmental and site-specific installations.  Luanne is a member of several artist organizations including the United South End Artists, Mission Hill Artist Collective, and the Provincetown Art Association and Museum.  More examples of her work can be seen in Contemporary Cape Cod Artists on Abstraction, (D.Forman, 2015, Schiffer Publishers)

In addition to her studio practice, Witkowski is the Communication Design Studio manager, adjunct faculty, and LR-MFA Mentor at Massachusetts College of Art and Design; she teaches Creative Thinking in the Critical & Creative Thinking (CCT) graduate program at the University of Massachusetts, Boston, and is an internet entrepreneur and business owner.

Honors include: Commonwealth of Massachusetts Lifetime Achievement in Art & Commerce Commendation.

Also at Kingston Gallery in April: 
Twenty by Ten by SMFA Students in the Center Gallery and Kathleen Gerdon Archer's Self Portrait: Carboniferous Period in the Members' Gallery. First Friday Opening Reception: April 1, 5:30-8:00 pm.

Kingston Gallery is an artist-run alternative space founded in 1982.
The gallery is committed to exhibiting the work of established and emerging artists. It hosts one-person and group exhibitions by gallery members and provides exhibition opportunities for guest artists in its Center Gallery.
The gallery is located in Boston's historic South End between Harrison Avenue and Albany Street in the vibrant SoWA gallery district.

Kingston Gallery, 450 Harrison Avenue, No. 43, Boston, MA 02118

results.description:
18xx games are about railroads: building track and running trains for profit. 18xx games are also about a stock market, and the skullduggery between various robber barons as they try to build, thwart, take over, or bankrupt companies. But, they can take quite a while to play. We play with poker chips and emphasize a "ready to play" culture (meaning you're ready to act when your company is up). Games have generally taken from 2 hours (via bankruptcy) to 6 hours (to the end) with the average around 5 hours, even with new players. The more you plan in advance, the faster the game (of course, many times the other robber barons thwart your plans!)

You will need to be ready to start right at the starting time, or very close to it, because the game is so long. We also are splitting into two games quite frequently now so being early is better so we can decide which 18xx games to play and then have to set them up, unless we ALL can come to a pre-arrangement in the comments.

New players are welcome although we strongly suggest familiarizing yourself with the basic rules and concepts first. A brand new player will need 20 to 40 minutes of rules explanation before they play. The game really isn't overly complex, rules-wise, it's just long with lots of decisions. It is a little fiddly sometimes, though.

Due to some late arrivals in prior months, we will emphasize: If you're over 15 minutes late and have not made arrangements with one of the tables, you are probably only going to be a mere spectator, unless there is a game doing a rules explanation, you know that 18xx variant well, and can make it before it starts. If you're much later you probably won't be able to join a game at all. It usually takes us all afternoon and well into the evening to play one game of 18xx. Even our more "experienced" tables usually drop four or five hours into a single game (or more; last month we didn't finish either 1835 or 1830 until 9:30 PM or later). It is rare that there is a second game.

Also since we usually know the people in the week or so prior it will be good at that point if we can sort out what games we want to play in advance. While it's no guarantee we can break down that way, knowing to set up something in advance is SUPER helpful and time saving. Setting up and teaching a new 18xx variant can take an hour or more and the games are quite long as it is, so every little bit helps. What you need to know about 334 Mass Ave:

-Press 999 on the intercom and security will let you into the building
-You must sign in at the security desk with a picture ID
-Take the elevator down to level "A." Exit the elevator to your left and the community room will be ahead on your right, next to the laundry room.

Session would start at 2 PM. Please note your availability in the comments.
results.name: Train Hard: With a Vengeance (April 18xx Meetup)

results.description:
These are some of the discussion points planned for this April meeting:

·  Black Lives Matter vs. All Lives Matter

·  What do we personally know about the Black Lives Matter movement? 

·  What is the difference when engaging with different races about BLM (and anti-racism in general)?

·  What do you think is the impact of talking to a black person about BLM? ·  What could we do instead of talk about our support?

“The essence of American racism is disrespect.” 

― Ta-Nehisi Coates, The Case for Reparations, www.theatlantic.com

Note: Each monthly meeting is a "stand alone" meeting. No previous, or future, meeting attendance is required. We are happy to have your participation at any meeting.


---------------
Below is the general information about this discussion series, posted every month. The post above this is information unique to this month's meeting:

The mission of this monthly group discussion series is to promote awareness of inequality, to build community, and to develop skills that address dismantling racism and oppression within a diverse, compassionate, and culturally sensitive environment.


"A window of opportunity won't open itself." - Dave Weinbaum


Even those of us living in the suburbs care about, and have a role to play in, the anti-racism movement. From frustration, fear, and anger to empathy, passion, and solidarity, this work can bring up a lot for everyone. Our supportive group discussions can help us get some clarity, perspective, and encouragement through the process. We will focus on a different topic each meeting, sometimes including films and discussions about printed materials …encouraging member feedback to help guide future topics.

All are welcome: People of Color, white people…people new to this topic and those involved and active for many years. Come with questions and/or experience to share with others wanting to learn more.

Hosted by Deb and Carlin, members of Boston Knapsack Anti-Racism Group.

If interested, please join Knapsack and RSVP to this meeting date (with no further obligations). Please change your RSVP if your plans change and you can no longer come so we can plan accordingly.

Feel free to post questions here too. We look forward to hearing from you!

Parking is available on the street, and behind and beside the church. Come in the door at the parking lot side of the church, lower level.

Public transportation unfortunately does not go to Medfield.  But most likely someone going to the meeting would be available to give rides to/from the Framingham commuter train station, Riverside T station, or elsewhere. Leave a comment about your needs and we will try to get you to the meeting if you want to join us! Car-pooling rules!

Future 2016 dates: plan for 3rd Sunday of each month, same time. We will post here if that changes.
results.name: Anti-Racism in the ‘Burbs (Medfield, MA)

results.description:
Nobody sees a flower - really - it is so small it takes time - we haven't time - and to see takes time, like to have a friend takes time. Georgia O'Keeffe

Blossoms are among the most popular subjects for photographers. I imagine you have already taken hundreds of GOOD flower photos. We love their colors, shapes, textures and energy. This workshop will focus primarily on blossoms and buds since this is the weekend they are here and so soon they will be gone.

With a little more creativity, camera knowledge, and professional instruction, you can take GREAT photos of blossoms. What is the difference? When you show someone a good photo of a blossom they say, oh that's nice. When you show them a great photo, they are touched, moved and inspired by the beauty of the image you have created. In this class you will discover how to really see and capture beauty in bloom. 

Can you feel the quality of tenderness and quiet in the image above?  This is because of the composition and because I paid attention to the way the light was playing across the surface of the petals in that moment.  You have to really slow down to see the subtle beauty and that is what I help will do.


In this image I used a shallow depth of field to divide the visual space into a one third, two thirds composition. Again the blue space is key to giving the eye a space to rest and refresh.  And by luck I caught the honey bee.

Blossoms are a special subject for photography because they can tell a story, evoke an emotion and invite us to express our creativity. This macro shot captures the subtle shapes and color gradations of a single blossom.  It takes time to create an image like this but is well worth it. You don't have to be an artist to see like one. In this class I will reveal the simple but effective ways you can see more creatively and express your love of beauty through your photos. There will be three creative lesson assignments designed to build your skills and give you a few new tools to work with.  In the fun and informative class you will discover: How to capture the translucent, ephemeral quality of a blossom
How to compose the shot for the greatest impact and drama
How to use color, texture and shape to express the beauty of blossoms

More advanced students will also work with panning to blur the blossoms as a background, and boken as a method of creating dots of light in the background.

Panning to blur the blossoms as a background for action shots.

Creative technique of Boken creates interesting background dots of light. 

Monochromatic effect using the branches to create structure and form. The empty space in the bottom right corner is essential to the success of the image. The eye needs a space to rest. 

The class size will be small so you will also receive individual attention and critique so you can immediately improve the quality of your photos.   This is an intuitive approach to creative seeing, not a technical workshop. But, I can also help you move off the Auto setting on your camera and use aperture priority if you would like to experiment with shallow depth of field. I will guide you step by step through a simple process of seeing creatively that you can use from now on not only when you photography blossoms, but other subjects as well. In this image for example I included the silhouette of the bird and the dark branches to add dynamic contrast. 

Why not make this the Spring your photos go from good to GREAT! If this sounds exciting to you, please RSVP RIGHT NOW.  I offer a 100% learning guarantee. If you don't discover something inspiring and practical in this class, I will refund your tuition.

The best part is, you will be learning with other Budding Photographers who share your love of photography and flowers. We will be meeting at the Charles River where the light is beautiful and the trees are in bloom. Details  for exactly where will be provided once you RSVP. Come join us and take time to see a flower and  make a friend. RSVP now please so I can reserve your space in this special class. Tuition $45.00
See you on Sunday!  Suzanne Instructor Bio: Suzanne is a Master Level Photography Instructor with over 20 years of experience teaching photography, creativity, and aesthetics, in Asia, Europe, and the US. She is an award winning author, speaker, and photographer with a studio at the Boston Center for the Arts. She is a former Polaroid Corporation manager. Her photography can be seen at:  www.curioussoulphotos.com P.S. Plan to stay at the end of class for the social time when we take a look at photos you have taken and have "refreshments". The blossoms won't last for long so catch the beauty while you can.  Closest T stop Arlington on Green Line. Public parking available at the Boston Common Garage. Flow-tography Book available on iTunes.  http://itunes.apple.com/us/book/flow-tography-better-photos/id499049037?mt=11&uo=4

results.description:
This is an opportunity to discover an exercise system that is rapidly becoming popular with men and women around the world.  Lady Gaga, Carl Lewis, Shaquille O'Neal... they all do GYROTONIC® exercise and GYROKINESIS is the group format of that system, without equipment.  Using instead, a stool and a mat, Specialized Master Trainer, Martha Mason will guide everyone through gentle spinal motions (to be done every day!) to make your spine feel looser and younger.  Big arm movements develop shoulder strength and mobility, while having an effect on the psyche as well.  On the mat, we will do flowing movement, opening hips, strengthening abdominals and back muscles, all with the sensation of yawning the body open, rather than gripping. 

Gyrokinesis movement is gentle but is a surprisingly good workout.  Imagine combining Swimming movements with Tai Chi, Yoga and Dance.  There will be no music, but instead, the rhythm created by your breath.  Weights can be used for the arm movements for those who want a stronger workout.

After class, all those who would like can walk around the corner to get a juice at Life Alive to continue getting to know one another.  It's a great pairing!
results.name: GYROKINESIS® and JUICE

results.description:
We're excited to read "My Life on the Road" by Gloria Steinem for our next book club book! We'll be meeting in mid-late April to discuss! 

Here’s Amazon's description of the book:

Gloria Steinem—writer, activist, organizer, and inspiring leader—now tells a story she has never told before, a candid account of her life as a traveler, a listener, and a catalyst for 

When people ask me why I still have hope and energy after all these years, I always say: Because I travel. Taking to the road—by which I mean letting the road take you—changed who I thought I was. The road is messy in the way that real life is messy. It leads us out of denial and into reality, out of theory and into practice, out of caution and into action, out of statistics and into stories—in short, out of our heads and into our hearts. 

Gloria Steinem had an itinerant childhood. When she was a young girl, her father would pack the family in the car every fall and drive across country searching for adventure and trying to make a living. The seeds were planted: Gloria realized that growing up didn’t have to mean settling down. And so began a lifetime of travel, of activism and leadership, of listening to people whose voices and ideas would inspire change and revolution. 

My Life on the Road is the moving, funny, and profound story of Gloria’s growth and also the growth of a revolutionary movement for equality—and the story of how surprising encounters on the road shaped both. From her first experience of social activism among women in India to her work as a journalist in the 1960s; from the whirlwind of political campaigns to the founding of Ms. magazine; from the historic 1977 National Women’s Conference to her travels through Indian Country—a lifetime spent on the road allowed Gloria to listen and connect deeply with people, to understand that context is everything, and to become part of a movement that would change the world.
results.name: Wanderful Reads: My Life on the Road by Gloria Steinem

group.name: Wanderful Women Who Travel: Boston Chapter

results.description:
Spring Kick-Off Day 2016 - April 24th

It's time for our 1st annual meet and greet at Danehy Park in Cambridge. Every year we set aside a day for players and friends to come down to the field and shake off the rust. Get out on the grass, kick the ball around and maybe play a friendly. The HUB Spring Kick Off is your first opportunity to meet the HUB team and see what the league is all about. You can also use it as an opportunity to pick up a player or two for the upcoming season. Independent teams can also meet for the first time and start laying out their strategy for bringing home a Championship.

Coffee and donuts will be served and the first 50 arrivals will bring home a HUB Sport Bottle.

Where - Danehy Park Cambridge [click here]

When - Sunday April 24th. 4pm to 6pm

Why - Shake off the rust and play some ball

results.description:
This movie is in the Coolidge Corner Screening Room, which seats 45 people.  It might be prudent to buy your ticket ahead of time and to get there a bit early for a good seat.

After, we'll go to Pho Lemongrass.  If you change your mind about joining us, please change your response.  I want to give the restaurant an accurate count.

Here's the rest of the invite...


Don't know about you, but I would watch Don Cheadle read the phone book.  So watching him inhabit Miles Davis should be an extra treat. I'm posting the blurb from the Coolidge below so that you can read about.

I'll be waiting outside the theater in the alley afterwards and we'll head on over to Pho Lemongrass to talk.

I've been looking forward to this movie for months...


Inspired by events in Miles Davis’s life, this is a wildly entertaining, impressionistic, no-holds-barred portrait of one of twentieth-century music’s creative geniuses.

Holed up in his Manhattan apartment, wracked with pain from a variety of ailments, sweating for the next check from his record company, and dodging sycophants and industry executives, Davis is haunted by memories of old glories, humiliations, and of his years with Frances Taylor, his great love.

Academy Award–nominated actor Don Cheadle—co-writer, director, and lead actor—remarkably captures the musical legend on film through an impressively orchestrated use of images and sounds. Varying cinematic rhythms and beats are used to create a singular and intoxicating viewing experience as Cheadle displays a deep understanding of the man and his music.

- Synopsis from Sundance Film Festival 2016
results.how_to_find_us: I'll be outside in the alley after the movie then we'll walk to Pho Lemongrass
results.name: Miles Ahead

results.description:
Hello ASL Enthusiasts!

WHAT: ASL Weekly Social
WHEN: EVERY SUNDAY 
TIME: 4:00-6:00PM
WHO: ANYONE is welcome to come by and have a conversation in ASL
WHY: To socialize, have fun, and enjoy chatting in ASL
WHERE:  Potbelly Sandwich Shop behind CVS (on Somerville Ave) 

NOTE: Every once a while, the location may change. PLEASE look on the website each week for confirmation. THANKS!


To get to the Meetup, take the RED LINE stop OUTBOUND TO ALEWIFE, and stop at PORTER SQ. You can easily spot Potbelly Sandwich Shop on side entrance when you arrive at top of escalator at Porter Square Station. If you're driving, you can park on the street for free on Sundays!

Anyone who loves ASL is welcome to come and be part of the fun! We want to warmly extend an invitation to Deaf people or others fluent/skilled in the language (CODAs for example) to join our group.

This is an easy-going, casual, ASL get-together to meet people who enjoy American Sign Language, who want to brush up on their signing skills, and want to learn more ASL by using it as often as possible.

We strive to have a good time and communicate without using voices. If we need to, we draw or write what we don't know how to sign, and if lots of folks show up, we split up into small groups and mix and mingle, so we can actually see one another clearly, face-to-face and get a good conversation going.

Don't be afraid or shy if you're not "perfect" at ASL, because being "perfect" is not the point of this group. No one expects that everyone will be at the same level, and none of us mind slowing down or repeating what we have signed so that everyone understands.

We all laugh WITH one another as we fumble along, mess things up, and start over again. This isn't an ASL class, since none of us are certified ASL teachers, so there's really no pressure or expectation--other than that we all use ASL to communicate. We all learn from one another!

IF you've taken an ASL/Sign Language class before (or have had exposure to someone who uses the language) and know the basics (alphabet, numbers 1-20, and even a small vocabulary of signs ), then join us to get your fingers, hands, face and body moving, ASL-style!

IF you haven't taken an ASL class, or don't know the basics, don't be discouraged ... you can come along anyway and learn by watching, and gradually, participating. We have lots of resources that we can suggest for learning ASL from a qualified teacher or authentic source, such as books, online classes, and local classes at various locations near Boston.

If you can, "officially" RSVP, even if the RSVP is "No," so that we know who is definitely going to come.

It will be great to see folks!

Sean
results.how_to_find_us: We will be there signing our beautiful language to inspire all of you!
results.name: ASL WEEKLY SOCIAL

results.description:
Meet other members for a brief happy hour mingle.  An icebreaker will be provided to held facilitate mingling. Then you'll be seated for your series of four minute "mini-dates." On your dating card that you receive at check-in, you'll select who you wish to see again. You can choose Dating or Friendship as your preferred connection.

We will collect everyone's dating cards at the end of the event and email you your mutual matches within 48 hours.

While this event is geared towards helping people meet potential romantic matches, you can also mingle with all the guests and find new friends as well.

~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~

PAYMENT POLICY:
$24 (MUST register with code ATWYS- codes can not be applied after registration)

REGISTER AND PAY HERE: 

http://atwys2016bostonspeeddating.eventbrite.com

(SEE MORE FAQ's BELOW)

ABSOLUTELY NO REFUNDS FOR LAST MINUTE/DAY OF CANCELLATIONS. NO EXCEPTIONS.

~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~


FAST FACTS - PLEASE READ:

*We can not accept payment at the door for these events. All registrations must be done online via the Eventbrite link below before the event. No exceptions.

*RSVPing through meetup does not guarantee admission. You must pre-pay to secure your spot in the event.

*Business casual attire requested. No sneakers, t-shirts or active wear, no ripped jeans.

*We limit our events to 12 couples/24 people. (See reason below)

*You will have approximately 8-12 dates.*

*Matches are tabulated and emailed to attendees 48 hours after the event.

*Event lasts about 90 minutes give or take 10 minutes between check-in and all speeddating rounds. Speed rounds last 5 minutes each.

*You must register with a valid, correct email address.

*There are no refunds for cancellations, late arrivals or no-shows.

*You must arrive and check in within 20 minutes of the advertised start time.

OUR METHOD:

Online dating is great. But how many times have you chatted with someone just to have them fade or never make plans to meet? How many dates have you had that you thought went well and then ended up confused because you never heard from that person again?

The upside of online dating is that it provides us with so many options. The downside is that people start to believe that their options are endless, which leads them to move on quickly seeking that "perfect" match.

This is where speeddating comes in. To try and combat the "shopping cart" mentality of online dating, we limit the number of attendees to 10-12 per gender.  Fewer choices to distract us means that people are more likely to make a connection. Face to face conversations result in fewer flakes. That means fewer people get put on the back burner.


FAQ'S

The Organizer RSVPD with X amount of people. What does that mean?

That number represents the RSVPS (not registrations) that have come in through our other pages listed below. It is NOT the total number of people pre-paid. The typical number of people per event is 16-20.

What should I wear?

Business casual attire is perfect. No sneakers or athletic wear, please.

What if I want to give someone my contact info at the event?

Go for it! That's the whole point. Do whatever you are comfortable doing.

Can I see photos of other attendees?

Most people do not RSVP on meetup for privacy reasons. They only pre-pay and therefore do not share their photo.

Where are all the RSVPs?

About 50% of the registrations come through Eventbrite and our main events website. They are not Meetup members. Many people prefer not to post their Meetup profile or photo for privacy reasons. We often remove the event from the calendar once it has started so that people can't contact attendees without the attendee's expressed permission.

What's The Refund Policy?

Since we need to try and ensure a gender ratio as close to even as possible, our policy is that all registrations are final. We can not offer refunds or transfers to last minute cancellations. However, if you notify us at least 3 days in advance, we can give you a credit to another event.

Can I bring a friend for moral support?

You'd be surprised how many people arrive alone. We actually prefer that guests do not bring friends or "spectators." It makes the other attendees uncomfortable. Fun fact: The people who sign up and arrive alone tend to get more matches than those who attend with friends.

Will there be equal numbers of men or women?

That's the goal. We constantly monitor registrations and amp up promotion to try and ensure and equal gender ration. Sometimes there's 1 or 2 more men or women. Sometimes it's even numbers. This is heavily dependent on the age range and weather. We will NOT host an event if there isn't AT LEAST 7 of each gender registered, and we will NOT let there be an excessive (more than 3) amount of one gender versus the other.

PLEASE REMEMBER:
* We run 3-5 Meetup Groups, plus maintain our own outside Dating Advice & Events Website. We advertise on Facebook, Twitter, Blogs, etc. Most registrations come through our outside events website, not Meetup. Therefore the number of RSVPs reflected here are NOT the total number of men or women registered.

*This is not a guaranteed number of dates.

See other RSVPS posted on our other groups. Please note that many people opt NOT to RSVP through Meetup for privacy reasons.
results.name: SpeedMeeting - Singles Ages 44-57 -SOLD OUT FOR WOMEN

results.description:
I normally ask members to suggest a topic at the Meetup, but occasionally I pick a topic in advance. 

With yet another anniversary of the Columbine tragedy approaching, I would like to discuss Columbine and school shootings in general: Were the shooters "bad" at heart? What could have been done to prevent this massacre? What is to blame for this sort of thing?

A new book, A Mother's Reckoning, by Sue Klebold, the mother of Dylan Klebold, one of the Columbine shooters, tries to make sense of what drove her loving son to such madness on April 20, 1999. Another book, Columbine, by Dave Cullen, explores the events leading up to the massacre and debunks some of the myths (no, the shooters weren't outcasts who were out for revenge; no, specific students or types weren't targeted; no, the shooters weren't members of "The Trench Coat Mafia"; no, a student wasn't shot because of her belief in God; etc).  These books aren't "required", obviously, but might help when discussing the issue. You can get them at your library if you're interested, although A Mother's Reckoning has a long wait list. Another option is to get a free trial with audible and download the audiobook.
results.how_to_find_us: Look for the Meetup sign!
results.name: Let's discuss Columbine, 17 years later.

results.description:
This is an ongoing weekly (donation only) class for anyone, offering experiential practice in meditation, along with an opportunity to be among others interested in deepening spiritutual practices.  The class provides you with a felt sense of your own divinity; your Higher Self. The meditation, based on Kriya practices,  is partly guided, partly silent. In the guided part we open up to the flow of golden light and energy that is always pouring down to our body/mind/heart and being. Accessing that flow and inviting it to fill us brings a profound level of openness, while washing away limiting thoughts, feelings and beliefs. This higher vibration of unconditional love serves to open our consciousness to new levels of peace, joy and awakening. Bringing the flow of light into the body/mind/heart means we more consciously embody our Light Being, so we are more present, happy, forgiving, peaceful and joyful while in the world.
   After the guided portion we spend time in peaceful silence.  Whether you are an experienced meditator or a beginner, you will love the sweetness and powerful energies of this group. At the end of the class we make time for questions or sharing.  Group meditation is powerful, and it's refreshing to be among fellow travelers!
   Judy also teaches the Sound and Light meditation; a way for you to draw your senses inward to open your spiritual eye and to hear the sounds of your chakras. 
   This practice is non-denominational, appropriate for anyone. 
   Held in a lovely healing space, just walking in will bring you instant peace.  All are welcome.
    You may also want to check out my other Meetup, for a variety of spiritual programs:  http://www.meetup.com/Evolving-Beings/
results.how_to_find_us: Enter at The Hawthorne Building, the large glass doors to the left of H&R Block.
results.name: The Salem MA Weekly Meditation Group

results.description:
"Science By the Pint: Gravitational Waves Unplugged"
Guest scientist Scott Hughes

Meet us Sunday, April 24, 5:30pm – 7:30pm at Aeronaut Brewing Company!

You may have heard a little announcement in the science world this February about gravitational waves. We’ve asked back MIT Professor Scott Hughes and members of his group from the Kavli Institute for Astrophysics and Space Research and the MIT LIGO Laboratory to talk to us about the incredible discovery of gravitational waves and what that means for us and the future of physics. Come grab a seat, enjoy Aeronaut beer and great science festival company.

Science by the Pint is a monthly science cafe free and open to the public, run by the Harvard non-profit outreach group Science In The News (SITN). Read more here: http://sitnboston/science-by-the-pint/

Our monthly labyrinth walks at the Somerville Growing Center are beginning again! I offer an outdoor labyrinth walk gathering each month on the Sunday nearest the full moon - April through October.

This is an open and free event. Come join us.

We'll have a little introduction of walking for those new to labyrinths and some fun discussion about the moon's current astrology and energy we might tap into for reflection or inspiration.

After our contemplative walk, those who wish, may linger for more conversation, community and snacks !

results.description:
Join the oldest established permanent floating Community Walk in Cambridge and Environs.  Join the Community Walkers and walkers from five other meetup groups.   Let's join 20+ others from six other walking groups for:

Since May 2012, there has been a regular walk around Fresh Pond at about an hour before sunset. Frequently, 20-25 walkers turn out for this walk, and you can too. There are a whole bunch of regulars, along with some new people.

We'll go out to dinner at a local pub or chinese restaurant - you can get a decent dinner for under $10.

Frequently, if we eat too much food, we'll go for another walk.

Come see why this walk is so popular. It's at a great time, the people are friendly, the parking is free -- no permit parking in Cambridge on Sunday, so you can park on Huron or Aberdeen Ave.

You can get there by T easily from Harvard Square, take the 71 OR 73 bus to Aberdeen Ave, then walk to the other end of Aberdeen Ave, and you'll see us there. We'll be next to the bridge, on the pond side of Huron Ave,at the intersection of Aberdeen Ave.

If you're late, and we've already started, start walking counter-clockwise. We'll be walking clockwise, so we'll surely bump into each other. We're the large group of vigorously chatting walkers.

Hope to see you there.

Shangri La is located at 149 Belmont Street, Belmont - please let the host know if you're coming, so we can get the right sized table.
results.name: Weekly Multigroup Community Walk at Fresh Pond + dinner at Shangri La 4/24 6:30

results.description:
Join the Fresh Pond Walking Community for our regular Sunday walk around Fresh Pond.   

Let's join regular walkers from surrounding towns + members of five other walking groups and 20+ walkers for this walk.  Walk is on, Rain or Shine.

Few things are more enjoyable than a nice walk and a chat at the end of a busy weekend.

Since May 2012, we've met with a few other meetup groups Let's join for a stroll in a beautiful setting.

We walk clockwise, so if you get there late, just start walking counter-clockwise and you'll run into us.

Parking on Huron Avenue is easy, since the "Permit Parking" rules don't apply on Sunday - just park in any spot on Huron Ave, there will be plenty of them.

If you're coming by bus, take the 71 or 73 bus from Harvard Square and get off at Aberdeen Ave. Walk all the way up Aberdeen until you come to Huron Avenue, we'll be there.

Afterwards, we'll go out for dinner. We usually go for some unusual Chinese food, and the total cost is about $10 per person.

If you have trouble finding us, call me at[masked]

results.description:
There will be stimuli for each meeting to inspire the conversation. The stimuli can be anything, such as a picture, a short story, a breaking news, etc. Each meeting includes member and stimuli introduction, small team and whole group discussion. 

Every attendee is required to raise 1-3 questions inspired by the stimuli. We will discuss why these questions are important; how these questions relate to one's personal life experience; what is one's perspectives on these questions, and how the discussion might affect one's future thinking. 

This is a place to share our souls and learn from others. This is not a place to promote any particular school of thoughts, beliefs, faiths, political views, etc. We must keep an open mind, respect each other, and agree to disagree.
results.how_to_find_us: We will be at the back separate session of the dinning hall, which is accessible from the backdoor towards the parking lot. There will be a sign on the table saying "Soulful Cafe"
results.name: We will enjoy coffee and have a soulful discussion inspired by stimuli

ANIMAL BLESSING SERVICE with Spirit Greetings

SUNDAY, APRIL 24 at 7 pm

Bring your beloved companion animal to church for our annual animal blessings service!

Our healers will be available to give energy healing to your pet...bird, cat, dog, ferret, rabbit...

For their safety and that of the other animals, please have your pet appropriately restrained with a leash for dogs, a cat carrier for small mammals and cats, and a cage for birds.

If your pet is too old and frail, ill, or does not do well around other animals or people unfamiliar to them, or is an exotic (iguana, snake, raccoon, etc.), please bring a picture of your animal instead of the animal. Our healers can work with the photo.

This is a wonderful service, filled with the beautiful energy of the animals! So even if you don't have a pet to bring, you'll want to be here to experience the Annual Animal Blessing Service in concert with Earth Day.

Intermediate Bluegrass Jam

With a number of our SLOW JAM players getting better, the Dedham School of Music is starting a new INTERMEDIATE Bluegrass Jam the 4th Sunday of every month 7 - 9 pm.

The INTERMEDIATE Bluegrass Jam is intended for players who

• are ready for MORE Bluegrass enjoyment

• know a half dozen (or more!!!) favorite Bluegrass songs or fiddle tunes

• can play those songs by heart (no notes) and (mostly) up to speed

• want to learn more complicated tunes and/or techniques from fellow musicians

At the INTERMEDIATE JAM we expect that you will


• play instrumental breaks on selected bluegrass songs or fiddle tunes

• pick up simpler bluegrass songs by ear or by watching the guitar chord changes

• bring and play traditional Bluegrass songs . . . not blues . . . nor rock . . . nor even Dylan 

NO ADMISSION CHARGE - WE "PASS THE HAT" TO PAY OUR RENT

results.description:
This orientation is intended to introduce PGN members who might want to offer events on PGN to the history, philosophy, scope, and strategy of leadership on PGN and some of the tactics and practicalities of offering events on PGN.  (A separate orientation deals with the mechanics of actually creating an offering.) 

This orientation is recommended to anyone who may be interested in creating an event on PGN in the future.  Events could include: 


Social Events 
- Dances; House Parties; Socials; Get-togethers; Reunions; Movies; Dining; Coffee; Cocktails; Bowling; Hiking; Bungee jumping; Ropes course; Games 

Practice Groups 
- Interest groups; Support groups; Mastermind groups; Book clubs; Study groups 

Workshops 
- Presentations; Classes; Webinars; MiniWorkshops;
- Workshops; Seminars; Retreats; Longitudinal (multi-week, multi-month)

Topics

- How PGN redefines the personal growth industry
- What is a leader on PGN?
- What type of events can you offer?
- How do you want to play this game?
- What qualities we look for in leaders?
- Framework for leading on PGN
- Choose your brand name
- Navigation for Leaders
- Tools that PGN provides
- Become a leader on PGN

A Bit About Leadership on PGN

Personal growth leaders are members of PGN who offer social, practice, or workshop events on PGN.  PGN leaders create over 200 events a year.  

One of the main goals of the Personal Growth Network is to identify and support leaders who can create personal growth events for the community.

Any member of PGN may offer an event on PGN, sharing their journey, their gifts, their joy, their successes, their vision, or their interests with like-hearted PGN members.

PGN offers such leaders a toolbox of software, of coaching, and of support to help create successful events that benefit themselves and the membership.


For seasoned leaders, this is an important overview.  Using such a new medium can be a bit confusing initially.  Some leaders, already with decades of experience, come to PGN simply wanting to promote one event to the greater personal growth community.  PGN takes a longer-term, win-win-win approach, different from 'business-as-ux34sual'.  Some long-practiced  but (this class argues) counterproductive, habits may need to change a bit in order to better align older themes with PGN's new paradigm of personal growth in Greater Boston.

For potential leaders, this is an important overview.  Any member thinking about maybe creating something to offer to others can find PGN a very powerful and empowering vehicle.  You just need to learn how to be effective with the toolbox, the support, and the community.

About the Personal Growth Network

The Personal Growth Network is a first-of-its-kind meta-organizer, bringing together diverse personal growth and positive psychology tools and techniques that are designed to help generally healthy people create greater joy and more success in all parts of their life.  Members can try out, learn, and practice numerous approaches; they can select some approaches for more in-depth study and application to their lives; they can practice, support, and share a particular approach with other members; and they can return to PGN to explore different approaches or to work on other parts of their life.  

PGN is also a community of like-hearted people who share an important, but not widely distributed, combination of values and characteristics (e.g., curiosity, willingness to learn, willingness to change habits) around consciously and proactively crafting a life well-lived.  For people with this important combination of characteristics, engaging with other members of the community can be fascinating, supportive, and affirming.

And finally, PGN is a toolbox with which members can create successful events.  Members can create workshops, practice groups, and social events through which they can share their journey, their gifts, their joy, their successes, their vision, and their interests.

About the Orientation Series

Given the enormous ambition and power of the Personal Growth Network, and its rapid growth, it is easy to feel a little overwhelmed at first, so we offer some "How-To" guides to maximize your utilization of the Personal Growth Network for whatever your goals may be.  

Our Orientations include:

For Participants 

- Wed May 4: Newbie Introduction 
. . . (For new, infrequent, or curious members) 
. . . . . (Tentatively repeated on Thu Jun 16)

- Tue May 31: User's Guide
. . . (For active members of PGN) 
. . . . . (Tentatively repeated on Thu Jul 28)

- Thu Jun 30: Customize PGN 
. . . (For reducing emails and focusing on your growth areas) 
. . . . . (Tentatively repeated on Wed Sep 7)


For Leaders 

- Sun Apr 24: Intro to PGN Leadership 
. . . (For members considering offering events) 
. . . . . (Tentatively repeated on Mon Aug 1)

- Sun May 8: Create an Event on PGN 
. . . (For members ready to offer an event) 
. . . . . (Tentatively repeated on Thu Sept 1)

- Sun May 15: Build Your Brand 
. . . (For leaders who want to build an identity.) 
. . . . . (Tentatively repeated on Thu Sept 29) 

About This Particular Orientation:

There is no prerequisite to take this orientation, although it may be useful to have taken the Newbie orientation and very useful to have taken the User's Guide orientation.  

The natural follow-up to this orientation is the mechanics of actually posting an event on PGN.

This orientation is conceived for new or potential leaders who are offering, or are thinking about offering, events on PGN.  Some of the concepts introduced here are expected to be understood in other leadership orientations.

I will also try to address any specific questions that you post below. 

About The Webinar Technology:

This orientation is offered as a "Zoom Webinar".  This means that you will need a computer, and you will need to be in a location where you can listen and watch without distractions.  (There will be opportunities for video discussion as well, so you may want to look presentable, at least from the waist up. ) 

The webinar software used is Zoom.  It runs on most platforms.  If you have not run it before, please click on the link a half-hour before, to ensure that it is working on your system.

The link will be sent to you the day before the event.
results.how_to_find_us: This Webinar is in the comfort of your home, with your computer and pen and paper.  Please sign on at least ten minutes beforehand if you have never experienced a Zoom webinar.

This class is an opportunity to learn or continue your practice of Shamanic Journeying. You will "travel" to meet powers animals and other helpful teachers and guides through the practice of Shamanic Journeying. We will discuss the benefits and the process and then experience two journeys. To the lower world to meet a power animal or guardian spirit, to the upper world to meet a spiritual teacher or to the Middle World to connect to the hidden folk or an element in nature. The class will be catered to the needs and experience of the class.

Shamanic Journeying allows you to lift the veil between our 3D world and other dimensions. It is a wonderful way to get Divine guidance as well as healing from loving helpers who are waiting and eager to be of assistance.

Dress comfortably. Bring a journal or notebook, You may want a scarf or eye mask to cover your eyes to aid in going deeper into the journey.

Feel free to contact me if you have any questions prior to the class.

Price for workshop is $30. Please RSVP. Minimum of 3 people needed to hold this class. Bring a friend!


Wendy

results.description: We will meet in Chinatown,  where a Chinese woman who came to the US to attend college and has lived in Boston for the last three years, and spent a year working in Chinatown,  will take us on a tour of this neighborhood.  Our guide is not a professional tour guide, but will offer her own perspective on Chinatown.  Following the 1.5-2 hour walking tour, our guide will join us for lunch and we can benefit from her knowledge of Chinese food in the area!  We need to limit the size of the group to ten due to the small size of many of the Chinatown shops/businesses.  If there is enough interest, we will repeat this meetup so that all who want to can participate.  If you do not get in to this one, but you are interested in a future tour, please comment below.  The $15/person charge to sign up of for the meetup is to cover the cost of the tour guide.   Each person will pay for their own lunch at the restaurant (to be determined...)  Please bring cash to pay for your lunch.    Note that this tour is planned as an alternative to a much more expensive professional tour that is available in Boston.   I felt that this would be a great alternative and just as much fun!  Remember, no refunds as we will need to pay the tour guide whether or not you are able to attend.

results.name: Walking tour and lunch in Chinatown

results.description:
NUTSHELL - every week day, 12:15ish until 1:45ish, Cumnock Turf Fields at Harvard Stadium, games of 4v4 up to 10v10 or larger depending on who shows, bring a white shirt and a dark/colored shirt (but not a gray one), almost never canceled, read below for more details before asking questions that are answered here, and read the comments for today's meetup to see if there is anything important about today.

http://goo.gl/I0tPQQ

GETTING THERE BY PUBLIC TRANSPORT - Harvard Square is the closest T stop (red line).  Check Google Maps or other to find fastest way there from wherever you are.

GETTING THERE BY RIDE SHARE - a lot of players in this meetup come by car and are nice enough to offer rides to others. Best hope of getting a ride is leaving a comment here asking if anybody is driving and willing to pick you up.

PARKING - you must park at one of the metered spots if you park on Harvard property near the stadium.  They will patrol for cars parked illegally.

COST - free while we play outdoors.

ATTIRE - Bring a *white* shirt and a dark/vivid color shirt so we can easily divide into teams.  DO NOT BRING A GRAY SHIRT- you will annoy a lot of people if you do. Turf shoes or cleats recommended, and sneakers are fine.  Shin-guards optional- most people don't wear them. Bring a ball if you have one.

RSVP and CANCELING - the sooner you RSVP, the better.  That said, most people don't RSVP until around 10:30am the day of the meetup, so we make the call around 11:15am the day of the meetup about whether a game needs to be canceled.  Check here right before heading over.

ETIQUETTE - we have A LOT of players in this meetup and play every (week)day. Each day is a different mix of people, skill levels, and attitudes.  Most people playing do this for fun and/or exercise in the middle of the day.  Please respect this by at least following these unspoken rules that we have:

1) You may not hurt anybody- especially yourself. All of us just want to safely return to the office/class afterward.

2) Do not yell at, criticize, or offer unsolicited "tips" to other players unless they ask for your opinion. It ruins an otherwise fun, all-skill-levels game. If you do this often, you may be asked to find another meetup.

3) Be the first to get the ball if it goes out of bounds. Especially if you kicked it last or are the closest one to the ball. 

4) Fighting is prohibited. We've never come close to having a problem with this, but better stated aloud. If it gets physical, we may call the police as it becomes a felony/legal matter.

WHAT ELSE - All skill levels welcome- it's a big mix. While these are general guidelines, always read the comments section for the latest updates for today's meetup.
