results.description:
Wanna try us out? Come join us at our water training sessions! No prior experience necessary. 

• First two practices are $10 (The $10 can go towards the full membership of $110 for the rest of the season). Pay via Paypal ("Boston 1 - Join us") or venmo (@boston1dboat).</a>

• Also you will not be allowed on the boats if you do not sign the waiver: <a href="https://docs.google.com/forms/d/1Ll2NR3MZbV3O7ZrmPdZsCbKRaC_G8KKa7lwBUlC59Pk/viewform?c=0&w=1">"Boston 1 e-waiver" 

• Make sure to check our Facebook,</a><a href="http://bit.ly/Boston1facebook">http://bit.ly/Boston1facebook for practice announcements and cancellations -- especially in the early and later parts of season with potentially colder night practices. 

Weekly practices are every Monday, Wednesday and Saturday unless a race is scheduled or practice is cancelled.

Mon & Wed: 5:45pm - 8pm, meet 5.45pm on the grassy patch near the Barking Crab. 
Sat: 10:45am - 1pm, meet 10.45am on the grassy patch near the Barking Crab.

Optional dinner/lunch or social activity afterwards!

Outdoor paddling means exposure to the weather and water! Be prepared to get wet!

• Clothing: Wear workout clothes, synthetic fibers that dry quickly are highly recommended. Bring dry clothes to change into afterwards. 

• Footwear: Sandals or flip flops recommended. Some people go barefoot. Shoes and socks are not recommended. 

• Other: Bring plenty of water and sunscreen. Expensive glasses or sunglasses are not recommended. 

All paddling equipment is provided (paddles, pfds). Locked locker provided on-site. Please bring as little as possible to practice as space is limited.

In the event of inclement weather, announcements will be made through the comments area of each meetup event, also in Twitter, Facebook and email alerts.

Sign up for our weekly emails and email alerts

Twitter: @Boston1Dboat

Facebook: http://bit.ly/Boston1facebook

Parking: Channelside Parking at 284 A Street. Enter at 29-41 Necco Street, off Melcher Street. Weekend $5 flat rate. Weekdays $8 flat rate (in after 3pm). More details can be found here: http://bit.ly/1Nxv1lw.

Restroom: Do not use the restrooms in the Barking Crab, use the public restrooms near the Daily Catch

Public Transport: Closest T stop is South Station on the red line.

Hope to see you there!

Free. Fun. Starts here!

Welcome to the Marlborough Couch to 5K sponsored by ConnectingPoint Church. We love people in our community. We've helped over 400 people get off the couch and start jogging!


We have 2 groups: 

 1. Our Jogging Group has a goal of jogging a 5K. 

 2. Our Alumni Jogging Group has a goal of keep jogging for those who have jogged at least once season with us. 

We introduce people to jogging and getting fit. The program gradually moves you from walking at your own pace to jogging at your own pace. 

• FREE 10-week program to get you from the couch to running a 5K (3.1 miles) 

• Anyone from the community can participate

• Led by experienced runners 

• Monday through Thursdays 6pm-6:45pm; Sundays 8am-8:45am, with a goal of joining us 3 of these sessions per week 

• 45 minute time commitment

• Goal of jogging and finishing the Sprit of Hudson 5K in June 

Encourage those you love to get “off the couch” and join you in the great sport of running. Come have some fun! Bring a water bottle and join the group. 

Please arrive 15 minutes early the first night, so we can explain what you'll be doing on the Rail Trail, stretching out, etc.


 Please consult your doctor if you have a health or medical condition that prevents you from exercising. 

For more information please visit http://www.connectingpointchurch.org/couchto5k/

results.description:
Join CCI as their two interns from Boston College, Abbey and Jo, discuss what they've learned over the course of their year at CCI, and how it has impacted their lives. Hear their perspective on issues stemming from our society's culture of white privilege and how the emerging generations view these issues.

Abbey Blum is a current sophomore at Boston College. She is an Environmental Studies major with a Political Science concentration, and part of her presentation will discuss how CCI has shaped her future career goals.

Jo Oh is also a current sophomore at Boston College and is studying Finance and Economics. He will discuss his own journey of understanding racism through his involvement at CCI, focusing specifically on his interaction with Paul Marcus and how his perspective changed since he joined CCI.

Accessibility Information: 14 Beacon Street is wheelchair accessible, but the door to the building is heavy and does not have a button to open it.  Please let us know your needs so we can help make the event accessible for you.
results.how_to_find_us: If the door is locked, dial # and 62 to get into the building. We are in the conference room on the first floor, towards the back of the building.
results.name: CCI Interns Present: Understanding of Systemic Racism as an Emerging Generation

results.description:
Returning for the 2016 season, GBNEMBA is hosting a Monday night ride designed specifically for new and novice MTB'rs. Come learn the basic skills to ride singletrack! We will be teaching bike handling, shifting, body position, basic trail skills and basic trailside bike maintenance in a relaxed and supportive setting.

What to bring:
1. Bike with fat tires (2" or over)
2. Helmet (required)
3. Shoes suitable for riding your bike (no sandals, flip-flops or other open-toed shoes)
4. Water
5. You!

Instruction will be by GBNEMBA's experienced Ride Guides in a supportive, fun environment.

Ride format will *always* be no-drop, very casual pace (Note: this is not a recovery or rest ride for your experienced MTBrs - this is an instructional ride format for new riders). We'll have plenty of opportunity to practice what we learn as we go along! Please be ready to ride by 6:00pm, ride will leave the lot by 6:15pm.

results.description:
Yeah, sure, beer is great to drink, but have you every wondered how can I get even more beer in my life? Well, here's your chance eat beer while you drink beer.

During this class Chef Kimi Ceridon will show you how to make some dessert favorites even better with beer as the secret ingredient. But we won't just hide beer in these baked treats, we will use those flavors of beer that we all love to create unique and tasty treat.

To make sure everyone has something to nosh on while we bake, we dive right in by whipping up some beer mustard and beer cheese to go with soft pretzels. Then we will make Oatmeal Stout Brownies with Hops-infused Whipped Cream and Rye Ale Cinnamon Cookies.

Throughout the class we will cook with and sample beers from Blue Point Brewing Company courtesy of Anheuser-Busch. All participants will leave with snacks and a few beerecipes developed by Kimi. Follow Kimi and learn more at: www.NoReturnTicket.KCeridon.com

Tickets are $30 and can be purchased at: https://www.eventbrite.com/e/cooking-with-beer-tickets-23123358588

results.description:
Note: New date and place (rescheduled from earlier this week)

Fellow GMG'ers!  Jonathan Bobrow recently visited GMG with his invention, AutomaTiles.  He's extremely interested in brainstorming with us how they could be used in different game settings.  We've done this before with other inventors--gather before a playtest, learn about the invention, brain storm creative ways to use them.  Jonathan walks away with great ideas, and maybe you're inspired to help him more. 


Jonathan writes: "AutomaTiles are tangible cellular automata. They are a set of standalone tiles, with the ability to communicate to their adjacent neighbors and then determine their future state from their current state. Given a simple set of rules, such as “blue tiles are only happy, (or flashing) when touching two or more tiles that are of a color other than blue,” the tiles can show the state of a board game, updating in realtime.  They are a platform for playing hands on with dynamic systems and we would love to see what other game designers can come up with on the platform. Tiles can also have probabilistic logic, or change properties based on user interaction. Each tile is essentially a tiny computer which can respond to touch, or sound, communicate with neighboring tiles, and display the RGB spectrum. We have developed an API for quickly prototyping rulesets on the tiles, so we can brainstorm types of games and even implement them to play test.


More information is available at AutomaTiles.com and on GitHub Note: this is my Masters Thesis work at MIT Media Lab Playful Systems Group."

-- 


Venue Details


MIT Media Lab (E14) (Room 240) 75 Amherst St, Cambridge, MA 02139

(corner of Ames and Amherst, a 45 second walk from the Kendall stop on the Red Line)

If you have any questions or if you have any trouble getting in, feel free to call or text us at:


Jonathan: [masked] ([masked])


Jeff:[masked]

results.description:
Agenda

• 6:30: Networking & Pizza

• 7:00: Presentations

Presentation 1: Self Hosting Beyond Your WordPress Website

Jim Reevior

Self hosting WordPress offers more freedom and flexibility than using WordPress.com, but there are still restrictions. With the dropping prices and increasing performance of Virtual Private Servers, self hosting not just your website, but your entire server is quite possible. Jim will talk about why you should consider self hosting from the server level up, how to get started with a VPS, and the basics of configuring and monitoring your own private internet island.

Bio

Jim Reevior is a web developer for STAT, a medical and life sciences publication of Boston Globe Media Partners. He is a longtime technology lover, computer whisperer, WordPress developer and contributor, and also dabbles in DevOps. Linux is his operating system of choice, although he can speak Windows, OS X and even DOS on occasion.

Presentation 2: Easily implement webfonts using MyFonts WP-plugin

Jame Minior and Mark Berube

MyFonts has created a plugin for implementing webfonts from our site, myfonts.com. It’s a beta release right now, and we're interested in WP Boston’s feedback on it. We’ll discuss webfonts and typography then give a demo on the WP-plugin.

Bios

James Minior is a Technical Support specialist at MyFonts. As a typographic aficionado, he loves all font things. In his spare time he draws letters, runs along the Charles River, or goes exploring with camera in hand.

Mark Berube is a web developer at MyFonts. He develops and fixes features for the website and supports the customer service team with any issues that arise. He loves to learn new programming languages and applies them to his side projects.

results.description:
Sharon Salzberg returns to Newton, Massachusetts for an evening talk on Real Love at the Newton South High School. 

To love one another, we must know one another. But our assumptions, distractions, fears, expectations, and personal sense of unworthiness obscure these kernels of truth. We yearn for connection with others, but our minds get in the way, constantly spinning judgments about how we are fundamentally alienated from one another. 

We can train ourselves to change–to listen less to our limiting (and often self-condemning) thoughts – and to hear more of what is out there, thus becoming more present and connected.


Using core Mindfulness, lovingkindness, and other meditation techniques, Sharon Salzberg will guide participants through the process of shedding layers of habit, whether rooted in fear, self-condemnation or other mental conditioning, to find a truer meaning of love for themselves, their loved ones, and those they don’t know, but with whom they share this planet. 

This talk is suitable for both new and experienced meditators, and will include guided meditations, and a question and answer 

Click here for more info and to register
results.name: Sharon Salzberg:  Real Love

results.description:
April's Book is:  A Man Called Ove

by Fredrik Backman

In this “charming debut” (People) from one of Sweden’s most successful authors, a grumpy yet loveable man finds his solitary world turned on its head when a boisterous young family moves in next door.

Meet Ove. He’s a curmudgeon—the kind of man who points at people he dislikes as if they were burglars caught outside his bedroom window. He has staunch principles, strict routines, and a short fuse. People call him “the bitter neighbor from hell.” But must Ove be bitter just because he doesn’t walk around with a smile plastered to his face all the time?
results.name: Book Club

results.description:
Welcome new members!  Please note, RSVPs are required to attend this 35-person, multi-site game night.  The open RSVP spots on Meetup are for new members.


We are a casual group of people who enjoy playing complex board games -- the kind of board games that make you think. We play a variety of games, most of which are Euro style games of medium complexity.  Games often last 90 minutes or more and involve juggling a lot of rules and factors in your head, to decide what to do.  However, there's also plenty of laughter and friendship involved.  If that sounds up your alley, we hope you'll join us.

Our weekly meetup is in a TERRIFIC space for games steps from the Kendall Square T, with easy parking, and lots of room to spread out in.  Full directions are below.  The building door does get locked in the evening, but there is plenty of foot traffic in and out.

Our meetups happen once a week (alternating Mondays and Wednesdays), from 7:00 pm onwards.  Our group has been running since 2007, and we have about 35 attendees each week, including regulars and new members.

1. Due to finite space, you must RSVP to attend.  If you are having a hard time getting a spot, please send a message to the organizer and we will try to work something out!

2. We ask new members for a one-time donation of $5 towards our site fees.  After that, game night is completely free!

3. Please save loud and/or big games (like those with real-time arguing) for when the room is less full -- typically we thin out slightly by 10:00.  This allows us to accommodate more people, and play a greater variety of games.

We play whatever people bring, which typically includes a lot of Euros.  Here's a "tip of the iceberg" look at a few games that have been popular lately:

7 Wonders, Terra Mystica, Race for the Galaxy, Splendor, One Night Werewolf, Le Havre, Hansa Teutonica, Machi Koro, Concordia, Super Big Boggle


As you can see, there is some real variety.  (We do play some light games, but if that's the main thing you want to play, please try our Light Game Night instead!)  Our regular attendees bring about 20-30 games between them, so there's always a lot to choose from.  But if you have a game you like, just bring it with you!

If you haven't played these kind of games before, but think you'll like them, you're welcome too!  But be aware that you are NOT likely to find traditional American games (like Monopoly, Sorry, Risk, or Poker); heavy strategy or negotiation games (like 18xx, wargames, or Diplomacy); or pure abstract games (like Chess).

Finally, a note about Settlers of Catan and Ticket to Ride.  These are traditional "gateway games" that many people play when they first discover Euros.  Although you will occasionally find those games at our meetups, many of us have played them to death and have become more interested in games with a little more complexity to them.

OUTBOUND (from Boston / from Park Street)
Take the Red Line to Kendall Square station. Exit at the gates at the front of the train. Cross the street. (If you take the escalator up, turn around first to see the street.) After crossing, proceed behind the T entrance (perpendicular to Main Street).  Building E25 is the brick building a quarter block down, across from the parking lot.

INBOUND (from Alewife / Porter / Harvard / Central)
Take the Red Line to Kendall Square station. Exit at the gates at the rear of the train. Take the stairs or elevator straight up. Proceed straight ahead (perpendicular to Main Street). Building E25 is the brick building a quarter block down, across from the parking lot.

FROM BOSTON (or Memorial Drive)
1) Take Massachusetts Ave heading north (cross the river if coming from Boston).  Memorial Drive is the first cross street past the river; go past it.
2) Take the first right, onto Vassar St.  (Vassar is the first right after Memorial Drive.)
3) Take the first right, onto Main St.
4) Pass two signals, then turn right onto Hayward.  You may park in the parking lot on the right side of Hayward.  An MIT parking permit is NOT required in the evening, but please do not park in the spaces marked Medical. Exit the parking lot at the rear (opposite from where you entered). Building E25 will be directly across the street.

FROM CAMBRIDGE (or points west)
1) Take Massachusetts Ave heading south.
2) Take a left onto Vassar St.  (Vassar is the last left before Memorial Drive; there is a railroad crossing there.)
3) Take the first right, onto Main St.
4) Pass two signals, then turn right onto Hayward.  You may park in the parking lot on the right side of Hayward.  An MIT parking permit is NOT required in the evening, but please do not park in the spaces marked Medical. Exit the parking lot at the rear (opposite from where you entered). Building E25 will be directly across the street.

Once you enter, Room 119 is just past the stairs on the right.  We ask new members for a one-time donation of $5.00 that goes towards site fees.

Feel free to email with any questions -- we hope to see you at a meetup soon.

results.description:
Join us for an introduction to this unique Japanese martial art. Participants will all get a chance to practice some basic movements, explore a bit of the underpinning philosophy, and experience seated meditation. In short, we will have fun together learning about this martial way, one unknown to many in the United States. 

Shorinji Kempo is a relatively new martial art. It was founded just after WWII as part of a Zen Buddhist practice. Today, while the martial art has been separated from the religion, the practice of Shorinji Kempo remains true to it's Zen Buddhist roots, with philosophy and meditation still integral to the study in the dojo of hard (punches, kicks and blocks) and soft techniques (releases, joint locks and throws).

results.description:
Q & A:


Q.  I have never played x-wing, can I still play? 


A.  Yes, we will teach and supply ships and materials.  

Q.  Should I bring something? 
A.  If you want, bring a game you feel comfortable teaching. There will be pizza and sodas served, feel free to bring snacks or beverages to share or chip in $5 to $10 for the pizza/beverages in the pizza cup.


Q.  Until when do you play games?  Can I arrive later than 7pm? 
A.  Until the last game of the evening ends, usually past midnight.  Yes, you can arrive later than 7pm, but you may have to wait for a new game to start if you do.

Q.  I really want to play XYZ game instead of X-Wing, can we do that? 
A.  Some people ask for interest in a particular game on the event comments below.  This may be the way to make sure you get to play the game you want.  The game room will accomodate more players doing other games.  Just make sure you have game partners for that game or that you are fine in joining the x-wing game if no other players show up for the other game.

results.description:
Viruses are all around us. Some don't bother us. Others will do us in if given half a chance. Fortunately, there are scientists dedicated to studying these wee beasties, finding out what makes them tick and, more importantly, how to prevent them from making us sick.

This month, Boston Skeptics is very excited to welcome Paul Duprex, Director of Cell and Tissue Imaging at Boston's highly controversial BSL-4 lab, the National Emerging Infectious Diseases Laboratories (NEIDL). He will talk about why we need to work with viruses in labs under high containment, why vaccines are amazingly effective and have saved countless lives, and that you can't trust celebrities (cough*Jenny McCarthy*cough) on topics like this.

In addition to his role at NEIDL, Paul Duprex is a Professor of Microbiology in the Department of Microbiology at Boston University School of Medicine. He is a molecular virologist with nearly twenty-five years’ experience. His PhD and post-doctoral work involved studies of foot and mouth disease virus and the now eradicated rinderpest virus. This required animal biosafety level four (ABSL-4) training at the Institute for Animal Health, Pirbright, UK. His interests in working in biocontainment continue and he is currently undergoing mentored BSL-4 training at NEIDL.

From 1999 until 2010 he was a Lecturer/Senior Lecturer in Molecular Virology at The Queen's University of Belfast, Northern Ireland, UK. During this time he took a one-year leave of absence and worked for Johnson and Johnson (J&J) as Head of the Department of Emerging Sciences and Technologies at TransForm Pharmaceuticals, Lexington, MA, USA.

His research focuses on understanding the molecular basis of viral pathogenesis and vaccine attenuation, with a view to developing rationally attenuated vaccines. His interest in animal virology continues and he is actively studying barriers which restrict cross-species transmission events, with the aim of developing tools to predict pathogen evolution. He works primarily on human and animal paramyxoviruses such as measles, mumps, human respiratory syncytial and canine distemper viruses. He has received funding from DHS, DARPA, BBSRC, MRC, NIH, The Wellcome Trust, Zoetis LLC and the Bill and Melinda Gates Foundation Grand Challenges in Global Health Program. He serves as reviewer for numerous scientific journals, international institutions and for funding bodies which have supported his program of research.

Paul has chaired the Virus Division of the Microbiology Society (MicroSoc), is a Senior Editor for mSphere (American Society of Microbiology) and an Editor for the Journal of General Virology (MicroSoc) and FEMS Microbiological Reviews. He is a member of the European Society of Virology (ESV) Scientific Advisory Board and co-organizes the triennial Negative Strand Virology (NSV) conference.

He tweets as @10queues

results.description:
Climbing MeetUp at MetroRock Gym in Everett. Toprope, sport leading, and bouldering available, including some tall walls up to 55 feet. Whether you're a new or experienced climber, join us for a fun and solid workout! We usually have people at all levels. Gym meetups are also a great way to make more friends for outdoor climbing. Plus Mondays are Ladies' Night: discounted admission. If you'd like to lead climb, don't forget to bring your rope :)

*** If you are new to MetroRock Gym and/or climbing, please see the FAQ below. ***

Please RSVP if possible; helps everyone to know others are coming.  Meet at the picnic table near bouldering area (usually the round one, furthest from the cubbies, if available) at 7 PM.  We usually wait a few minutes for people to show and make introductions, but if you arrive later and miss us at the table,  check the small whiteboard near the bathrooms and water fountain, for a description of what the Event Host (see RSVP list) is wearing that day, and come find us on the walls.  Don't be shy, make an effort to ask around and find the group; we're all friendly.  We usually climb until 9-9:30-ish, but if you'd like to secure partner(s) who can come earlier or stay later, feel free to post to the comment section below.

Full-access Day Pass:  $22.  Students, Military or Bouldering-Only Pass:  $18.  Mondays are Ladies Night:  Women's Pass $14 after 3 PM & also special class pricing.


For membership, gear rentals, and other programs and pricing available, or for directions, check the gym website:  http://www.metrorock.com/

Frequently Asked Questions for Newbies:

Q) How do I get to the gym?

A) See website for directions: http://www.metrorock.com/ If you're driving here for the first time, it can be tricky to find MetroRock Everett, especially in the dark! Use a GPS if possible. MetroRock is in a building opposite Boston Coach.   If you don't have a vehicle, the gym offers a shuttle service from nearby Wellington T Station; call the gym for schedule details.

Q) I've never climbed at MetroRock Gym before, what do I need to do?

A) You'll need to take and pass a belay test for rope climbing. There is a separate test for toproping and sport lead climbing (if you are interested in both). For toproping, if you are not confident you can tie a re-threaded figure-8 knot and double fisherman's backup knot and safely belay a climber using an ATC device, it is highly recommended you take the Basic Safety class. They will not allow you to climb on ropes without passing a belay test. Call MetroRock in advance to reserve your spot in the class, and ask them about any discounts or special prices they are offering. Also, you can rent basic climbing gear (harness, shoes, belay device, etc), if needed, at the gym.

results.description:
Robert C. Berwick and Noam Chomsky discuss Why Only Us: Language and Evolution

Online pre-sales (ticket + book = $24.50) go on sale March 22nd HERE - [book only ($5) April 5th]. This event includes a book signing.

Monday, April 25th, 7pm (Doors at 6:30)


First Parish Church - 1446 Mass. Ave., Cambridge

:: :: ::

Harvard Book Store welcomes ROBERT C. BERWICK, Professor of Computational Linguistics and Computer Science and Engineering at MIT, and renowned author, logician, and philospher NOAM CHOMSKY for a discussion of their book, Why Only Us: Language and Evolution.

About Why Only Us

We are born crying, but those cries signal the first stirring of language. Within a year or so, infants master the sound system of their language; a few years after that, they are engaging in conversations. This remarkable, species-specific ability to acquire any human language—"the language faculty"—raises important biological questions about language, including how it has evolved. This book by two distinguished scholars—a computer scientist and a linguist—addresses the enduring question of the evolution of language.

Robert Berwick and Noam Chomsky explain that until recently the evolutionary question could not be properly posed, because we did not have a clear idea of how to define "language" and therefore what it was that had evolved. But since the Minimalist Program, developed by Chomsky and others, we know the key ingredients of language and can put together an account of the evolution of human language and what distinguishes us from all other animals.

Berwick and Chomsky discuss the biolinguistic perspective on language, which views language as a particular object of the biological world; the computational efficiency of language as a system of thought and understanding; the tension between Darwin's idea of gradual change and our contemporary understanding about evolutionary change and language; and evidence from nonhuman animals, in particular vocal learning in songbirds.

Praise

"Explaining the origins of the unique is famously difficult. Through elegantly showing the simplicity of the underlying mechanism, Berwick and Chomsky adroitly surmount this problem in the case of that most remarkable of all human uniquenesses, our possession of language." —Ian Tattersall, author of The Strange Case of the Rickety Cossack: And Other Cautionary Tales from Human Evolution

"Berwick and Chomsky, masters of language and computer science, make a daring proposition: the phenomenon 'human language' arose when the brain evolved to instantiate the simple operation 'Merge.' At this crucial moment the complex trait, which led to a new mode of evolution, fell into place. The book is captivating and a must for everyone interested in evolution and humans. It is a landmark that will define future research." —Martin Nowak, Professor of Mathematics and Biology, Harvard University

:: :: ::

Purchase the Book: Featured event books will be for sale at the event for 20% off. Thank you for supporting this author series with your purchases.

General Info: (617)[masked] - [masked]

Media Inquiries: (617)[masked] x1 - [masked]

results.description:
Our brand new lighter games meetup event.  This is a great opportunity to socialize and play games in a relaxed environment -- and best of all, there's no cap on attendance.

We are a casual group of people who enjoy playing complex board games -- the kind of board games that make you think. We play a variety of games, but the games at this particular event are going to be on the smaller side -- because those are often the games that work best in a cafe setting.

Our main meetup requires RSVPs due to heavy popularity and finite space.  This event runs simultaneously, two buildings away.  RSVPs are NOT required for this event.  RSVPs are still appreciated so the event hosts know how many people to expect, but you don't need to update them and can come even if you don't RSVP.

This event takes place once a week (alternating Mondays and Wednesdays), from 7:00 - 9:30.  Sometimes members will go to a nearby bar (like Champions or Meadhall) afterwards for more gaming.  Please note that our other meetup is still full at this hour, so it is not usually possible to attend both meetups in the same night.

Cosi Cafe has graciously allowed us to use their back seating area every week.  You are not required to buy anything from them, but their food is honestly pretty good, so please take advantage of them if you are hungry for dinner, soft drinks, or snacks.

We play whatever people bring, but you don't have to bring anything -- the hosts will always have a bag of games with them!  Some games that you might expect to see here include:

Red 7, Love Letter, Codenames, Pictomania, The Resistance, Avalon, One Night Ultimate Werewolf, Bang!, Glory to Rome, Innovation, Mottainai, Chrononaughts, Time Lines, Tash-Kalar

If you're looking for longer or larger Euros (like 7 Wonders, Puerto Rico, or Terra Mystica), check out our regular "Game Night" meetup.

If you haven't played these kind of games before, but think you'll like them, you're welcome too!  But be aware that you are NOT likely to find traditional American games (like Monopoly, Sorry, Risk, or Poker); heavy strategy or negotiation games (like 18xx, wargames, or Diplomacy); or pure abstract games (like Chess).

OUTBOUND (from Boston / from Park Street)
Take the Red Line to Kendall Square station. Exit at the gates at the front of the train. Cross the street. (If you take the escalator up, turn around first to see the street.) After crossing, turn left and walk about 20 feet to Cosi.

INBOUND (from Alewife / Porter / Harvard / Central)
Take the Red Line to Kendall Square station. Exit at the gates at the rear of the train. Take the stairs up, then up again towards the busy street, which is Main Street.  Turn left and walk about 20 feet to Cosi.

FROM BOSTON (or Memorial Drive) 
1) Take Massachusetts Ave heading north (cross the river if coming from Boston).  Memorial Drive is the first cross street past the river; go past it. 
2) Take the first right, onto Vassar St.  (Vassar is the first right after Memorial Drive.) 
3) Take the first right, onto Main St. 
4) Pass two signals, then turn right onto Hayward.  You may park in the parking lot on the right side of Hayward.  An MIT parking permit is NOT required in the evening, but please do not park in the spaces marked Medical.
5) One side of the parking lot has a bunch of buildings with a handicapped ramp leading into it.  Go up the ramp, through the walkway, and Cosi will be right next to you when you come out.

FROM CAMBRIDGE (or points west) 
1) Take Massachusetts Ave heading south. 
2) Take a left onto Vassar St.  (Vassar is the last left before Memorial Drive; there is a railroad crossing there.) 
3) Take the first right, onto Main St. 
4) Pass two signals, then turn right onto Hayward.  You may park in the parking lot on the right side of Hayward.  An MIT parking permit is NOT required in the evening, but please do not park in the spaces marked Medical.
5) One side of the parking lot has a bunch of buildings with a handicapped ramp leading into it.  Go up the ramp, through the walkway, and Cosi will be right next to you when you come out.

Qualche dato:

L'Italia nel 2015 era in posizione N. 61 nella Classifica di Transparency International (La Danimarca era N. 1 e Somalia ultima, in posizione 168). Si tratta di un piccolo miglioramento rispetto alla posizione N 69 degli anni 2014 e 2013 e N. 72 nel 2012.

https://issuu.com/transparencyinternational/docs/2015_corruptionperceptionsindex_rep?e=2496456/33011041


Nell'ultimo decennio sono andati in prescrizione il 9.2% dei processi. "...dal 2005, quando a dicembre, dal governo Berlusconi, fu approvata la legge ex Cirielli sulla prescrizione breve, alla fine del 2014. Il dato complessivo, "il totale dell'ultimo decennio", parla di[masked] prescrizioni. Si parte con le[masked] del 2005, per calare progressivamente alle[masked] del 2012. Ma dal 2013 il trend cresce,[masked] nel 2013, e siamo alle[masked] di due anni fa...."

http://www.repubblica.it/politica/2016/02/13/news/prescrizione_cancalla_processi-133317375/?ref=search

Come e’ strutturata la serata? 

• Mezz’ora per salutarci e ordinare cena (Di norma ci incontriamo per cena)

• Un’ora di discussione sul tema di discussione 

• Un’ora di discussione su temi vari di piu’ recente cronaca proposti dai partecipanti 

• Varie ed eventuali 

Quali sono le regole per la discussione? 


1.  Apprezzare la diversita’ di idee


2.  Basare la discussion su fatti e numeri 

3.  Sforzarsi di capire il punto di vista degli altri 

4.  Criticare i fatti e le politiche, non le persone o i politici 

5.  Dare a tutti la possibilita' di parlare 

6.  Promuovere un clima di amicizia 

(Adattato da: http://ctb.ku.edu/en/table-of-contents/lead...)
results.name: Corruzione: Cosa fa' il governo?

results.description:
This month we will be reading The End of the World Running Club by Adrian Walker. 

 From Goodreads, "Edgar Hill is 35 and caught in his own headlock. Overweight slob, under-performing husband and reluctant father – for Ed, the world may as well have already ended.
So when it does end in a catastrophic asteroid strike and Edgar and his family find refuge in an Edinburgh army barracks, it comes as something of a relief. His world becomes simpler, life becomes easier, things might just be looking up.
But nothing's ever that simple. Returning from a salvage run in the city, Edgar finds his family gone, taken to the south coast for evacuation by an international task force.  Suddenly he finds himself facing a gruelling journey on foot across a devastated United Kingdom. Accompanied by a group of misfits that include a large, hairy tattoo artist and an old man who claims to have run around Australia, Edgar must race against time and overcome his own short-comings, not to mention 100 mile canyons and a very strange council estate, to find the people he loves before he loses them forever. "

We meet at the Newton Public Library on the 3rd floor in the rear crescent.  Plenty of free parking available. 

Be sure to check out our goodreads page at: https://www.goodreads.com/group/show/161102-newton-library-scifi-book-club

results.description:
(Please note: many of the friends who attend regularly are not Meetup members, so there are always more people attending that it says on the Meetup site.)

About This Meditation Meetup

We sit in silence for around 45 minutes, followed by discussion for around 30 minutes or so. The silent sitting is interspersed with some meditation instruction, perhaps a brief reading, a little simple inquiry, exploration or movement. Sitting posture is relaxed, either on a meditation cushion or a bench. It's not a rigid practice- move whenever you need to!

We meet every Monday night, 7:30 pm at the Cambridge Friends Meeting House. The Friends Meeting House is located at 5 Longfellow Park, Cambridge, MA 02138 You can find a very good map here: <a href="http://www.fmcquaker.org/FMC-Map_2006.pdf" target="_blank"></a>

http://fmcquaker.org/about-friends-meeting-at-cambridge/directions/

Parking is available after 6:00 in the loop off of Brattle St. that leads to the Friend's House, and there is a small lot in back of the Friend's House for those with limited mobility. After that, parking is a little tricky in Cambridge (lots of "resident only" signs), but you will find available parking on Mount Auburn St. near Friend's House and on Brattle St. as you head away from Harvard Square.

Coming by the T is a great option, with the Friend's House being a lovely 15 minute walk out of Harvard Square.

If you find you are running late, come anyway! The format is very relaxed and open— anyone interested in contemplative practice is welcome!

 

About Open Awareness Meditation Group

At the heart of these meditation sessions is the silent exploration of what we refer to as Open Awareness. We all know what it means to feel closed, limited, vulnerable, or separate. What is it like to allow ourselves to return to our natural condition of openness, presence, non-separateness and ease? This is what we explore in our meetings.

We have been meeting for over a decade, and those who lead the meditations have known each other and been practicing together for many years. They have all deeply explored a variety of traditions— for some it has been the Tibetan Buddhist practices of Dzogchen or Mahamudra, for others it has been the Indian traditions of Yoga, or Advaita, or what is currently referred to as Nonduality (some popular examples of this are Francis Lucille, Rupert Spira, Eckhart Tolle and Adyashanti). 

However all of these traditions ultimately point to the same truth, the truth of our basic awareness or presence which is beyond any tradition, practice or teaching. This is the presence we share, and the presence we are, beyond words. This is what we explore in our meetings.

This group is unique in that there is no specific guiding teacher, lama, or guru. We all meet as equals to question, share, and inspire each other to explore the Open Awareness we most deeply are. The meetings are suitable for newcomers as well as experienced meditators, and all are very welcome.
results.name: Open Awareness Meditation Group Meetup

In order to identify good note opportunities, optimize your time, and negotiate the most profitable note deals, investors first need to get a grip on what actually makes a note valuable, and what takes away from their value and appeal.

What Makes Notes Valuable?

20 factors that can impact the value and appeal of a note for investing:

1.  Loan amount

2.  Balance

3.  Property value

4.  Loan-to-value

5.  Location

6.  Market direction

7.  Discount

8.  Amount of remaining payments

9.  Interest rate

10.  Type of note and collateral

11.  Term left on the note

12.  Condition of underlying collateral

13.  Other liens against the property or borrower

14.  Borrower credit profile

15.  Seasoning on the note

16.  Maturity date

17.  Performance of the note

18.  Who is selling the note

19.  Ease of acquisition

20.  Occupancy Status

Our goal at NNG is to build a note community by teaching investors how to capitalize on the foreclosure crisis by buying mortgage notes for pennies on the dollar. Purchasing mortgage notes is another alternative to buying foreclosure or owning rental properties.

results.description:
RSVPing just on Meetup does NOT get you a seat to this event. Please also need to RSVP and pay on Eventbrite. To save money use Promo Code KATHY. One of my Harvard Negotiation teacher is offering an in-depth 2 Day training in Negotiation and Behavior change. This is a great opportunity to learn skills that can help in both your personal and professional life from an expert in the field.

He is generously offering a 5% discount off the regular price of $264.74 to Boston Social and Cultural Club members who want to attend. Just use the promo code Kathy when you register.

https://www.eventbrite.com/e/negotiation-and-behavior-change-training-april-26-27-boston-ma-tickets-23063559728

The program is on April[masked]:00AM - 5:00PM

Every day, both professionally and personally, we engage in a continuous series of negotiations. While it may seem beyond what we formally think of as negotiation (contracts, clients), we are constantly negotiating, with our bosses, subordinates, peers, group members, customers, and clients. In order to succeed in our professional (and personal) lives, we need to be able to communicate and collaborate effectively with the people around us. To do so, we need key negotiation tools and communication skills to apply to the many, varied negotiations we engage in every day.

This two-day workshop focuses on the nature of these interactions and helps participants gain insight into their own strengths and weaknesses as negotiators. Participants will learn the best ways to get what they want in a negotiation while strengthening (rather than damaging) their relationship with their negotiation counterpart. Using short lectures, role-plays, exercises and simulations, the workshop will provide a number of opportunities for participants to develop and test their skills.

Beyond negotiation and influence theory, this course will teach participants how to incorporate the accompanying communication skills into their lives as new habits in a way that produces lasting changes in their behavior. We all learn to negotiate (advocate for our interests) at a very young age, leading each of us to have developed a set of negotiation skills and habits that we employ, often without giving it much thought. Without conscious attention to our negotiation style, we are limited to this narrow repertoire of familiar responses. And while these default responses may work well in some situations, they limit and handicap us in others. This course provides a model for shifting out of these default behaviors.

All are welcome to attend the training and we are hoping to attract individuals and organizations pursuing missions of Sustainability, Corporate Social Responsibility and Social Entrepreneurship.

Our meetup will get 5% off the regular $264.74 price by using the Promo Code Kathy. Tickets through Eventbrite

https://www.eventbrite.com/e/negotiation-and-behavior-change-training-april-26-27-boston-ma-tickets-23063559728

Where 50 Milk St - 50 Milk Street 17th Floor (ImpactHub), Boston, MA 02109 -

View Map

results.description:
NUTSHELL - every week day, 12:15ish until 1:45ish, Cumnock Turf Fields at Harvard Stadium, games of 4v4 up to 10v10 or larger depending on who shows, bring a white shirt and a dark/colored shirt (but not a gray one), almost never canceled, read below for more details before asking questions that are answered here, and read the comments for today's meetup to see if there is anything important about today.

http://goo.gl/I0tPQQ

GETTING THERE BY PUBLIC TRANSPORT - Harvard Square is the closest T stop (red line).  Check Google Maps or other to find fastest way there from wherever you are.

GETTING THERE BY RIDE SHARE - a lot of players in this meetup come by car and are nice enough to offer rides to others. Best hope of getting a ride is leaving a comment here asking if anybody is driving and willing to pick you up.

PARKING - you must park at one of the metered spots if you park on Harvard property near the stadium.  They will patrol for cars parked illegally.

COST - free while we play outdoors.

ATTIRE - Bring a *white* shirt and a dark/vivid color shirt so we can easily divide into teams.  DO NOT BRING A GRAY SHIRT- you will annoy a lot of people if you do. Turf shoes or cleats recommended, and sneakers are fine.  Shin-guards optional- most people don't wear them. Bring a ball if you have one.

RSVP and CANCELING - the sooner you RSVP, the better.  That said, most people don't RSVP until around 10:30am the day of the meetup, so we make the call around 11:15am the day of the meetup about whether a game needs to be canceled.  Check here right before heading over.

ETIQUETTE - we have A LOT of players in this meetup and play every (week)day. Each day is a different mix of people, skill levels, and attitudes.  Most people playing do this for fun and/or exercise in the middle of the day.  Please respect this by at least following these unspoken rules that we have:

1) You may not hurt anybody- especially yourself. All of us just want to safely return to the office/class afterward.

2) Do not yell at, criticize, or offer unsolicited "tips" to other players unless they ask for your opinion. It ruins an otherwise fun, all-skill-levels game. If you do this often, you may be asked to find another meetup.

3) Be the first to get the ball if it goes out of bounds. Especially if you kicked it last or are the closest one to the ball. 

4) Fighting is prohibited. We've never come close to having a problem with this, but better stated aloud. If it gets physical, we may call the police as it becomes a felony/legal matter.

WHAT ELSE - All skill levels welcome- it's a big mix. While these are general guidelines, always read the comments section for the latest updates for today's meetup.

results.description:
Data and analytics are changing the way businesses compete and operate by driving new types of insights that empower individuals and organizations to achieve far more than ever before. A key to driving value from big data is getting analytics out of IT and spread throughout the organization. This shift to the spread of analytics throughout the organization and accompanying empowerment of individual users has led to the substantial increase in popularity in recent years of the R programming language. R is now the predominant tool used for computational statistics, data science and visualization. R is used extensively by the largest analytics driven companies in the world such as Google LinkedIn and Facebook.


In this session we will addresses the challenges of scaling R analytics at an enterprise level for big data and making scalable R analytics readily accessible to end users. We will explore the use of scalable, high performance platforms such as Spark; in-memory, columnar, massively parallel databases; and Hadoop to enable scalable R analytics. We will also explore cloud deployment patterns for enhanced agility and accessibility. In the session we will walk through examples and demos of R programs running on these scalable platforms.
results.how_to_find_us: https://www.google.com/maps?f=q&hl=en&q=1+Rogers+Street,+Cambridge,+MA,+us
results.name: Accelerating and Scaling R Analytics Using Spark R, In-memory Columnar Databases

We have 2 groups: 

 1. Our Jogging Group has a goal of jogging a 5K. 

 2. Our Alumni Jogging Group has a goal of keep jogging for those who have jogged at least once season with us. 

We introduce people to jogging and getting fit. The program gradually moves you from walking at your own pace to jogging at your own pace. 

• FREE 10-week program to get you from the couch to running a 5K (3.1 miles) 

• Anyone from the community can participate

• Led by experienced runners 

• Monday through Thursdays 6pm-6:45pm; Sundays 8am-8:45am, with a goal of joining us 3 of these sessions per week 

• 45 minute time commitment

• Goal of jogging and finishing the Sprit of Hudson 5K in June 

Encourage those you love to get “off the couch” and join you in the great sport of running. Come have some fun! Bring a water bottle and join the group. 

Please arrive 15 minutes early the first night, so we can explain what you'll be doing on the Rail Trail, stretching out, etc.


 Please consult your doctor if you have a health or medical condition that prevents you from exercising. 

For more information please visit http://www.connectingpointchurch.org/couchto5k/

results.description:
Back from the dead! Join us on April 26 for a meetup at the DigitasLBi Boston offices. Please note: if you are going to attend this meeting, you will need to RSVP and provide contact information so you can be added to the visitor list for access to the meeting location.

Our Speakers:

Peter and Joey, our friends at AXIS 41, authors of AEM Podcast will be talking about "Developing with the Dispatcher in Mind." An often forgotten about piece of AEM development is the caching layer of the AEM infrastructure called the Dispatcher. And it is forgotten about at a website's peril. Peter Nash and Joey Smith will discuss how the AEM infrastructure is normally setup, some misconceptions, what a dispatcher does for you, how it works, what to do if the site isn’t caching properly, how to diagnose problems, and some tools to help developers use the dispatcher better. Speaker Bios:

Peter Nash

Peter has been a Technical Project Manager in the web development industry since 2006, specializing in Adobe Experience Manager for the last three of those years. Peter serves as the Editor In Chief for AEM Podcast.

Joey Smith

Joey has been a Software Developer and Systems/Server Administrator since 1999, specializing in AEM for the last two years. Joey serves as the Chief Technology Adviser for AEM Podcast

Thank you Peter, Joey and AXIS 41 for flying all the way from Salt Lake City to speak to our group.
results.name: AEM Developer Community in New England reboot!

results.description:
Sketch is a lightweight, powerful, interface-focused vector design tool. It is easy to learn, costs a fraction of the price of Photoshop and is quickly becoming the industry go-to. Sketch is perfect for designing on multiple devices and delivering assets quickly. It was recently voted the most used Wireframing and Interface Design tool on a survey responded by 4,000 designers.


In this class, we'll go through the basics of Sketch and learn how to create designs for web and mobile applications by completing simple exercises. We'll cover getting started in Sketch, working with artboards, creating symbols, designing with user interface (UI) kits, exporting screens and using plugins to get you designing quicker and more efficiently.

Who should take this class?

This class is recommended for designers, developers and anyone who wants to learn how to use Sketch to create beautiful deliverables!

All attendees are expected to abide by the Girl Develop It Code of Conduct.  


Takeaways

• Basic understanding of Sketch and how to navigate around its interface

• Best practices, tips and resources

• The tools to begin creating professional-looking designs for web and mobile applications

*We will be raffling off 1 Sketch license, graciously donated by Sketch, at the end of this class!


Pre-reqs & Preparation

You do not need any prior experience with Sketch. Just come with a desire to learn and the following tools:

• Laptop & charger - Mac OS X 10.10+

• Note that Sketch is for Mac only

• Sketch installed on your computer. If you do not currently have Sketch on your computer, you can buy it for $99 or download a free 14-day trial here. (Note: If you are using the free trial, please do not install Sketch until the day before or the day of class to make sure you get the most out of your free trial!)

Class Schedule

The class will take place on Tuesday, April 26th from 6:30-8:30pm.

Instructor

Jamie Lee Connor

Jamie works as a User Experience Designer on the Product Management team at Epsilon, a global leader in data-driven marketing. She spends her time creating, testing and iterating on prototypes with the goal of building intuitive and easy to use products.


Previously, she worked as a Front-end Developer designing and building websites and as a Visual Designer on a global marketing team. Jamie studied Graphic Design at Massachusetts College of Art & Design and has been continuously learning ever since. She is excited to help women transition into the tech field and expand their skill set!

We start off chatting about our work, including setting goals for ourselves (which is entirely optional but super helpful!), and then we write. There is power for laptops, and some of us use pen and paper. Your choice! Bonus: there's no Internet access, so you can omit a huge distraction without even trying. And, although we are not a discussion group, there are many areas where people can go if they want to talk without being disruptive.

results.description:
Are you curious about programming or thinking about pursuing a career in software engineering? 

Then RSVP on this meet-up page for this 2-hour Intro to Coding class happening in the Boston area at CIC Boston. Learn the basics of programming, do hands-on exercises, and meet new people. All for free!

The class is being taught by MakerSquare, which runs some of the top coding schools in the country.

Class officially starts at 6:30pm, but please arrive at CIC Boston by 6:15pm to mingle with your fellow classmates and settle in. We will end at 9pm, with the last 30 minutes being an optional Q&A session.

What will I learn during the class?

This beginner ­level class will contain several instructor-guided exercises. The class will cover the following topics:

   1. Overview of programming 

   2. Intro to data & data structures

   3. Basics of functions

We ask that you read the Prerequisites section before the start of class and bring your own laptop (Windows, Mac or Linux) with Google Chrome installed.

What is MakerSquare Boston?

MakerSquare is a three-month full-time school for software engineering. By teaching computer science fundamentals and modern web languages like JavaScript, we prepare students to join top flight engineering teams.

We have campuses all over the country, and are excited to be opening a campus in Boston. The free Intro to Coding class is to introduce more people to the wonderful world of programming and to get the community excited about the launch of our full-time class in Boston in July 2016!

Questions? Email us at [masked].
results.name: Free Intro to Coding Class (Tues April 26, 6:30-9pm)

results.description:
Hello Gopher!

Come join your fellow Boston Gophers for an evening of talks and networking. Our community is steadily growing. Be a part of it.

Full-Length Talks:


Go Debugging Tactics - James Bardin

Techniques for debugging Go programs without a debugger". I intend (still need to determine how long these topics will take) cover how to read stack traces, the various GODEBUG options, extracting data from running programs, and possibly some basic profiling for debugging purposes.

Embedded Interfaces - Jeff Mitchell

Many people are aware of and take advantage of embedded structs, but embedded interfaces are much less common. I'll talk about how you can use embedded interfaces to take abstraction to the next level and make it much easier to support disparate implementations.
results.name: April Boston Golang Meeting

results.description:
WEE-HAW!

Its been too long--I miss Miles and Jack!

Lets get together for an encore private screening of the fantastically funny and influential wine film "Sideways" at the screening room in my apartment building Hanover CambridgePark.

This venue is like something you would find in a movie producer's home! Since we are responsible adults, I'm going to make this a free pot-luck. We'll still need to be careful not to mess on the rug, but I believe we can handle it.

READ THIS! Movie -- and security -- start at 7pm on the dot; please plan to arrive 6:30; if you come past 7 you won't be able to get into the building. Helpers at 6pm.


Sideways won the Academy Award for Best Adapted Screenplay, and was nominated for four other awards. It profoundly affected the wine biz here in the US: Mile's famous love monologue to Pinot Noir caused sales -- and prices -- to jump. Likewise, his rant "If those bi*ches order Merlot I'm out of here!" depressed Merlot sales til this day. But there's a twist, hmmm, something about a horse, which I encourage all of you to research and discover for yourselves. There will be a quiz.

COST

FREE!

POLICIES

Seats are limited to 18 total, so no guests. 10 general available seats now, last 8 are reserved for newbies (just get on wait list, I'll move you up). Everyone must be a member of BostonWine. If you've already done this event before, give others a turn. RSVP early, but please don't RSVP unless you're sure that you can make it.

NOTE: As part of the RSVP process you will be asked to accept the group's Policies and Disclaimer (use a new web browser window to see the About Us section of our group). You must answer "Yes" in the RSVP to attend this event. (Note, apparently some versions of the Meetup mobile app don't display this question -- in that case, use a web browser later on to update your RSVP). 

Sideways is a 2004 comedy-drama film written by Jim Taylor and Alexander Payne and directed by Payne. Adapted from Rex Pickett's 2004 novel of the same name, Sideways follows men in their forties, Miles Raymond (Paul Giamatti) and Jack Cole (Thomas Haden Church), who take a week-long road trip to Santa Barbara County Wine Country. Payne and Taylor won multiple awards for their screenplay. Giamatti and Church, as well as actresses Virginia Madsen and Sandra Oh, playing local women who become romantically involved with the men, all received accolades for their performances.

WHAT TO BRING

POT LUCK! You should bring wine, food, serving dishes, utensils, etc. I will supply ice, wine glasses, plates, cleaning supplies.

WHERE

Hanover CambridgePark 
160 CambridgePark Drive 
Cambridge, MA 02140 
Phone:[masked]

T stop: Alewife (Red line)

Parking: No parking at the venue. Best to take T.  Otherwise, park at Alewife T station ($7). Walk down CambridgePark Drive Park, enter main lobby of 160 Hanover and follow general directions. 

The Hanover CambridgePark is a new luxury apartment building complex in the Alewife area of Cambridge. It has a spacious club room where we'll be meeting, a spa-like pool, fitness center, pool, courtyard with fire pits, grills, high-end finishes, etc. Expect to see many more BostonWine events here in 2016!

For those interested in seeing a model apartment, leasing staff will be on hand before the event to do a tour (call ahead to be sure to get a spot). Remember to let them know that you're part of BostonWine. ;-) 

Look forward to seeing you! 

-Jim
results.name: Encore! -- Private screening of "Sideways" film

results.description:
AngularJS is currently one of the most popular frameworks for building dynamic web applications. This class will introduce you to the basic concepts and tools in the AngularJS framework. The class will step through a single page app project so you can see your new skills in action.

We will cover the basics, what MVC/MV* means, and best practices for code design and performance. Angular 1.x will be the focus, but we will also cover differences with the recently released Angular 2.0.


TAKEAWAYS

• Learn the basics of MVC/MV* architecture for Javascript

• Understand the AngularJS toolset and how to apply it to your project

• Use directives and/or ui-router to easily wire up front end views

• Learn how to use (and how not to use) two-way data-binding

• Complete a single page app mini project with AngularJS

• Testing strategies for AngularJS

• Tricks for high performance

• Comparison of Angular 1.x and 2.x


 SCHEDULE

4 Class sessions:

• Tues, April 26 (6:30 - 8:30pm)

• Thurs, April 28 (6:30 - 8:30pm)

• Tues, May 3 (6:30 - 8:30pm)

• Thurs, May 5 (6:30 - 8:30pm)


Your payment registers you for the entire series.

PREREQUISITES

Working knowledge of HTML, CSS, JavaScript, jQuery (if you’ve taken our Intro to HTML/CSS and Intro to JavaScript classes, you should be set to go).

Note: All attendees are expected to abide by the Girl Develop It Code of Note: All attendees are expected to abide by the Girl Develop It Code of Conduct


TECH REQUIREMENTS

• Your laptop. (Note: a netbook or tablet is NOT a substitute!)

• A modern browser such as Chrome or Firefox installed.

• A text editor. We recommend Sublime Text 3 (It's free and available for Mac/PC/Linux).

Having git and Node 5.x is helpful as well but not necessary before class.

YOUR TEACHER

Marcela was an environmental engineering major at MIT. She explored coding as a way to make a difference with fun, educational games. In the process she made a few websites, and enjoyed making them so much that now she does it full time. She has used a variety of stacks on projects, and is currently having fun with React and Scala. As a technical consultant at Cantina, she has worked for clients including Empower and Pearson. All the screen time needs to be offset somehow, so she walks, bikes, or does parkour outside as weather and energy permit. But just as often she'll dream of traveling the world and building a table while surfing Reddit.


FINANCIAL NEED

A limited number of scholarships are available for those with a financial hardship. To apply, click here. Scholarship applicants will be notified shortly after the deadline. Class capacity does not impact scholarship students. Check out this info sheet about getting course fees covered by your employer.


Interested in hosting classes? Email us at boston[at]girldevelopit.com!

Interested in discovering classes like this, workshops, special events, giveaways, volunteer opportunities, and more? Sign up for our monthly newsletter!

results.description:
Is your Law Of Attraction "vibe" attracting the Intimacy you want in your relationships?

Would you like to be able to RELATE AUTHENTICALLY with ease and joy about INTIMACY ....with friends, family and/ or special someone?

Would you like to be able to ask for what you want without being shy or feeling manipulative? 

Would you like to be heard? To be supported? (even when there are different preferences or interests) 

If you say YES to any of the questions, then say YES to joining us on Tuesday. We invite you to explore & expand your relating around Intimacy, and become more "attractive". 


Through highly interactive "games" outside of the context of a workshop or class, where we engage in conversations about connection rather than content, you'll get to delve deeper into discovering what it means to have loving, meaningful, lasting "intimate" connections.It can be fun, silly, deep, powerful, moving, and anything in between.

The skills I get to practice find their way organically into my life to enrich all my relationships with friends, family, workmates, even strangers on the street. ~NM


What are AR Games?
Authentic Relating (AR) Games are a way of using games to invite you to be a compassionate "relate-or". These "games" are extensively tested, masterfully facilitated experiences that give players a hands-on taste of both the joy and skills of interpersonal authentic connection.

From heights of joy and heart-pounding fun to meditative depths of presence, these highly interactive games allow you to explore ways of seeing, connecting, and appreciating yourself and others at a deeper level.

Why Play?
These games allow you to Interact in safe, spontaneous and fun ways. You get to practice the art of relating with others, playing a little more outside your comfort zones.

These games invite you to:
- Learn to speak from what truly matters to you and ask for what you truly want

- Experience the absolute relief of being seen and accepted as together we explore outside the box of social sleepwalking and superficial conversation

- Create and foster conscious, deep connections and discover wonderment in each other’s unique way of relating

What Should I Bring?
The most important thing to bring is your willingness to be curious. Be open to expand your perspective, to be moved by another person, to be surprised by what you learn.

What Can I Expect?
Laughter. Fun. Delicious. More genuine connection. Anxiety/excitement (while learning the difference). Relief. Feeling alive and awake. Juicy. Reverence. Conversation beyond small talk. New possibilities. New friends. Insights. Sparks. Challenges. Empowering. Transformation.

Secure Your Spot: $10**
Please pay at bit.ly/ARGames042616-PP

**If this is your first time at an Authentic Relating Game, we'll be refunding $3 at the event as a thank you for coming to play with us ;0)  

This event is being announced in various places. The RSVPs here do not reflect the accurate total # of attendees. Go ahead and secure a spot, come play with us ;o)

NOTE: Please be here by 6:55 pm. Delicious fun and games kick off at 7 pm.

Your AR Facilitators:
ChewHoong and Michael Trachtman 

We're passionate about fostering a community where the more we let ourselves relate authentically, the more we’ll be deeply congruent and satisfied, and be supported and nourished by each other. 

We have both led many events including Authentic Relating and so excited to support you in your authentic relating journey.

results.description:
Yoga postures came about in ancient times so that yogis would have strong healthy bodies conducive for sitting and meditating for hours and days.

Nowadays, as modern yogis, we can still reap the many benefits of yoga practice which can have a positive impact on our body and mind, our life and relationships.

This mixed-level yoga class begins with setting intention and breathing techniques, followed by a therapeutic joint freeing series, standing and balancing postures, and other postures such as back and belly strengtheners and hip openers. The last twenty minutes are spent in guided meditation, using techniques such as breath awareness, visualization, and contemplating themes to enhance our inner good qualities.

No prior yoga or meditation experience necessary. Please wear comfortable, fitted, modest clothing. You may bring a sticky mat if you have one but it is not required. All welcome.

Yoga at Kurukulla Center is offered freely and while donations are gratefully received according to the students' financial ability, they are not expected. There is a donation box in the hallway just outside the meditation room.

Wendy Cook has been practicing yoga since 1987 and teaching since 2001. She has been practicing Tibetan Buddhism also since 1987 and is a former Director of Kurukulla Center. www.yesheyoga.com
results.name: Yoga & Meditation with Wendy Cook

group.name: Kurukulla Center for Tibetan Buddhist Studies

results.description:
This Meetup is intended for intermediate level players or higher, which means:Yankee C and above level, players with firm understanding of game strategy. Should be able to play 5-1 and 6-2 formations, have a good grasp of skills (passing, setting, hitting) and be able to move around to cover areas of the court. Play should consistently be bump-set-spike.



If you'd like to play, please do the following:


1. Send an email to Kory using the following URL: http://www.meetup.com/volleyball-122/message/?recipientId=8675200

2. In the message please indicate the date of event and your preferred position so we can make sure we have the right mix. ( If I don't know your position already)

Note that sending an email does not guarantee a spot to play; spots are only guaranteed if you receive a positive confirmation email. We will do our best to make sure the event is co-ed, have setters,  and incorporate a couple new members who want to join as well.

The location for this volleyball meetup is at the Orient Heights Community Center located at 86 Boardman Street in East Boston. Kory and Wing will be hosting these Tuesday night volleyball meetups.

This event is free if you are a member of Boston Community Centers. If not, it's a one-time $20 membership fee that is valid for a year. The Community Center is a short walk away from the Orient Heights T Stop on the Blue Line and also has plenty of parking. When you drive up, turn at the Mariott Hotel Sign and park in the lot or further along the fence.

As always, please remember:

- Respect the RSVP system (Don't show up expecting to play without a confirmed RSVP)

- The gym is open before the event to warm up, so please arrive a little early if you would like to warm up and stretch as we would like to start the game promptly from 7:00PM

- If it looks like you won't be able to make it or will run late please cancel your RSVP in time for someone else to join.  Event day/last minute cancellations and no shows will jeopardize your participation in future events.

results.description:
INSPIRING SOLUTIONS FOR DIFFICULT TIMES                                                                                                     a meditation class series 

TUESDAYS | MARCH 22nd - APRIL 26th


7:00 - 8:30pm

Sometimes life can become overwhelming with difficult and turbulent events. At such times, peace can feel far away. However, just as the center of a hurricane is perfectly still, through meditation we can learn to build a place of peace within. From this inner space, we can make good decisions that foster harmony and happiness for ourself and others.

Join us in this practical course to learn simple and effective meditations for becoming more peaceful and at ease in everyday life. By creating peace within, we can share this with our community, our city and our world. Each class is beginner friendly- feel free to drop-in to any class in the series or try to attend each one!

Feel free to drop-in to any or all of the meditation classes in this series! No need to pre-register. 

with Kadampa Buddhist Teacher, Kyle Davis


Cost | $10 per class / $5 students & seniors.  Members FREE! 

Location | 179 Green Street – Boston, Jamaica Plain, MA 02130  

meditationINboston.org

For more info please call[masked] or email [masked]

Transportation
The Red Line stop for CIC is Kendall. For those who drive, there is a pay parking lot underneath the building, and limited meter parking in the area. Additionally, the MIT Hayward St lot is free after 5pm. Please make sure to check in with security when you arrive.

results.description:
• This is a spiritual meet-up for those interested in Reiki shares and enhancing their practitioners skills. This is also a group for healing others in the community and long distance. 

We welcome those in our community who need and believe in hands-on spiritual healing ONLY at the beginning of each share and as recipients only. 

Each share begins with a Reiki meditation. This is followed by group/community healing - upon request. THOSE WHO ARE FROM THE COMMUNITY AND ARE NOT REIKI PRACTITIONERS and are joining us ONLY because they are suffering from an ailment will be on the tables FIRST for a 20-30 min group treatment and prayers. After treatment, community members can rest as we will be break for refreshments and then will need to quietly leave the space to practitioners only. Please see note below+++ 

Following that, practitioners will break into groups of 2-4 per table for practitioner's only share. The schedule for this meet-up is as follows: 

• 6:45 pm Welcome and table setup 

• 7 pm - 7:30 pm Reiki Angel Meditation, community healing upon request and/or Reiki exercise. 

• 7:30 pm - 8 pm Light refreshments break, intros, goodbyes to community patients (if any) 

• 8:00 pm - 10:00 pm Reiki shares for practitioners only. (Must be attuned through a real RMT not a DVD to participate) 

The short exercises we will be offering for practitioners are different in every meet-up. These methods were used in Japan and the purpose is to enhance your intuition as well as other important breathing exercises.

Community members who are not Reiki practitioners:

 +++Please be advised that we do NOT guarantee or claim to provide any healing or improvement or treatment to your condition. Reiki is a spiritual energy-based practice that may or may not help to provide relief from pain, trauma,  post-cancer treatment, emotional issues, help with addictions and overall wellness. Those seeking relief from the community must email me first before coming in with a real picture on their profile, confirmation they are coming in on time (7 pm), You only need to bring your intent to heal. No need to share your information. You will need to sign a waiver due to the laws of this country. We promise to treat you with respect and dignity in a safe environment where love is abundant.
results.name: SOUL TOUCH REIKI SHARE

Pete Campbell reads The Crying of Lot 49  in Season 5 Episode 8 "Lady Lazarus."  Here's a synopsis of the episode:

http://madmen.wikia.com/wiki/Lady_Lazarus


Women and madness is a theme in this episode as is women and liberation or rebirth. These are also themes in The Crying of Lot 49. This cult classic, published in 1965, also made it to #25 of Time's List of "All Time 100 Novels" published since 1923: 


http://entertainment.time.com/2005/10/16/all-time-100-novels/slide/the-crying-of-lot-49-1966-by-thomas-pynchon/


"Lady Lazarus" is also the title of a poem published by Sylvia Plath in her 1966 collection Ariel:

https://www.poets.org/poetsorg/poem/lady-lazarus


Pete is paired up with The Crying of Lot 49 on this blog:

http://mashable.com/2015/03/05/mad-men-reading-list/#k01HpfNB5Zqc


It might be fun to discuss whether we agree or disagree that this book represents Pete!

results.description:
Please join Laura Howell and the NDF Cambridge Sangha for a session of natural meditation in the Tibetan Buddhist traditions of Dzogchen and Mahamudra. 

Laura has been practicing meditation since 1988 when she began attending retreats led by Baba Ram Dass. In the early 1990’s she became a Dzogchen practitioner and a student of Lama Surya Das. Laura was a practice leader for Cambridge Dzogchen Sangha for many years. She has been a student ofLama Willa Miller since 2008.  Laura resides in North Andover, MA where she is director and meditation teacher for Great Pond Sangha, which she and her husband Brad co-founded in 2004. She is a poet, psychotherapist, homeschooling mother of two sons, active in North Parish Unitarian Universalist Congregation, and especially interested in sharing the Dharma with children and families.


More details and information about our group can be found at the following URL:


http://www.naturaldharma.org

Please note: most of the friends who attend regularly are not Meetup members, so there are always more people attending than are signed up using this web site.

Shamanic Journeying is a tool that has been traditionally used by indigenous shamans for the healing of individuals and communities. Shamans use drums and rattles to shift their consciousness into non-ordinary reality, a trance-like state, to communicate with their helping guides and spirits. We know now that anyone can learn to journey, to connect with their own helping guides and spirits in non- ordinary reality, in order to get answers to personal questions, solve problems, open creativity, see new ways of being in the world and obtain healing information for themselves and their community. Each participate will receive a Shamanic Blessings from Sue.

Please bring something for the alter, a journal and anything you would need to lay down with.

CALL, EMAIL OR TEXT Sue for information and registration:

[masked]

Every 2nd and 4th Tuesday of each month

Cost: $35

 Angelo created Shamanic Spirit Song over the past 10 years blending her natural intuitive gifts with her training as a Shamanic and Energy practitioner. Sue studies and practices Native America, Peruvian, and West Africa Traditions of Shamanism. She is certified by the Rhys Thomas Institute of Energy Medicine and is a certified Reiki Master. She worked in women’s health care for 30 years.

results.description:
An evening of meditation practice, led by Rev. Kim K. Crawford Harvie, Senior Minister. Sessions include seated & walking meditation, Dharma talk, and conversation. This practice is open to all, beginning and experience practitioners.

The warm, inviting evening includes two short seated meditations; walking meditation through the gorgeous Arlington Street Church sanctuary and Public Garden; and community discussion.

Rev. Kim K. Crawford Harvie is an extraordinary and inspired leader in the LGBTQ community. She is founder of The Shared Heart, a traveling exhibition and book of photographs of lesbian, gay, bisexual, and transgender teenagers, designed to support the Massachusetts Safe Schools Initiative. The Legacy Foundation named Rev. Crawford Harvie Uncommon Woman of the Year. The Women's Educational and Industrial Union of Boston honored her as one of 100 outstanding women in the Commonwealth. She is recipient of the Maximilian Kolbe Award for Community Service and was named Provincetown Citizen of the Year. In 2004, she performed the first same-sex wedding in a church in the United States.

Rev. Kim has been a Zen Buddhist practitioner since 1977.

For more information on the evening: Arlington Street Zen Center

Prior to the ASZC at 7:00 pm, you are also warmly invited to join the Buddha's Belly Book Group at 6:00 pm in the Hunnewell Chapel. Check out the ASC website for information on what book the Buddhas Belly group is currently reading.

results.description:
Two PyCon-bound speakers will rehearse their talks, sponsored by MassMutual. David Baumgold: Prototyping new APIs with Flask

You need to build a new API, but which tools do you use? Flask is a microframework that makes web development a snap, and an ecosystem of extensions and other tools has grown around it to make it perfect for prototyping APIs. In this talk, we'll see how to get started with Flask, and learn the best parts of its ecosystem for API development. More info...

Scott Sanderson & Joe Jevnik: Playing with Python Bytecode

Ever wondered what Python is actually doing when it executes your code? Want to learn to hand-craft artisanal Python bytecode? In this talk, we explain CPython's internal code representation, and we demonstrate techniques for modifying code objects for fun and profit. More info...


Pizza will be provided.

Because these are rehearsals, we will not be recording.  You'll be able to see the recording from the actual presentation given at PyCon.
results.name: PyCon Rehearsals 1: Flask APIs, and Bytecode
