results.description:
Merchants of Doubt

MIT Science for the People and Radius present a film screening and discussion of Merchants of Doubt

Tuesday | April 26 | 7:30pm

MIT - Room[masked]  

A screening of the documentary Merchants of Doubt, inspired by the book of the same name. The film examines the use of a PR tactic in developing relationships with scientists and others who convincingly cast doubt on scientific research and evidence. This tactic, first used by the tobacco industry, successfully delayed federal regulation for years; long after the health risks of smoking had been proven. The film then connects to the current tactics stalling governmental action to regulate greenhouse gasses that are contributing to global climate change and other issues we face.
results.name: Merchants of Doubt

results.description:
Meditation practice gives us a chance to step away from the busy-ness of our day-to-day lives. It provides space for us to be free from reaction, from expectation, from doing, and step into the gentle space of being.

This weekly practice consists of 25-30 minutes of guided Vipassana meditation followed by a brief discussion. Vipassana meditation encourages us to experience each moment exactly how it is, fostering presence and awareness.

In this practice we allow thoughts, emotions, and all other stimuli to surface. We become a witness of these, cultivating a space of non-attachment and revealing a deeper connection with one's inner self.

Newcomers to meditation and long-time practitioners are welcome to attend. This is a FREE practice. There is a suggested donation, but that is not required to attend.

results.name: Mindfulness Meditation

results.description:
Hello and welcome to another edition of the Manga Club! I hope you’re ready for something special because we are bringing back an old favorite! 

Last year, we held a special event where, instead of reading a particular title or titles together, the membership was able to debate their favorite title from past selections. This event had the potential to be a major disaster, but you came together and kept it clean. Even better, you kept it fun and enjoyable! Therefore, we are going to run this event again!
For those of you who were not here last year, we are going to use the following rules. For those of you who were here please review said rules due to a few minor adjustments.

1. One person can select one title. This is done by signing up for the event and then providing your title selection in the comments below. Once a title is selected, no one else may do so, so RSVP today!

2. One of the issues that we have run into is the amount of material covered, so after selecting a title you may read and discuss up to two additional volumes of that title than we covered in the group.

3. If you haven’t liked any of the titles listed below, then pick the one you hated the most and be prepared to figuratively rip it apart!

4. To prevent a possible blood bath, I am EXCLUDING the titles previously selected for this event last year, our light novel selection, as well as Naruto and Dragon Ball from the Anniversary Special. Let’s try something new.

5. As the coordinator of this group, I will select last, just to make things fair.

If you need copies of a title, the venue still has a whole bunch of them left over from earlier meetings. Just call ahead at (617)[masked], and check, and they should be happy to put one aside for you. Otherwise, I have not forgotten that Anime Boston was last month, so there should be plenty of opportunity to purchase titles there. 

So let’s get ready to defend our favorite manga!

Akira volume 1 - Joshua D. Altobelli

results.description:
Ongoing class in Medieval and Renaissance Longsword in the tradition of Johannes Lichtenauer.


The Longsword is the iconic fantasy Knight's sword - a two-handed, straight blade with a cross guard. The weapon may seem to be simple at first but is in reality a weapon of finesse and skill.


The class covers all the basics of footwork, attacks and defenses. Drills are developed from simple to complex; from rigidly choreographed to open-ended. Timing, distance and judgement are developed.


All classes begin with a Strength & Conditioning program designed to physically prepare one for fighting with the sword. Elements develop agility, core stability and power.
results.name: Lichtenauer Longsword

This is an interactive, online event that you can participate in from your computer. To join and get the access link, you must register at https://fifiteast.splashthat.com/  

----

With so much uncertainty, and so many questions to answer, validating your startup ideas can be overwhelming. Justin Wilcox, one of Founder Institute's most popular and highly rated mentors, has spent the last 18 months solving this problem. 

Combining the best of Customer Development, Design Thinking, Lean Startup, and Growth Hacking, Justin's "FOCUS Framework" (http://j.mp/_F0CUS) lays out an actionable path to validating your startup ideas, and achieving "Product-Market Fit." 

On this interactive online workshop, Justin will guide you through a step-by-step process to outline your ideas, test your riskiest assumptions, and run valid startup experiments to find your Product-Market Fit.

You'll leave the workshop with a clear, actionable, next step - and a practical strategy for finding your Product-Market Fit.

Don't miss this opportunity to participate in a unique, interactive online workshop! RSVP today at https://fifiteast.splashthat.com/ ;

results.description:
NUTSHELL - every week day, 12:15ish until 1:45ish, Cumnock Turf Fields at Harvard Stadium, games of 4v4 up to 10v10 or larger depending on who shows, bring a white shirt and a dark/colored shirt (but not a gray one), almost never canceled, read below for more details before asking questions that are answered here, and read the comments for today's meetup to see if there is anything important about today.

http://goo.gl/I0tPQQ

GETTING THERE BY PUBLIC TRANSPORT - Harvard Square is the closest T stop (red line).  Check Google Maps or other to find fastest way there from wherever you are.

GETTING THERE BY RIDE SHARE - a lot of players in this meetup come by car and are nice enough to offer rides to others. Best hope of getting a ride is leaving a comment here asking if anybody is driving and willing to pick you up.

PARKING - you must park at one of the metered spots if you park on Harvard property near the stadium.  They will patrol for cars parked illegally.

COST - free while we play outdoors.

ATTIRE - Bring a *white* shirt and a dark/vivid color shirt so we can easily divide into teams.  DO NOT BRING A GRAY SHIRT- you will annoy a lot of people if you do. Turf shoes or cleats recommended, and sneakers are fine.  Shin-guards optional- most people don't wear them. Bring a ball if you have one.

RSVP and CANCELING - the sooner you RSVP, the better.  That said, most people don't RSVP until around 10:30am the day of the meetup, so we make the call around 11:15am the day of the meetup about whether a game needs to be canceled.  Check here right before heading over.

ETIQUETTE - we have A LOT of players in this meetup and play every (week)day. Each day is a different mix of people, skill levels, and attitudes.  Most people playing do this for fun and/or exercise in the middle of the day.  Please respect this by at least following these unspoken rules that we have:

1) You may not hurt anybody- especially yourself. All of us just want to safely return to the office/class afterward.

2) Do not yell at, criticize, or offer unsolicited "tips" to other players unless they ask for your opinion. It ruins an otherwise fun, all-skill-levels game. If you do this often, you may be asked to find another meetup.

3) Be the first to get the ball if it goes out of bounds. Especially if you kicked it last or are the closest one to the ball. 

4) Fighting is prohibited. We've never come close to having a problem with this, but better stated aloud. If it gets physical, we may call the police as it becomes a felony/legal matter.

WHAT ELSE - All skill levels welcome- it's a big mix. While these are general guidelines, always read the comments section for the latest updates for today's meetup.
results.name: Wednesday Lunchtime Soccer (OUTDOOR)

results.description:
Join NetCom Learning trainer, Audrey Halpern, along with Managed Learning Services leader NetCom Learning for a complimentary webinar on "Transitioned to Manager, Now What?" 

Date: 04/27/2016

Time: 1 P.M. Eastern Standard Time/ 10 A.M. Pacific Standard Time


Agenda:

If you have recently gotten promoted to a more managerial position in my company, and are nervous about making the transition, especially since you will be managing your former friends and co-workers. here are some tips for a managerial first-timer

» Learn about the role and the differences between leader and manager.
» Learn about working along side your peers in your new role.
» Learn about the appearance of favoritism, what to do and what not to do.
» Learn about building relationships and building trust in order to get through your team goals.
» Q&A with Audrey.

  To receive the link for the Virtual Meetup, REGISTER HERE

Please note that in addition to RSVP'ing to this Meetup, you must register to get access by clicking the register button above.
results.name: Virtual Meetup: Transitioned to Manager, Now What?

results.description:
Do you VEGETABLE-TARIANS want all the OTHER people (even if they have not committed to be vegetarians) to eat fresh produce?  Then help us - each Wednesday late afternoon - bag vegetables (and some fruit) for the neighbors in Mission Hill.  Usually there are also freshly-baked loaves of bread, also (baked that morning - Jessica's Bakery).

It's an assembly line, then take home a bag (or two) of produce for yourself. 


Bring your business cards, smartphone, or notepad, and prepare to exchange contact info with other volunteers you like.  Volunteers come from several sources (not merely this meetup or others:Craigslist, Pharmacy School, School of Public Health, etc.) 

~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~
VOLUNTEERING for $2/bag of produce in Mission Hill
Tobin Community Center, 1481 Tremont Street
Mission Hill, Roxbury
(between Brigham Circle and Roxbury Crossing T stops)
Boston, MA 02120 - <2 blocks from Orange Line T Each Wednesday, from 4:00 - 6:00 pm (indoors in bad weather)

We will be VOLUNTEERING for the weekly Wednesday late afternoon $2/bag of produce in Mission Hill.

When you volunteer,
YOU will ALSO TAKE HOME one or two of those "$2 bags"!
We've had 55 volunteers, and we've had 7.  Workloads vary!

Fair Foods provides a 20-22 bag of produce for the Mission Hill neighbors so they can eat like me - on produce. The neighbors only need to pay' $2 for the bag.

Volunteers unload the truck, set up 3 banquet tables, set up the food in order of desntiy (potatoes on bottom - tomatoes and bananas and berries and kale on top), then fill each bag (and 'stack' them upright by one another - for the 'paying neighbors' to pick up (for $2).


We arrive around 4 pm (maybe as late as 4:30 pm) and work until 6 pm (can leave as early as 5:30 pm if we've finished).

In the FRONT of the Tobin Community Center, 1481 Tremont Street (between the Brigham Circle T stop - GREEN E-Line - and the Roxbury Crossing Orange Line T stop), behind the wrought iron fence.

Wear comfortable clothing that allows you to move flexibly and to actually work, lifting heavy bags of food. 
~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~ 
Tobin Community Center 
1481 Tremont Street, Boston, MA

THERE IS NO PARKING - IT'S BEST FOR THOSE WHO LIVE IN BOSTON AND TRAVEL IN ON THE MBTA

THERE IS NO PARKING IN THE NEIGHBORHOOD

Every Wednesday, from 4:00 - 6:00 pm 
~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~ 
Bring friends!  Forward the invitation to others!

Invite FRIENDS through the Facebook, LinkedIn, and Twitter 'share'
buttons
http://www.yelp.com/events/boston-volunteering-for-2-bag-of-produce-in-mission-hill-each-wednesday-afternoon-from-4-6-pm-at-tobin-community-center

Looking for an ARTIST to help VISUALLY REPRESENT this vegetable outreach effort. 
TALK with us FIRST !!

Looking for Gifted Marketers to 
(i) conceptualize the WHY of low cost vegetable distribution! and 
(ii) the desirability of TAKING the low cost vegetables !!

LOGISTICAL CHALLENGE IS TO GET LOW COST VEGETABLES to the REFRIGERATORS of LOCAL RESIDENTS !!!

~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~ 
Vegan Cooking classes or Vegan Cooking Ideas

Vegan Cooking Classes or  
Learning How to Prepare Vegan Food
(using the $2 bag of produce as a low-cost start) 


What Can You Do With Your $2 Bag?

Portion Control

Bake...Don't Fry!

Roasted Veggie Stackers

No-Guilt Banana Ice Cream

Avocados!!!

Salad with Chipotle Hummus

Simple Cilantro Chutney

More $2 bags of Produce!

Drink your greens!

SYNOPSIS:

Keegan-Michael Key and Jordan Peele, a.k.a. the hugely popular comedy duo Key & Peele, star as Clarence and Rell, two cousins who live in the city but are far from streetwise. When Rell’s beloved kitten, Keanu, is catnapped, the hopelessly straight-laced pair must impersonate ruthless killers in order to infiltrate a street gang and retrieve the purloined feline. But the incredibly adorable kitten becomes so coveted that the fight over his custody creates a gang war, forcing our two unwitting heroes to take the law into their own hands.

results.description:
This is when we put all our skills into practice. We'll pair up and make progress on our life's goals or difficulties. Each person will have approximately 25 minutes to think through any issue of their choosing with a partner on hand to listen and ask good questions. I hope to see you there!

Our usual schedule is 


• 5:30-6pm Welcome everyone and discuss progress  on goals from last week. Order drinks and appetizers or dinner. 


• 6-7:00pm Focused discussion and work on our topic for the week. In addition to discussion of the theory, we really want to do exercises and make progress on real problems.


• 7-7:30pm Conclude and set individual goals for next meeting 


• 7:30-... Chat, mingle and leave whenever

Please bring something to write with and on.
results.how_to_find_us: We usually reserve a table in the back left. It should be easy to find.
results.name: Wednesday Workshop: Peer Debugging

results.description:
Who should join: Beginners to Advanced speakers interested in learning how to improve their public speaking for fun or professionally.  Reduce your fear and increase your confidence.


Why  members should join: Learn the basics of public speaking, challenge your current skills to be a professional speaker or just to have fun & meet interesting people.  You will also be challenged to give more challenging types of speeches such as ice breakers, humorous and inspirational speeches.

What members can expect out of the group: We have a fast paced 1 hour meeting packed with 2 prepared speeches from members as well as Table Topics where anyone is invited to speak on a suggested topic for 1-2 minutes to hone their ability to speak off the cuff.


You can also join our mentorship program and be assigned an advanced speaker who will guide you to improving your skills.

Lead meetings and presentations at work, begin your path to being a better teacher or professional paid public speaker or simply be a better storyteller.

Tuesday 12pm meeting for members and guests. Please visit for free! 

All are welcome.
results.how_to_find_us: Clarendon street entrance. Ask the desk attendant for directions to room.
results.name: Attend a free meeting as a guest and consider joining!

results.description:
Wanna try us out? Come join us at our water training sessions! No prior experience necessary. 

• First two practices are $10 (The $10 can go towards the full membership of $110 for the rest of the season). Pay via Paypal ("Boston 1 - Join us") or venmo (@boston1dboat).</a>

• Also you will not be allowed on the boats if you do not sign the waiver: <a href="https://docs.google.com/forms/d/1Ll2NR3MZbV3O7ZrmPdZsCbKRaC_G8KKa7lwBUlC59Pk/viewform?c=0&w=1">"Boston 1 e-waiver" 

• Make sure to check our Facebook,</a><a href="http://bit.ly/Boston1facebook">http://bit.ly/Boston1facebook for practice announcements and cancellations -- especially in the early and later parts of season with potentially colder night practices. 

Weekly practices are every Monday, Wednesday and Saturday unless a race is scheduled or practice is cancelled.

Mon & Wed: 5:45pm - 8pm, meet 5.45pm on the grassy patch near the Barking Crab. 
Sat: 10:45am - 1pm, meet 10.45am on the grassy patch near the Barking Crab.

Optional dinner/lunch or social activity afterwards!

Outdoor paddling means exposure to the weather and water! Be prepared to get wet!

• Clothing: Wear workout clothes, synthetic fibers that dry quickly are highly recommended. Bring dry clothes to change into afterwards. 

• Footwear: Sandals or flip flops recommended. Some people go barefoot. Shoes and socks are not recommended. 

• Other: Bring plenty of water and sunscreen. Expensive glasses or sunglasses are not recommended. 

All paddling equipment is provided (paddles, pfds). Locked locker provided on-site. Please bring as little as possible to practice as space is limited.

In the event of inclement weather, announcements will be made through the comments area of each meetup event, also in Twitter, Facebook and email alerts.

Sign up for our weekly emails and email alerts

Twitter: @Boston1Dboat

Facebook: http://bit.ly/Boston1facebook

Parking: Channelside Parking at 284 A Street. Enter at 29-41 Necco Street, off Melcher Street. Weekend $5 flat rate. Weekdays $8 flat rate (in after 3pm). More details can be found here: http://bit.ly/1Nxv1lw.

Restroom: Do not use the restrooms in the Barking Crab, use the public restrooms near the Daily Catch

Public Transport: Closest T stop is South Station on the red line.

Hope to see you there!

results.description:
I wanted to pass along some information about a program that AARP does. Eileen and I heard about this at the Best Years Expo last year and it seems to be a good fit with what this meetup group is about. It's FREE but you have to register in advance...and I haven't heard back if there are still openings.  This is being done again the morning of May 11th.  Below is a description from AARP:

At AARP, “real possibilities” means that anything is possible and that age doesn’t define people. In fact, we believe that age and experience can expand—not limit - possibilities. Figuring out those possibilities is where AARP’s Life Reimagined program comes in! Life Reimagined is like a personalized guidance system. You start where you are in your life, and— through a series of fun, simple exercises—see where the possibilities lead you. The free program, called a “Checkup,” includes six practices that guide you through making a change: Reflect, Connect, Explore, Choose, Repack, and Act. It’s fun, it’s contemplative, and it’s a great way to begin the process of discovering your own, personal “What’s Next?” moment or path.

Life Reimagined Check-up: This popular, engaging event is like a personalized guidance
system for life transitions. It’s fun, it’s contemplative, and it’s a great way to begin the process of discovering your own personal “What’s Next?” moment or path. You start where you are in your life, and—through a series of fun, simple exercises—see where the possibilities lead you.

What is Life Reimagined?

Life Reimagined is a new way of thinking about what's next in your life. Backed by decades of research, Life Reimagined introduces a powerful step-by-step approach to help you discover possibilities, prepare for change, and make your ideas real - whether you're focused on work, health, relationships, or finally pursuing your passion. When you find yourself wondering, "What's next?" Life Reimagined empowers you with guidance, tools, and connections, both online and in person, to plan your next move.
results.name: Life Reimagined workshop

results.description:
Free. Fun. Starts here!

Welcome to the Marlborough Couch to 5K sponsored by ConnectingPoint Church. We love people in our community. We've helped over 400 people get off the couch and start jogging!


We have 2 groups: 

 1. Our Jogging Group has a goal of jogging a 5K. 

 2. Our Alumni Jogging Group has a goal of keep jogging for those who have jogged at least once season with us. 

We introduce people to jogging and getting fit. The program gradually moves you from walking at your own pace to jogging at your own pace. 

• FREE 10-week program to get you from the couch to running a 5K (3.1 miles) 

• Anyone from the community can participate

• Led by experienced runners 

• Monday through Thursdays 6pm-6:45pm; Sundays 8am-8:45am, with a goal of joining us 3 of these sessions per week 

• 45 minute time commitment

• Goal of jogging and finishing the Sprit of Hudson 5K in June 

Encourage those you love to get “off the couch” and join you in the great sport of running. Come have some fun! Bring a water bottle and join the group. 

Please arrive 15 minutes early the first night, so we can explain what you'll be doing on the Rail Trail, stretching out, etc.


 Please consult your doctor if you have a health or medical condition that prevents you from exercising. 

For more information please visit http://www.connectingpointchurch.org/couchto5k/

https://youtu.be/OndSmceU9R4

Spring is around the corner.  We ran this program with great success the last few years.  This is for members with little or no experience that want to take a "swing" at learning and playing golf.

THIS YEAR YOU NEED TO CALL THE GOLF COURSE[masked] GOLF SHOP, TELL THEM YOU ARE WITH SUE'S NORTH SHORE WOMEN'S GROUP ....YOU MAKE PAYMENT TO THEM DIRECTLY.  YOUR SPOT IS ONLY SECURED ONCE YOU MAY PAYMENT!

Do the math ladies that is $20/per lesson!!!!

FIRST COME FIRST SERVE!!! (with secured payment to the golf club!)

Wednesday's, Starting on April 27th 6pm (for 5 weeks)

Hillview Golf Course is a regulation 18-hole golf course that is town owned by North Reading and managed by Golf Facilities Management, Inc. Hillview is a course where players of all levels will have a wonderful golfing experience, challenging for the expert and playable for the beginner. The player friendly course plays to 5773 yards from the blue tees, 5290 from the white tees, and 4521 from the red tee markers at which par is 69. Golfers will feel comfortable off the tee and will be challenged with their approach shots requiring precise shots into the greens.

In recent years, Hillview has undergone many extensive renovations. These renovations have improved course conditions, pace of play and the overall golfing experience at Hillview Golf Course. These renovations include many new greens, tees, and fairway landing areas. These projects funded by The Hillview Commission, have made Hillview Golf Course one of the best and affordable golfing experiences in the area. Come out and give us a try!

Instructors:  (we will have one)

Directions

Hillview Golf Course is located at 149 North Street, North Reading, MA 01864

From Rt. 93: Take exit 40 (Rt. 62 East), Follow for 1.5 miles, Take left onto North St., Follow for 1 mile through set of lights, Hillview will be on your left.

From Rt. 128: Take exit 40 (Rt. 129 North Reading), Take first right from rotary (Haverhill St.), Follow for approx. 5 miles, At Stop sign take left onto Rt. 62 West, Follow for .5 miles, Take right onto Central St., Follow for approx. 2 miles, At stop sign take left onto North Street., Hillview will be on your right.

results.description:
Plan is to follow the Rock Circuit Trail from the Flynn Rink to Fellsway East, then coming back the same way or returning via the Cross Fells Trail, depending on the will of the group.

Parts of the Rock Circuit Trail can be challenging for some intermediate hikers. The pace will be set by the slower members of the group. Safety first.

Length: About 3.0 miles. Duration: Approximately 1.5-2 hours. However, any time estimate given by an Event Organizer is just that. Actual times vary greatly according to weather, trail conditions and the group itself. Don't sign up if you've scheduled something later in the day.The Organizer is not responsible for getting you back in time.There is no way of knowing trail conditions ahead of time. Use your own judgment.

This hike is rated intermediate. That means you should be able to stay with the group over an extended distance going up a moderately steep gradient at a pace of 2.5 MPH.This is a group event and participants are expected to follow the lead, stay together, stop at junctions or summits, and support all participants should circumstances require teamwork. We start together and finish together. If you decide to leave the group at any time, you are on your own. We hike in light rain or showers, but heavy snow or extreme cold weather cancels.

Bring water, hiking boots (not sneakers), and lunch/snacks. Protect yourself against deer ticks and dress in layers. If you are a beginner hiker, read Basic Hiking Clothing and Gear You’ll Need: in the Pages section before you show up. If you are unprepared, you will not be allowed on the hike.

Anyone with recurrent "No Shows" or about whom we have received complaints from fellow hikers will not be accepted. Please don't RSVP "Yes" unless you really intend to come. Don't sign up for this and another event being held at the same time.We are committed to being there for you. If you are not equally committed to being there then please don't sign up. People who repeatedly fail to show up for events to which they have RSVPed “Yes” will be dropped from the group. People who repeatedly drop out at the last minute may be removed from the Attending list at the Event Host’s discretion.

No dogs and no guests are allowed on hikes. Have your guest join the group so they can agree to the liability waiver and attend an event. Please don't ask; there are no exceptions.

Please remember that your Event Organizers are volunteers, the event is free and we are all adults. The people who have the best times on these hikes are those who stay loose and roll with things as they happen. If you are expecting Daniel Boone as your leader, you’re barking up the wrong tree. If you need everything to run perfectly, this hike is not for you.

By clicking the "Yes" option on the RSVP link you are agreeing to the Liability Waiver as stated below

Remember: Your Event Organizers are volunteers. You are solely responsible for your own safety and enjoyment. As a condition of your voluntary participation in this activity you acknowledge and agree to the following: this activity involves inherent risks that can cause property damage, injury, illness, disability, and/or death to participants and/or others; you assume all risk associated with this activity; you are responsible for having the necessary knowledge, skills, abilities, clothing, and equipment to safely participate in this activity; you have read and agree to adhere to the safety standards detailed @http://www.hikesafe.com/; the organizer(s) of this activity is a volunteer; and you for yourself, your heirs, executors, and administrators release, hold harmless, and indemnify organizer(s) and all members of this group from any and all claims for property damage, injury, illness, disability, and/or death - including those caused by negligence and/or other reason.

If you want to carpool, put a message in the comment section. To respond, please send that person a direct message by clicking on their profile picture on the right and then clicking the "Message" link in the upper left hand corner.

results.description:
EVENT LOCATION CHANGED TO SAL'S IN WOBURN

The first book we will be reading and discussing is "To Heaven and Back" by Mary C. Neil, MD.   It is 220 pages but a smaller size book, we will review this book in its entirety.

There are many copies of this book available at the local libraries.

I ask that you have read some of the material to attend the book review.

Below is a brief summary:

There is no charge for the room, with that being said please only rsvp if you can make the event.

We will need a minimum of 5 for the meetup to be held.  This event may be cross posted in other meetups.

In 1999 in the Los Rios region of southern Chile, orthopedic surgeon, devoted wife, and loving mother Dr. Mary Neal drowned in a kayak accident. While cascading down a waterfall, her kayak became pinned at the bottom and she was immediately and completely submerged. Despite the rescue efforts of her companions, Mary was underwater for too long, and as a result, died.

To Heaven and Back


 is Mary’s remarkable story of her life’s spiritual journey and what happened as she moved from life to death to eternal life, and back again. Detailing her feelings and surroundings in heaven, her communication with angels, and her deep sense of sadness when she realized it wasn’t her time, Mary shares the captivating experience of her modern-day miracle. 

This meetup maybe cross posted in other meetups.

Please no fragrances are we have members with allergies.


Same day cancellations will be marked as no shows.

PLEASE BE SURE TO PURCHASE SOMETHING FROM THE RESTAURANT, THEY ALLOW US TO HAVE OUR EVENTS HERE AT NO COST FOR THE ROOM AND WE WOULD LIKE THAT TO CONTINUE.  THANKS:)
results.how_to_find_us: party room in back at SAL'S PIZZA
results.name: Book Review:  To Heaven & Back  by Mary c. Neil MD

results.description:
Please join us for an evening dedicated to two of the most important issues one faces when going through divorce or separation, as well as afterwards: asset division and estate planning. Mick Judge, Divorce Attorney, and Dave Raymon, Trust & Estate Planning Attorney, from Burns & Levinson LLP will provide an overview of the divorce process, explain equitable division of assets, and discuss essential pre and post-divorce estate planning techniques. 

Attorneys Judge and Raymon will cover:

I.  Basics of Divorce

     a.  Overview of process/basic legal concepts of divorce

     b.  Property division/equitable division of assets

II.  Estate Planning Techniques for Divorcing Spouses

     a.  Prenuptial agreements

     b.  Child support/alimony trusts

III.  Estate Planning Techniques for Parents Of Divorcing Spouses

     a.  Treatment of inherited assets in divorce

     b.  Pitfalls of no planning or improper planning

     c.  How estate planning (particularly trusts) can help to avoid pitfalls

     d.  Dos and don’ts of using trusts for divorce planning (Pfannenstiehl, etc.)

IV.  Post-Divorce Estate Planning

     a.  Beneficiary designations

RSVP to reserve your seat as space is limited. If you prefer not to RSVP through meetup, you may RSVP directly to Deanna at[masked] or [masked]. There is no cost for attendance and complimentary refreshments & snacks will be provided for your enjoyment throughout the event.

Click this link for more information on Attorney Judge: http://www.burnslev.com/our-attorneys/michael-judge

Click here for more information on Attorney Raymon:  http://www.burnslev.com/our-attorneys/david-raymon

Directions: If you are taking public transportation, 125 Summer Street is located just a few blocks away from both South Station and Downtown Crossing. If you are driving, you can park in the parking garage of 125 Summer Street. Enter the parking garage at 30 Lincoln Street. Bring your parking ticket with you to Burns & Levinson (where you check into the seminar on the 8th floor) and you can pay $10 (cash or check) to receive a voucher for parking.
results.how_to_find_us: Garage parking is available at 125 Summer Street (enter the garage at 30 Lincoln Street) for a discounted rate of $10. Burns & Levinson is located on the 8th floor. Please call/text Deanna at 508-333-3191 with questions or for directions.
results.name: The Do's and Don'ts of Asset Division and Estate Planning Pre and Post-Divorce

results.description:
Helbling presents its first Visionary Series event of 2016!  

Join us for an evening with Windgap Medical, the local startup building a new drug delivery device for people with severe allergies.

Bringing a combination product to market is tough, but big rewards come to those that can offer alternatives to the status quo. By focusing on improving patient experience and outcomes, Windgap Medical has developed a miniature, easy to use, heat-stable alternative to the EpiPen®, addressing a pressing need in a growing, $1B market.

Schedules permitting, we will have all four principals of Windgap Medical sharing the story of their founding, their product development approach, and lessons learned along the way. It should be a very entertaining and enlightening evening.

IMPORTANT: Cambridge Innovation Center (CIC) is a secured facility, so you will need to check in at the security desk on the first floor. Please bring a photo ID. results.description:
Please join us for an evening dedicated to two of the most important issues one faces when going through divorce or separation, as well as afterwards: asset division and estate planning. Mick Judge, Divorce Attorney, and Dave Raymon, Trust & Estate Planning Attorney, from Burns & Levinson LLP will provide an overview of the divorce process, explain equitable division of assets, and discuss essential pre and post-divorce estate planning techniques. 

Attorneys Judge and Raymon will cover:

I.  Basics of Divorce

     a.  Overview of process/basic legal concepts of divorce

     b.  Property division/equitable division of assets

II.  Estate Planning Techniques for Divorcing Spouses

     a.  Prenuptial agreements

     b.  Child support/alimony trusts

III.  Estate Planning Techniques for Parents Of Divorcing Spouses

     a.  Treatment of inherited assets in divorce

     b.  Pitfalls of no planning or improper planning

     c.  How estate planning (particularly trusts) can help to avoid pitfalls

     d.  Dos and don’ts of using trusts for divorce planning (Pfannenstiehl, etc.)

IV.  Post-Divorce Estate Planning

     a.  Beneficiary designations

RSVP to reserve your seat as space is limited. If you prefer not to RSVP through meetup, you may RSVP directly to Deanna at[masked] or [masked]. There is no cost for attendance and complimentary refreshments & snacks will be provided for your enjoyment throughout the event.

Click this link for more information on Attorney Judge: http://www.burnslev.com/our-attorneys/michael-judge

Click here for more information on Attorney Raymon:  http://www.burnslev.com/our-attorneys/david-raymon

Directions: If you are taking public transportation, 125 Summer Street is located just a few blocks away from both South Station and Downtown Crossing. If you are driving, you can park in the parking garage of 125 Summer Street. Enter the parking garage at 30 Lincoln Street. Bring your parking ticket with you to Burns & Levinson (where you check into the seminar on the 8th floor) and you can pay $10 (cash or check) to receive a voucher for parking.
results.how_to_find_us: Garage parking is available at 125 Summer Street for a discounted rate of $10. Enter the parking garage at 30 Lincoln Street. Burns & Levinson is located on the 8th floor. Please call/text Deanna at 508-333-3191 with questions or for directions.

results.description:
Hello ASL Enthusiasts!

A number of folks living NORTH of Boston have asked about an ASL SOCIAL. Let's make this happen!

On WEDNESDAYS, starting October 29 - 6pm to 8pm - I / we will be at the NORTH SHORE MALL Food Court.

While technology has improved the way people communicate, "Deaf Social Clubs" are slowly disappearing. This is a way to start bringing REAL social interaction back!

Please join us for a casual, relaxed, no-pressure two-hour Social, where we can chat, tell stories, get to know each other, and meet new people (or old friends!). Friends, Fun and Food!

A warm welcome is extended to all Deaf & non-Deaf people: folks in the Deaf Community, CODA's, Interpreters, ASL students, parents of deaf children AND their children, ASL professors/teachers, Relay Operators, Deaf services workers- EVERYONE!

This will be a "SOME ASL KNOWLEDGE and ABOVE" Social, because not all of us are ASL-fluent! "Voices- Off" -- we'll all laugh & learn WITH and FROM each other!

WHAT: ASL SOCIAL CLUB
WHERE: North Shore Mall Food Court, PEABODY,MA
DAY/TIME: Wednesdays, 6pm - 8pm
WHY: To meet like-minded people, socialize using ASL, tell stories, and have good time!
WHO: Anyone who wants to chat using American Sign Language!
HOW TO FIND US:  We'll be sitting on the couches closest to the "walkway" side of the Food Court, not hidden inside the food court, so easier to locate us!

If you have any question, please contact Connie or Paul I., through the EMAIL LINK via BOSTON ASL profile page.

PLEASE, if you would be good enough, RSVP either "YES" or "NO" so I know who to look for!

CHEERS!

Paul I.

PEACE...
results.why: ASL is the third largest "foreign language" in the U.S.; ASL is fun to use; ASL is NOT English, but does "borrow" from the English language.

Welcome back to the Cash Game Island, where the blinds are .25/.50 and the game is dealer's choice or no limit holdem. There is no minimum buyin and the max is 400 bb ($200.) There is no rake, tipping, donation, or seat fee. House rules are posted below:

If it's your first time at one of my games RSVP on meetup then text, email, or call to confirm your RSVP and receive the address. If you RSVP and no-show without changing your RSVP, then you have likely taken a seat from someone else, made me very sad, and I put your name on the shit list. Don't do it. If you're running late I appreciate hearing from you.  Doors open at 6, and if you havent arrived or contacted me about running late by 6:30 I will begin offering seats to the waitlist.  I reserve the right to cancel the game if we can't get enough players.


-1 chip=call

-Verbally declared actions are binding

-No string bets or splashed pots

-Don't discuss hands as they are ongoing. Talking about hands or action is allowed only are when heads up, and only by the 2 players remaining in the pot.

-Hands must remain on table or not more than 12 inches from the edge of the table and must be visible to all players.

-Everyone makes mistakes but strive to pay attention so you act in turn in a timely fashion.

-Cut-off shuffles

About the class

This class series is an introduction to the popular, open source programming language Ruby. 

Ruby is an incredible language to use when learning to program! It’s easy to get up and running, and learning ruby is the first step to learning Ruby on Rails, a rich and powerful framework used to build web applications. 

In this class, you will learn to: 

• Get started with Ruby

• Understand the Ruby development environment

• Learn the basics of ruby

• Learn the basics of object oriented programming

• Discover how to debug errors


Schedule

4 class sessions:

• Wednesday, April 27: 6:30-8:30

• Wednesday, May 4: 6:30-8:30

• Wednesday, May 11: 6:30-8:30


• Wednesday, May 18: 6:30-8:30



Tech Requirements

• Your laptop. You need to have a working wifi connection and a modern browser. (Chrome, Safari, or Firefox)

• Power cord for your laptop

Teachers

This class will be taught by Amanda Muñoz and Sean Kelly.

Financial Need

A limited number of scholarships are available for those with a financial hardship. To apply, click here. Scholarship applicants will be notified shortly after the deadline. Class capacity does not impact scholarship students. Check out this info sheet about getting course fees covered by your employer.

results.description:
Bob Crovella joined NVIDIA in 1998 and leads a technical team that is responsible for supporting GPU Computing Products. Prior to joining NVIDIA, Bob worked in various engineering positions at Honeywell and Kodak, and holds an MEng from Rensselaer Polytechnic in Signal Processing.

His talk will start with a brief introduction to why GPUs are helpful when training deep neural networks. He will then discuss the software offerings from NVIDIA, namely cuDNN and DIGITS from the perspective of how they fit together with frameworks like Caffe, Torch, and Theano. Finally, he'll run through a demonstration of how to productively build models using AWS EC2 instances.
results.name: GPU Accelerated Learning

results.description:
The book is The Unfinished Life of Addison Stone by Adele Griffin.


This book club has covered a lot of ground, but one area that hasn’t been touched much yet is the mystery genre.

Addison Stone was a young and dynamic artist until one night she fell from the Manhattan Bridge. Was it an accident? Suicide? Something more sinister?

Blending narrative prose with newspaper articles describing Addison's career and death as well as interviews with family and friends, Griffin tells a fascinating tale of self-destructive genius.

A twist on the who-dun-it with an experimental style.

The venue is Pho Hoa in Chinatown, a reasonably priced Vietnamese restaurant with a nice, round table and a quieter atmosphere.
results.name: The Unfinished Life of Addison Stone at Pho Hoa in Chinatown

It doesn't matter if you are an expert "planeswalker", or don't know anything about Magic: The Gathering -- you can come to play or learn this amazing strategy game.  There are usually between 6-12 people at each event, consisting of all experience levels.  All decks of all types are welcome for this "casual play" event.  Beginners who want to learn are welcome!

This location is easily accessible from Rt. 16, Rt. 28 and Rt. 93, and is walking distance from the T, near the new Station Landing apartment complex. Here is a map of the area.

By Subway: Take the Orange Line to Wellington. Walk over the skybridge and cross through the parking lot. Upon exiting the garage, you'll see a building complex (SL75) across the street. Cross the street and take a right. Follow around this building and you'll find Not Your Average Joe's on the opposite side of the street.

By Car: If you are driving, be aware that Station Landing is at the intersection of Rt. 16 and Rt. 28, and you can enter the Station Landing complex from the north-bound side of Rt. 28, or the east-bound side of Rt. 16. There are a number of stores in the Station Landing complex -- look for the Margarita's, Starbucks or Not Your Average Joe's signs. NYAJ is located right off of Rte. 28. Although there is free parking all around the building, we recommend that MTG Boston members park in the garage underneath the restaurant.

results.description:
The event is located at the Fort Point WeWork location in Boston at the basement of the building.

This event will be a post-Imagine discussion to talk about some of the content, themes and key announcements from Magento Imagine 2016. 

Presentation: JavaScript in Magento 2


At Magento Imagine 2016 there were many conversations around Magento 2 – what it is, when to upgrade,  and specific technical elements such as Magento’s implementation of JavaScript.  

Magento developer Malachy McConnell will give an introduction to the changes in Magento's implementation of JavaScript and how to get your own JavaScript code onto the page securely and in-line with Magento 2's approach to JavaScript.

If you attended Magento Imagine, please come and share your input (and let us know if you’d like to share thoughts on a specific topic). If you didn’t attend Magento Imagine, then please join us to ask questions and join in the discussion.

This will be a laid back schedule, with food and beverages provided.
results.name: Post-Magento Imagine & Magento 2.0 Meet Up Discussion

Come join us for a midweek climb!


To the left there is a chip-in feature. Your donations will go directly to the monthly dues and will allow MAC meetup group to keep going. Any amount would be greatly appreciated. Thank you.

All levels are welcome! If you are new to climbing, there is a belay class at 7 PM. Here is the link to sign up: www.centralrockgym.com/bookeo.php?s=watertown 

I will happily belay those who have not climbed before up until 7 PM, but then it's really important to know how to belay and to take the belay test that starts at 7 PM. You can rejoin the group after taking the belay test.

For those of you who already know how to belay, no need to take the class, you just need to pass this gym's belay test when you arrive.

The price is as follows:

Membership: $89/month

Adult Day Pass: $22 

Gear (shoes, harness, belay device): $8 ($5 for members)

Belay class: $15 (free for members)

Belay test: Free

We will meet at the cluster of cubbies on the first floor at 6:30 PM, greet each other, make sure everyone has a group or person to climb with then head off to climb. I'm looking into whether there is a place nearby to grab a bite or drink at the end of the night. If you have a place in mind, please let me know.

I'll send a message letting you know what color shirt and pants I am wearing incase you arrive late and want to search for us. I will also swing by the cubbies every 15 minutes until everyone who signed up has arrived. So, if you are not able to make it or are running late, PLEASE COMMUNICATE on this event's chat or by contacting my cell-phone, which I will send out once you are confirmed for the event.

Hope you can make it! I'm looking forward to meeting more climbers in the area.

~Avery~

results.description:
- RSVP now for Wed, Apr 27 -

- Why you should ditch your elevator speech (if you even have one)

Last Meetup Summary:

At our meetup Wednesday, special guest Michelle Jeffalone spoke about mindfulness: incorporating presence and warmth in our lives and conversations (especially in tense situations). She also provided tips and exercises for how to be "more in the moment" and minimize mind chatter.

If you'd like to read more about Michelle's work, or to contact her, please go to:     www.michellejeffalone.com

                                   ........................

We're planning another special meetup Wednesday, June 8, with verbal branding expert Stephen Melanson.

Let's face it: crafting an elevator speech - a clear, brief message that creates interest in a project, idea or in yourself (who you are, and what you're looking for) - is one tough assignment. Which explains why most of us avoid developing one. They're typically about 30 seconds, which approximates a typical attention span. Or does it?

Finally, here's a reason to throw away your elevator pitch (if you even have one).

Melanson believes they're too long, they provide description [vs position] against the competition, and it's not a strategy to continue thru the rest of the interaction. “Branding books don’t recognize that the most important branding moments are conversations,”  he explains.

What's the answer?  Great verbal branding is direct, honest, and moves action. We'll learn how to intrigue our listener instead of losing their attention. Ever have that sinking feeling of watching your words fly past him/her?

Stephen Melanson is an entertaining and dynamic speaker. We'll start working on our personal branding statements in the previous meetup (May 25), and refine and revise them with Melanson at the special June 8 session.  The lessons you learn will stick with you for a long time to come.

                                                ........................

If you're new to Speak Up Cambridge, what should you expect from our usual meetups?

Learn valuable do's and don'ts for addressing an audience. Listen to first-time speakers. And discover how to get over that "anxiety hurdle."

Did you ever imagine speaking to a group could be fun?

First-time (and returning) guests enjoy our simple exercises and learn useful techniques for connecting with an audience.

Our meet-ups are fast-paced and entertaining. Nobody feels intimidated. Come experience it for yourself: You'll get to listen to prepared speeches and learn simple yet effective speaking tips.

You are welcome to participate in our two-minute impromptu speaking exercises, but certainly not required. We do have a 30-second “Round Robin” that everyone participates in (it’s fun and easy), and you’ll probably be asked to introduce yourself [talk very briefly about an interest, or what brought you there]. Pretty basic, no surprises.  The only requirement is to enjoy yourself and get a sense of how the meet-ups run. [They start promptly at 6:50, so please arrive by or before 6:45. They end by 8:30 pm.]


Mark Your Calendar - Our Next Meet-Ups:

Wed, April 27 (6:45 PM)

Wed, May 11 (6:45 PM)

Wed, May 25 (6:45 PM)

[Next "Second Saturday" AM session May 14.]

       ..............................

3rd Floor, Room 097.

You must take the elevator by the security desk to access the floor.

Parking: If you can't find street parking (Beware - Metered until 8 PM !), There is parking to the rear of the bldg. You will present ticket to the security desk on your way out ($3), then insert the ticket at the gate as you exit.
(Don't park in the supermarket/Porter Square shopping center parking lot.)


See the "About Us" tab for more info.

results.description:
Here are just some of the things you can get out of these meetings:

• Access to thousands of dollars of courses, software, and other resources

• Advice on overcoming a business or marketing obstacle you're facing

• Accountability, so you actually get your work done and turn your dreams into reality

• Ideas and inspiration to help you make something new or improve what you already have

• Meet awesome people who enjoy talking about this stuff as much as you do

Or, you can be a fly on the wall. No pressure at all. Feel free to drop in to just listen and see what internet marketing really looks like from people who are actually doing it.

These meetings tend to run between 1.5-2 hours. Here's the way it works:

7:00pm Join the meeting here:

https://hangouts.google.com/hangouts/_/daviddrayton.com/weeklyautomatedincomemastermindmeeting

First, new members introduce themselves, and existing members talk about what goals they hit and didn't hit in the past week. This part usually takes about 15 minutes. The remainder of our time is spent helping one of our members overcome any problems they may be facing by giving them a chance to sit on the "Couch of Insight!" Long story short, with our dozens of years of experience and our huge diversity of current business projects, we give them brutal but constructive feedback on their plans and current projects, helping them get insights they could never get from their friends and family alone.

Anyone can join. It doesn't matter where you are, how older you are, or even what stage of your business you're in. Our regular members include everyone from total beginners who are just getting their feet wet all the way up to serial entrepreneurs who are already making six-figures or more in their spare time doing this stuff.
results.how_to_find_us: Google Hangouts.  Join by clicking the link in the description.  Give it a shot before the meeting to make sure you can join without any problems.  Let me know if you're having trouble.
results.name: Weekly Remote Mastermind Session

results.description:
As spring approaches, there are ever more reasons to be outside walking around. It also is a time when we see people sometimes for the first time in months coming out of their bunkers. We'll see people playing with their kids in parks, or planting new gardens in their front yards (or along the bike path) etc... We might be doing things like this as well. The topic for this week, is given this influx of "seeing" others, what types of things can we do to be better neighbors. Most people admit that the concept of neighbor has kind of gone by the wayside. In fact, we join groups like Think and Drink as an opportunity to select in a way our neighbors (But we don't always know who'll be at meetup! Sometimes our actual neighbors!). But the people who live near us, could be great resources for us to find and build connections. A Harvard study, that hilariously took 75 years, showed that one key indicator to happiness is as we all already know - good relationships. They made a ted talk: https://www.ted.com/talks/robert_waldinger_what_makes_a_good_life_lessons_from_the_longest_study_on_happiness?language=en. This link is not an endorsement it's to document the reference :).

For something more worthwhile, check out this Wikihow on how to be a good neighbor - pretty funny/helpful! http://www.wikihow.com/Be-a-Good-Neighbour

Hope you can make it!
results.name: neighboring well

results.description:
It’s not only eggs that are dyed in spring but also wool, cotton and linen! Come discover the joy of pulling unexpected hues from plant-based dyes.

Common onions produce these earthy tones.
(Photo credit: Inger Maaike.)

People have historically gone to great lengths to harvest plant dyes for their fabrics for the same reason we look forward to spring flowers – the mind loves a color feast. Learn the surprising depths of familiar medicinal and culinary herbs, and the shocking colors they reveal in the dye bath: yellow onion skins yielding rich browns and golds, for example. We’ll cover the basic dye-making recipe for wool, linen and cotton fibers.

7:00pm – 9:00pm
25 St. Mary’s Court, Brookline

The fee for this class is $20.

RSVP by filling out our contact form, emailing us at [masked], or calling[masked]-5274.

results.description:
Welcome to the weekly BKBS Wednesday meet up. Please join us at 7:00 PM by the 3rd table station in the middle of the top roping / lead area. If you are still by the bouldering wall, keep on walking.

We usually meet there for about 10 mins, and then team up in groups of 2 or 3 for top-rope climbing.

If you know that you'll be late, let us know in the comments section, and maybe tell us what you'll be wearing, so we can look out for you. 

BKBS (http://www.bkbsomerville.com/Classes/. If you have a working knowledge of how to belay, you will need to be belay certified before climbing on the ropes. Please flag down a BKBS employee and let them know you need to take a belay test. To pass such a test you will need to display how to tie a double figure eight knot with a fisherman's backup, safely belay a climber up a wall, catch them on a fall, and lower them to the ground safely.

What equipment do I need?  You will need at the bare minimum a harness and climbing shoes. Rentals are available. Grigri devices are provided at every station.

What if I can come, but at a different time?  Just let everyone know you want to climb at a different time and use the community to find a partner for those dates / times.

These are the climbing rates:

ADMISSION (Full day use, you can leave and come back!): 

Day Pass - $25 (Students $20) 
10 Pack - $225 (Students $180)

(Membership Pricing also available)

RENTALS: 

Shoes - $5 
Harness - $5 
Chalk Bag - $2 
Full Gear Kit - $11
results.how_to_find_us: The third table in the middle of the climbing area between 7:00-7:10 PM. It's the table in the middle of the TR \/ Lead area.

results.description:
Wednesday night is our (almost) weekly get-together for open gaming at the Panera Bread location in Porter Square. All are welcome to join us, regardless of experience level!


If you have a game you are particularly interested in playing, you are welcome and encouraged to bring it. But this is not required; many people typically bring a selection of their favorites and we're always happy to teach. The only things you need to bring are an open mind and a good attitude. If you're particularly hot to try something out, you are encouraged to leave a comment and see if you can drum up some interest beforehand. Please bear in mind that table space is limited, so an especially huge or epic game may not be appropriate for the venue (but see our Sunday night event at Pandemonium in Central Square for an alternative venue).


The event officially opens at 7 PM, but some people like to show up early; those who show up early should feel free to get started on a shorter warm-up game if time allows.


We look forward to seeing you at the gaming table!


WHERE WE SIT: Unless the restaurant is super-crowded, we gather in the basement dining area; just look for the games and say hi. We're friendly, honest!


GETTING THERE:


The Panera is located within easy walking distance of the Red Line T and several bus lines, and public transit is probably the easiest way of getting there. If you drive, mall parking is (theoretically) limited to 2 hours except where posted. I've never heard of anyone getting towed for overstaying this limit. For the extra-cautious, there are metered spots on Mass Ave; check the meter to be sure but most Cambridge meters don't need to be fed after 6 PM or 7 PM. There is also a Hubway bike-share station less than five minute's walk from the mall.


SOME NOTES:


As a group, we don't usually make a huge deal about attendance policy, however: attendance at these events is limited, and our Panera events are usually not huge; one side effect of this is that RSVPing and then not showing up can have a disruptive effect on our events, and for particularly popular events, "no shows" take up a spot from someone who wanted to be there. Bottom line: If you RSVP for a Panera event, please make a good-faith effort to show up or at least let us know if you can't make it.


As far as possible, please also let us know if you're going to be more than a few minutes late. As a rule of thumb, if we haven't heard from you and you arrive after 7:15 or so, you're likely to be limited to a spot at whatever game has room for an extra player. Much later than that, and we'll almost certainly be underway without you! You're welcome to show up and socialize and of course we'll try to accomodate you if we can, but we can't guarantee you a game. Because we as a group tend to play longer and more involved games, most groups at our events tend to play one and only one game per night.


Panera has been quite gracious about hosting our group with minimal fuss. To ensure that this happy state of affairs continues, please give them some business if you're hungry or thirsty and (especially) respect the hardworking people who work there, and their desire to go home after a long shift -- be ready to leave when the restaurant closes at ten.
results.name: Wednesday Gaming In Porter Square

results.description:
Seeking a successor to organize this Meetup. Please if you always wanted to do it better than I could, step up and contact me.

Making friends on Facebook is good, sitting together at the same table and having a nice beer or glass of wine is even better. Join us and see where it takes you.

results.description:
Join 50 or more dancers any Wednesday at Dance Freedom!!

We are the original barefoot weekly dance, continuously running for 47 years, that has spawned hundreds if not thousands of other dances around the world.

In a drug, alcohol, and shoe-free environment, we've been making friends and sharing safe and juicy dances for decades. Come join the fun!! Discover the joy of dancing in a totally non-judgmental atmosphere, where anything safe and respectful goes... dance by yourself, in a group, with a same or opposite sex partner, or even just chat and enjoy watching.

First time visitors are welcomed heartily! You decide what to pay in a range from $10 to $20, or less later in the evening as the event nears its end (information on late admission discounts is at the door). Our friendly dancers range from utterly new at it to very skilled dancers in many different styles. Dance with or alongside amazing dancers from local dance troupes as well as with ordinary good-hearted rug cutters. At work they may be doctors, lawyers, programmers, massage therapists, expressive therapists, artists, students, dog walkers, scientists, or anything else, but at heart they all love to dance.

The music runs the gamut: funk, world music, soul & r&b, house, trance, hip-hop, salsa, yoga music, jazz or swing, reggae, disco, you name it! Each DJ from our rotating list has a unique style, but we try to include something for everyone in every set. We keep a good balance in the music: familiar with unusual, timeless with current, melodic with drum-based, and positive lyrics with instrumentals--in all kinds of rhythms & styles! In any given evening, the world music parts of our dance are likely to include at least 3 or so of the following... African, Latin, Indian, Middle Eastern, Caribbean, zydeco, gypsy and much more. You'll hear everything from basic party music to very danceable songs with socially conscious lyrics, but you won't be hearing anything sexist, racist, violent, hating or otherwise divisive.

Start with a soothing stretch and warm up at 7:30, connect with the group and start to boogie at 7:50 with our first DJ of the evening, take a brief break at 8:50 for community announcements and a short unique performance or workshop then cut the rug again by 9:15 at the latest with the evening's second DJ, till 10:30--plenty of time for a great workout and some feel-good inspiration and respiration and perspiration!

At the beginning of each half of the evening's music, dancers  hold hands, and dance in a winding chain together.  (This dance was created from out of a drumming circle on the Cambridge Common in the sixties, after all, and some of that great political and community spirit still lives on here.) Then, it's all dance music, generally building in tempo to a crescendo, slowing down again for some more melodic and slow dance songs for a few minutes, then gradually building to a second crescendo. The second half of the evening's dance follows roughly the same pattern with a different DJ and style, and ends with another circle dance for those who enjoy it.

Dancers are always welcome to help with set-up or take-down, and get in free for doing so! It's a great chance to get to know the community better.  Welcome! For more information, E-mail: [masked]
results.how_to_find_us: Opposite the Cambridge Common, see the Sheraton Hotel w/the big red letters COMMANDER on top.  Enter the stone church just left of hotel, @ entrance closest to hotel.  Follow the hall straight, left and right to the desk to sign in.

In association with Celebrity Series of Boston, NEC's Calderwood Director of Orchestras, Hugh Wolff, brings the NEC Philharmonia to Symphony Hall. Just one performance—don't miss it!

Meet the new Stradivarius in town! The estate of world-renowned violinist, educator, and NEC alum Si-Hon Ma ’50 M.M, ’52 A.D. has gifted the 1714 “Joachim-Ma” Stradivarius violin to New England Conservatory. This instrument will be heard in NEC's Jordan Hall April 23 in its first appearance under NEC's ownership, in performances by NEC faculty and students, including Artist Diploma student & 2016 Avery Fisher Career Grant recipient Alexi Kenney. Tonight, Kenney will play the instrument again with the NEC Philharmonia, led by NEC's Calderwood Director of Orchestras, Hugh Wolff.

PROGRAM:

Adams: Concerto for Violin
quarter note = 78

Toccare
Alexi Kenney (Violin)

Purchase tickets here: https://www.bso.org/Performance/Detail/76352

Sky-high virtuosity, passion you can just about touch, and a program that showcases it all.

results.description:
What is Isha Kriya?

Isha kriya is a simple and powerful process created by yogi and humanitarian Sadhguru.  It is rooted in the timeless wisdom of the yogic sciences.  Today, for most people, the word ‘yoga’ usually conjures up images of twisting the body into impossible postures.  The physical aspect of Yoga is only one facet of this multi-dimensional science.  Yoga is a technology to bring the body and mind to the peak of their capabilities, allowing one to live life to the fullest.

Daily practice of Isha Kriya brings health, dynamism, peace and wellbeing.

This meditation can be learned in one session and requires an investment of 12 – 18 minutes per day.  It has the potential to transform the life of anyone who is willing to incorporate it into their everyday life.

No previous experience is necessary and it can even be done seated in a chair. It is a powerful tool to cope with the hectic pace of modern life.
results.name: Isha Kriya Guided Meditation--FREE LIVE Class

results.description:
Kangoo Jumps is one of the latest fitness crazes catching on across the country.  It's an amazing workout for people who are interested in losing weight and building strength. Great for those who want a high intensity cardio workout with far less impact to their joints. Kangoo jumps can burn up to 50% more calories than traditional workouts.

                                                    Meetup Details:

Organizer/Event Host: 
Jenna (*SHC)

Kangoo Jumps Instructor: 
Wendel C.

Sponsored by: 
Kangoo Jumps Club - MA.


Choreography Level:
Easy, basic steps, entry level

Cardio Level:
High Intensity Workout

Location: 
Abington

Cost: 
$15.00 with Kangoo Jumps rental - $10.00 without rental, * Special rate pricing avail to SSH&B/SHC members only.

Attendance Limit:
10 members, limit may increase as needed later.

Gear/Clothing:
Bring 2 pairs of thick socks, similar to those you would wear hiking (wool or wicking). Wear supportive clothing, a good sports bra & bring water. 

Kangoo Rental Sizes:

Small - Womens 4-6 or Mens 3-5
Medium - Womens 6-9 Mens 6-8
Large - Womens 10-12 Mens 9-11
XLarge - Womens 12+, Mens 12-15

Action Required After RSVP: 
Please add your Kangoo size to the comments board so that I can arrange to have them onsite for the class.

Communications:
I'll arrive on site early and will use the meetup board to communicate. I'll send my contact info to those that RSVP. Please use text when contacting me if poss.


Misc but Important:
- What happens in Kangoo club stays in Kangoo club - pls don't video tape anyone the without their consent, pics are fine

.- There is no secure place to put your things, open lockers are right by the front door so leave your valuables in car or at home.

 - Bring cash/exact change (if possible) to expedite - Bring a healthy snack with you for the ride home.

- Zumba class lets out prior to the Kangoo classes, there may not be much room to in the foyer to wait around for Zuma to end. I like to wait until the Zuma class exits the building before entering.

- You can not just show up at this event without an RSVP. Kangoos are brought to the location based on your RSVP & size + class size must be controlled due to type of activity. 

Prereqs:
Anyone with basic concepts of aerobics, step, boxing or zumba/dance and enjoys a high intensity cardio workout.

* Future Kangoo Jump Events: 
Kangoo jump weekend hikes will be posted to meetup under Southeastern Hiking Club (SHC) starting in May. 


Disclaimer:
During all events, everyone is responsible for themselves. Meetup hosts, organizers, assistant organizers, leaders, guides and sponsors are not responsible for the safety of participants. By joining the group, you acknowledge and agree to this statement.

results.description:
Dear Boston Culture Lovers,

Let's enjoy a night of Brazilian choro music.  If you don't know what choro (aka chorinho) sounds like, it is a samba/bossa nova style instrumental jazzy music. It is wonderful, you are going to love it.  

Listen to sounds bites from the featured band, The Regional de NY, at https://www.facebook.com/choronyc/info/ and  http://choronyc.com/sounds/ .

The show starts at 9 pm, however let's meet at 8 pm so we can all get a table and sit as a group and enjoy some eats and drinks before the music begins. 

Admission is $10

The restaurant policy is to only seat the group when all members have arrived.  If you are late, please understand that we cannot wait for you or guarantee that you will be able to join the group. It is not fair to ask fellow members who arrived early to wait any longer for latecomers.  Most importantly, it is not fair for the restaurant to hold empty seats and lose business for latecomers or for people who fail to show-up.  Just need to give you this fair warning.  


If you reserve "yes" and are no longer able to attend, I only ask you to adjust your reservation before the start of the event.  

I look forward to enjoying this event with the group.  

Joana

*********************************************************

Event Details 


The Regional de NY is a traditional Choro group in the style of the great Brazilian ensembles of years past and present. Since 2011, our mission has been to keep the rich musical tradition of choro alive in a contemporary US context. For the past several years we have hosted regular rodas (jam sessions) to provide a unique opportunity for enthusiasts of Choro to sit in with the band and hone their craft - these jams have been instrumental in building and maintaining a vibrant choro scene in New York. We have performed at venues such as Brasil Summer Fest, Zinc Bar, Barbes, Cornelia Street Café, and the Brazilian Endowment for the Arts.


Our first album, "Na Roda", is an attempt to capture the spirit of our regular rodas (jam sessions) -- all the playfulness, virtuosity, sensitivity, and joy that can come from performing live with close musical companions. The album features guest performances from several fantastic friends of ours -- the great Fred Hersch, Anat Cohen, and Eduardo Belo -- and is a window into the thriving Choro scene in New York.


http://www.rylesjazz.com/week1.cfm



Venue - Ryles Jazz Club Parking and Directions Details

If you can not find a meter, Ryles has a small parking lot on Hampshire Street between Armory and Prospect Streets, across from the Hess Express gas station/adjacent to the 7-Eleven.  In addition, you may also park across the street at S&S Restaurant, their sister restaurant. I also heard they have a third parking lot, however I am not sure where it is. 


Ryles is located in the heart of Inman Square with lots of access to public transportation.  To plan your travel via public transportation, visit the MBTA web site's Rider Tools, http://www.mbta.com/rider_tools/. 

http://www.ryles.com/ 

http://www.ryles.com/directions.cfm

results.description:
Ellen Jaffe JonesThe Veg Coach

Creative Cook / Author / Consultant
From our test kitchen to your home kitchen

OK, show of hands.  How many of you eat quinoa as a side dish?
Most cooks use the protein-rich grain as a substitute for rice.
But, I've got a treat for you today.  It's a recipe for Quinoa crisp chocolate balls!
What a way to reward yourself for following a healthy lifestyle.

Find it below.

Consider this too as a tasty approach to getting people interested in coming to one of my FREE cooking classes. This week, Wednesday at 9pm EST, I'll be doing a free class prepping and serving 2 recipes from my book "Eat Vegan on $4 a Day." Bring any questions to our Google Hangout: 

https://plus.google.com/events/c0oegddjuh07utbrq1mv6vm1rfg

Happy cooking,

Ellen Jaffe Jones
The Veg Coach
http://www.vegcoach.com

Buy my books:

Paleo Vegan

Eat Vegan on $4 a Day

Kitchen Divided - Vegan Recipes for Semi-Vegan Households

This is a Quinoa crisp chocolate bar you might find at your local health food store.  
But, my recipe lets you create your own Quinoa chocolate treat.  

It'll satisfy your chocolate cravings and it's so easy to make.  

The recipe is below.

You're Going to Love This!  

Quinoa Crisp Chocolate Treats
by Ellen Jaffe Jones

INGREDIENTS 

1 cup vegan chocolate chips
1/2 cup puffed quinoa
4 teaspoons coconut oil
1/8 teaspoon salt (optional)

PREPARATION INSTRUCTIONS

1 cup vegan chocolate chips
1/2 cup puffed quinoa
4 teaspoons coconut oil
1/8 teaspoon salt (optional)

Melt chocolate chips in a double-boiler, or place in a microwave-safe bowl and heat for about 60 seconds until the chips develop a slight sheen.  
Place all ingredients in a medium pot (or add to the double-boiler) and over medium heat, and stir constantly for about 5 minutes taking care not to burn the chocolate. 
Form small balls and place on a non-stick cookie sheet.  
Refrigerate for at least 60 minutes before serving.  
For those wanting to reduce fat intake, this can be made without the coconut oil, but make sure the chocolate chips are completely melted.

results.description:
Immersive exploration of interesting, playful, and fun concepts behind Agile Software Development focuses on teaching, demonstrating, and improving effectiveness using game theory.  

Using games, we can model complex or time-consuming processes and systems, examine why they work (or don't work), look for improvements, and teach others how to benefit from them.  Games can model just the core of a process or model, leaving out unimportant factors.  They can involve collaboration, brainstorming, comparing variants, and of course retrospectives.

Come be part of this fun, hands-on and thought-provoking conference - you’ll leave with the knowledge to facilitate a variety of games and activities and gain practical ideas that you can start to apply in your team, workgroup or organization right away! 


This event is not filled to capacity.  We are doing registration and payment on a link outside of Meetup, so please do not try to RSVP here.  For detailed information or to register, please go the Agile Games 2016 website: agilegamesnewengland.com

Agile Games 2016 is an event of Agile New England, a chapter of the ACM.

results.description:
Join us for a guided meditation to help you achieve a state of well-being, relaxation, and strengthen your connection to self. 

Each week, Elaine will lead the group in a guided meditation to induce a deepened state of relaxation, healing on all levels.  You can achieve an expanded state of self and a higher state of consciousness, connecting you to the ALL that IS! 

Elaine is able to connect with the most highest vibrations and frequencies of light that serves the group as a whole.  Your personal experience will be enhanced by the group setting. 

All levels of meditators are welcome to join us.  A sacred space is created to help you feel safe and comfortable. 

Please RSVP your intention on attending.  Cost is $5 at the door.  Doors open at 10:45AM with the group staring at 11AM! 

Visit our website for more info www.essencehealing.net
results.name: Weekly Morning Meditation

results.description:
Finding the right co-founder is crucial for your success in all business, especially startups. One of the most common reasons startups fail has to do with bad chemistry between founders or a lack of sound decision making when entering into a partnership agreement.

Our online webinar will focus on best practices when searching for and engaging with potential co-founders. It is based on the experiences Startupblink co-founder Eli went through while building his startups. 

This event is a Free Online Webinar, happening via Blab, an application and webpage allowing video live conversations. The link to register and participate in the Blab session is:  

http://unbouncepages.com/blab-webinar-startupblink/

After you leave your details on the above link, you will get redirected to the blab event page, and after the event we will send you an email with a link to the recording and the slides.

This lecture is brought to you by our sister company, Lingolearn, an online language school where you can learn any language you wish with our private tutors from around the world. We have a special offer of 1 hour lesson in more than 20 languages with a private tutor for $15, only for StartupBlink meetup members. The lesson is money back guaranteed (no questions asked), so in case you are not happy with the lesson, we will  get your money back immediately. Time to learn the language you always dreamed of at www.Store.Lingolearn.com

If you missed our previous online webinars on Getting Traction for your Startup and Building a startup by bootstrapping, you can watch them here :


https://blab.im/startupblink-getting-traction-for-your-startup

https://blab.im/startupblink-building-a-startup-by-bootstrapping-pv5sw

Special request from us, please don't forget to add your startup or organization @ http://www.startupblink.com and join our closed startup group at: https://www.facebook.com/groups/startupblink/
results.name: Finding the Right Co-Founder

results.description:
Meditation practice develops concentration, which allows us to calm and steady the mind and give us clear access to our natural wisdom. This practice is 30 minutes of guided Vipassana meditation followed by a brief discussion.

The focus is to be present in the moment, allowing thoughts and emotions to surface. We become an internal observer of these, fostering healthy non-attachment and cultivating a deeper connection with one's inner self.

Newcomers to meditation and long-time practitioners are welcome to attend.

results.description:
The Art Playground will be open on Thursday afternoons from 1 to 6 for working on (or playing with, however you like to think of it)individual art projects. You can bring your own supplies, or chose from a vast array at the studio. Sessions are each $10. 

The registration fee does not including supplies, which are a $5 or $10 contribution to the supply fund, depending on what you want to use. You can also bring your own supplies. 

 At the studio are plenty of magazines, maps, foils, colored papers, colored mylar,  thick papers for grounds, glues and scissors and exacto knives, beads and glue guns, craypas, colored pencils, watercolors, pastels, and it goes on. 

If you sign up for the following week, or if you sign up for 4 or more weeks over the course of April, May and June, you may leave your projects at the studio.

There is no instructor for these sessions, but, if wanted, I can give you ideas and assistance with using supplies. 

I hope it is possible for some people to work in a social atmosphere while others create their own personal zone to work in. Come join us and we'll see what happens.

Margot
results.how_to_find_us: Suite 16, off the stairs at the front of the building, first door on the left.
results.name: Open Studio Time to work/play with art materials, collage and mixed media
