results.description:
Over the last decade there has been an explosion of both data and opportunity as genomics transitioned from science fiction to everyday reality.  The Boston area is primed to lead the way in this new frontier with its bustling research and start up communities.

Join us and other members of the Life Science community at Venture Café for a lively panel discussion on the current opportunities and challenges in this rapidly emerging field. We will have a discussion with some of the area’s most exciting companies doing work in this area.  Together, we will explore the many possibilities and challenges on this new frontier. We hope to determine what the future holds for this quickly evolving industry.

This FREE event is sponsored by IBM and hosted by Venture Cafe. We hope you can join us for this great discussion!

TO REGISTER: https://www.eventbrite.com/e/genomics-decoding-the-future-tickets-24652059975?aff=ebrowse

When Thursday, April 28, 2016 from 5:00 PM to 6:00 PM 

Where Venture Café (Havana), 5th Floor, CIC, One Broadway, Cambridge, MA 02142

-------------------------------------------------------------------------------

2nd Panel from 6.30pm-7.30pm:

Life Science meets Big Data and Analytics: A natural Progression

The life sciences and healthcare industries historically have generated large amounts of data garnered through patient profiling, regulations and compliance requirements, along with scientific research. These overwhelming amounts of data hold the promise of supporting a wide range of medical and healthcare functions, including clinical decision and outcome, disease monitoring, and clinical analytics. Data in life sciences and healthcare continues grow exponentially year over year will be beyond the capability of the traditional methods of data management and data analytics.

This FREE event is sponsored by IBM and hosted by Venture Cafe. We hope you can join us for this great discussion!

If you can make it, please RSVP here https://www.eventbrite.com/e/life-science-meets-big-data-and-analytics-a-natural-progession-tickets-24649634721


When: Thursday, April 28, 2016 from 6:30 PM to 7:30 PM (EDT) -
Where: Venture Café (Havana), 5th Floor, CIC, One Broadway, Cambridge, MA 02142 - View Map
results.name: Genomics - Decoding the Future ; Life Science meets Big Data and Analytics

results.description:
Let's go for a brisk hike in the the Fells. We plan to hike 3 to 5 miles, approx 1.5-2 hours. The route is TBD and may include steep or rough terrain.


*This is a fitness hike rather than a stroll in the woods.* To keep pace with the group, you should be able to walk a 2.5 mile per hour pace on the trail (which is significantly slower than walking on the road.)


You will need to wear good trail shoes and layers to adjust for temperature change. We will meet at the Long Pond parking area on South Border Rd off Mystic Valley Pkway. Arrive a few minutes early - we leave promptly at 5:15pm.


http://www.getupngoadventures.com/html/south_border_road.html

Random Group of Hikers Disclaimer

As a condition of your voluntary participation in this activity you acknowledge and agree to the following: this activity involves inherent risks that can cause property damage, injury, illness, disability, and/or death to participants and/or others; you assume all risk associated with this activity; you are responsible for having the necessary knowledge, skills, abilities, clothing, and equipment to safely participate in this activity; you know and will follow theHike Safe Responsibility Code; the organizer(s) of this activity are volunteers; and you release, hold harmless, and indemnify the organizer(s) and all members of this group from any and all claims for property damage, injury, illness, disability, and/or death - including those caused by negligence and/or other reasons.

results.description:
Join the talented team behind WBUR podcasts, Dear Sugar, Kind World, Modern Love, and The Magic Pill at WBUR On Tap: The Art & Science of Podcasting on Thursday, April 28, at Aloft Boston Seaport. Free registration required. 


The team will explore how they make a podcast from conception to deployment (discovering the idea, building out the concept, creating the content, finding the right voice, figuring out the rhythm, implementing sound and music, editing to the right length, and more) as they deconstruct one of theModern Love segments. You’ll get to hear an excerpt of the raw audio and a first draft before all the elements are layered in to create the final sound with finishing touches.

WBUR On Tap begins with light refreshments and a cash bar at 5:30 p.m. followed by the conversation from 6:00 – 7:00 p.m.

On Tap is free, but advanced registration is required and seats are limited.

Click here to register.
results.how_to_find_us: Please register for location
results.name: WBUR On Tap: The Art & Science of Podcasting

results.description:
Have you heard a call to create a better world, but the gap between your dream and current reality sometimes seem insurmountable?  How do you keep pursuing your dream when the going gets lonely, frightening, or uncertain?    


You’re not alone!  Be inspired by other social entrepreneurs who are finding solutions to social, cultural and environmental problems. Share ideas with other like-minded people who will inspire you and with leaders who will educate and mentor you. Leave with clarity, an action-plan, and the support of the Dream Factory Community in taking your next steps.

This conference won’t be the same without you.

. . . . . . . . . . . Answering the Call . . . . . . . . . .
. . . . A Gathering of Social Entrepreneurs . . . .
. for Direction, Inspiration, and Camaraderie .
(Dream Factory Annual Dinner and Conference)

You can create solutions to social problems. Join us at our annual conference to hear from social entrepreneurs and how they are creating positive changes. Engage in workshops and become inspired to make a change yourself, while gaining the knowledge and tools in order to do so successfully. 


https://mlsvc01-prod.s3.amazonaws.com/d1c9f3a6be/6e7739b6-6d26-484f-a1ab-374bb355291b.jpg?ver=1456442888000

On Thursday, the Executive Director of Build, Ayele Shakur, will share POWER, a model they use to teach under-served inner city students how to build their own businesses.  You will hear from our Workshop Facilitators who will outline what they are offering the next day.

On Friday, you will engage in these workshops that will empower you to take next steps in fulfilling your calling.


Add to Calendar

Driving Directions

Contact: Nancy Cantor, The Dream Factory Community, [masked] [masked]

Gold Sponsor:

</a>

<a href="http://www.dreamfactorycommunity.com/wp-content/uploads/2016/02/doctors-express.png">

Price: Until April 25th

Thursday Night Dinner and Friday Workshops: $189
Thursday Night Dinner Alone: $85
Friday Workshops: $140

To REGISTER

Friday Workshop Facilitators

Dennis Pratt

Title: Be the Realizer of Your Dreams

Blurb: We may have fabulous dreams for a better world, but we also have "ways of being" that can limit our ability to realize our dreams.  The more that we can change our limiting behaviors, the more we will be able to realize our dreams in reality. Dennis will explore the common saboteurs that he and 100s of entrepreneurs have confronted before their dreams could begin to come true. 

Questions:   
* What are some common saboteurs of entrepreneurs?
* What are the ways that I am acting/thinking that might be getting in the way of my success?
* What way of acting or thinking differently would better support my success?
* What is the cost of my transformation?
* What would I gain by changing the way I am being?

Bio: Dennis Pratt is the founder and "Chef Réalisateur" of the Personal Growth Network.  A graduate of Northwestern and MIT, Dennis guided scores of entrepreneurs in the marketing strategy and technical design of new-to-the-world high-tech businesses for nascent industries.  Dennis now volunteers to help guide and support scores of personal growth leaders as they scope out their niches.
www.meetup.com/Personal-Growth-Network
<a href="http://www.meetup.com/Personal-Growth-Network"></a>


Punita Arora


Title: Importing Handmade Products that Support Women in Other Countries

Blurb: How can one sort through aspirations and craziness of being dedicated to growing a business--for the benefit of society? Punita offers a way of thinking about our thinking, to sort through dreams and de-sires of success. She uses a thoughtful prism to clarify inten-tions and allow participants' designs to emerge. Consider looking at dreams through a different light and see what happens!

Questions: 
* Who am I, and what do I want to achieve with my entrepreneurial efforts?
* Whom do I serve, and what do I know about them? 
* Who benefits from my offering my services?
* What are my biases about various stakeholders in my entrepreneurial world and the people around me?
* What do I know about the market in which I operate, and the world that is touched by this marketplace?
* How can I connect with and serve the world more effectively as a social entrepreneur?
* How is this new and improved approach different from traditional business?

Bio: Punita Arora sells delightful daily luxu-ries; her brand, Poppies and Persim-mons, supports women's collectives in India, using Dream Factory princi-ples to build community and com-merce in service of a greater good. Social entrepreneurs are a special breed of business people, engaged in the building a better world through enterprise. 

Gail Harris

Title: How to Write a Book: From Idea to Publication

Blurb: Thinking about writing a book? Find out how to:  select your idea for marketing purposes;  write your manuscript (self-help, memoir or other);  choose agents and traditional publishing or self-publishing ; market, distribute, promote, and publicize;  stay true to yourself


Questions: So you want to write a book ...? 
* With so many options for publishing a book, these days, how do you move forward with your book project and remain true to your vision and purpose?
* What are your vision and purpose for writing your book? 
* Will you write the book yourself or have someone write it for you?
* Will you look for an agent and publisher or will you self-publish?
* Is your manuscript up to snuff?

Bio: Gail Harris is an author and intuition coach who teaches people how to trust their intuition, so they can make the right choices in their life. She was a finalist for an IPNE Book Award for the memoir Finding Zoe. Her book, Your Heart Knows the Answer is a primer for learning to trust your intuition. Through her coaching prac-tice, Gail guides people to develop an intuition practice they can use every day for the rest of their life. 

Linda Waters

Title: How to Launch a Product

Blurb: Learn how to successfully launch your idea! This talk will include market positioning exercises, tips and strategies to bring your business idea to life.


Bio: Ms. Waters' passion is to help people gather the tools and confidence they need to market themselves effectively and make successful career transi-tions. An accomplished business leader and presenter, Linda speaks regularly to academic, professional and corpo-rate audiences on career-related and motivational topics. Linda also enjoys conducting workshops for corporations, blending her hands- on business experience with world class personality inventories. 

Clara Angelina Diaz

Title: Your Passion and Business Model in One Page


Blurb: Through her presentation, Your Passion and Business Model in One Page, Clara will explain how she created a profitable coaching busi-ness with services and products, along with how to use The Lean Model Business Canvas to map out your business idea. Her workshop will also help you to gain inspiration to serve the world with your passion and make money doing it.

Questions: 
* Do I have a clear and simple to understand business plan for my business? 
* Do I struggle with understanding the essence of my business? 
* What problem or problems does my business solve? 
* What solutions do I offer? 
* What's my  unique value proposition? 
* Am I clear on how to reach the people that have the problem I solve and want my solution? 
* What does it cost me to make and deliver my products or services?  


Bio: Clara is a bilingual lifestyle coach, author, and speaker with a passion for helping women create and define a unique idea of personal happiness. She empowers women to increase their confidence and income by help-ing them discover their life purpose and develop a positive mindset to achieve greatness! 

Marianne Connor

Title: Tell a Compelling Story; Enroll Others in your Ideas

Blurb: A compelling story is essential to creating the culture shift to Conscious Capitalism, a story that reveals the devastating and unsustainable costs of our current system and educates and inspires investors, staff and customers alike to vote with their dollars, talents and time for a better world. Come discover your story for building the new economy

Bio: Marianne Connor is a screenwriter, producer, and evolutionary activist. She believes writers and storytellers have a critical role to play in imagining and designing the cultural shift to a new, life-giving story created in partnership with the natural world. The commitment to a triple-bottom line (people care, earth care, fair share) is countercultural in America, where the corporate structure legally binds many businesses into making the most profit for shareholders in the least amount of time. 

About the Dream Factory

The Dream Factory Community is an educational women’s organization, that has communities that train Chief Dream Officers, women who take on their life, their work and their world.

We are creating communities that empower women to make their contribution and impact the world

http://www.dreamfactorycommunity.com
results.how_to_find_us: Directions below.

Blurb: A compelling story is essential to creating the culture shift to Conscious Capitalism, a story that reveals the devastating and unsustainable costs of our current system and educates and inspires investors, staff and customers alike to vote with their dollars, talents and time for a better world. Come discover your story for building the new economy

Bio: Marianne Connor is a screenwriter, producer, and evolutionary activist. She believes writers and storytellers have a critical role to play in imagining and designing the cultural shift to a new, life-giving story created in partnership with the natural world. The commitment to a triple-bottom line (people care, earth care, fair share) is countercultural in America, where the corporate structure legally binds many businesses into making the most profit for shareholders in the least amount of time. 

About the Dream Factory

The Dream Factory Community is an educational women’s organization, that has communities that train Chief Dream Officers, women who take on their life, their work and their world.

We are creating communities that empower women to make their contribution and impact the world

<a href="http://www.dreamfactorycommunity.com/">http://www.dreamfactorycommunity.com 

Register Here

Come paddle at one of our practice sessions with Living Root, your 2015 Boston Dragon Boat Festival Grand Champions! We're a social and friendly co-ed team who enjoy the sport of dragon boat paddling.

results.description:
Analytics.Club's Monthly Meet-N-Greet Mixer

About the Event:

Monthly Meet-N-Greet Mixer networking event is conducted every last Thursday of the month. This event will primarily focus on building networks to initiate good conversations on data science across different venues around the town.

The monthly event will be Networking only mixer(Just plain and simple networking with no long sales pitch or knowledge sessions) envisioned to keep local data science professionals connected. You will use the opportunity to exchange contact information, seek opportunities, and connect with fellow data science professionals and build deeper connected networks.

Goal: We hope you at least make 2 new contacts / event & spread the word on event so more and more data science professionals could leverage the opportunity to build their personal network.

When: Last Thursday of the Month

Time: 6:00 p.m. - 8:00 p.m.

Location: Local Bar / Cafe  (hopefully a new exploration every month). Venue will be our participating members choice and will be finalized one week prior to the event every month. 

* Please provide a bar/cafe recommendation in the comment section and vote yes if you agree *

Refreshments/Drinks: Buy Your Own Drink/Meal

(We appreciate sponsor pitching in on drinks/refreshments to support a great cause)

Agenda:

0. Put name tag with following initials in circle (optional, for effective networking):

a. (B) for Business Background 

b. (C) for Coding Background 

c. (S) for Statistician Background 

d. (T) for Technology Background 

e. (M) for Math / Modeling Background

1. Open networking (20min)

2. Job / Employee seekers pitch (20min)

Quick pitch (90secs each) from Job seekers or recruiters

3. Product /Project pitch session (20min)

Quick pitch (2min each) from data enthusiast who wants to share among fellow data science professionals.

4. Open networking (60min)

FAQ:

1. Can I be the event host/organizer for an evening?

Yes. We do appreciate our community members to take charge and help build a great networking event. Please make your interest known to us in comment section.

2. Can my company sponsor for the drinks/refreshments? What do they get?

Yes. Besides great karma points for helping build a strong data science community, the company will also get face time with brightest data science professionals for brand recognition. You also get an opportunity for a 90 sec pitch time about the company & job openings.

3. Will event still happen even if there are no sponsors?

Yes. As long as there is a mutually agreed bar/cafe for the evening the event is a GO. Attendees will buy their own drinks/refreshments.

4. Could we volunteer our office space for the networking?

Yes, one of the bigger objective for the event is to introduce various innovation/discussion hubs to data science community.

5. What are the possible scenarios in which event can be cancelled?

Public Holidays, Bad Weather, Lack of interest or No venue.

6. I still have questions. How can I get them answered?

Best way is to put them in comment section, so that even our members can pitch in. You are welcome to email us as well at info[at]analytics[dot]club
results.name: Data Analytics.Club Monthly Mixer

Welcome to the Marlborough Couch to 5K sponsored by ConnectingPoint Church. We love people in our community. We've helped over 400 people get off the couch and start jogging!

We introduce people to jogging and getting fit. The program gradually moves you from walking at your own pace to jogging at your own pace.

results.description:
How awesome was the 3rd Birthday Party in March?! Many thanks again to General Assembly Boston for hosting.

This month, we are lucky to be joined by two rockstar Dockers: Ryan Wallner from ClusterHQ and Abdelrahman Hosny from the University of Connecticut Bioinformatics Department.

UCONN Bioinformatics & Docker

[AH] We have utilized Docker in our research lab to solve one of our nightmare problems – algorithms reproducibility. We have created a solution called AlgoRun to easily package algorithms in Docker containers. We are now polishing another product called AlgoPiper to connect packaged algorithms into meaningful pipelines and workflows. Both projects are open source and the code is available on GitHub. 


ClusterHQ on Flocker


[RW] In this talk, we’ll demonstrate the ease of deploying and managing a multi-container stateful application in your Docker environment using Machine, Compose, and Swarm. We’ll first introduce Flocker, a container data volume manager, and cover the latest features available in v1.11.

After installing Flocker, we’ll provision a Swarm cluster that uses Consul. Once set up, we’ll create a multi-host Cassandra cluster for our deployment. We’ll walk-through how to access the containers in the cluster and how Flocker enables persistent services to move around the cluster in the case of failure or scheduled maintenance.


About: Abdelrahman Hosny

I’m a full-time learner in the field of computer science and a part-time teacher for computers raising them to mimic humans. Technology for better living is my life philosophy. 

http://www.abdelrahmanhosny.me

About: Ryan Wallner

Ryan is a Technical Evangelist for ClusterHQ focused on the developer community, integration and tooling around containers and persistence. Previously, Ryan was a software engineer at the EMC and IBM. You can find Ryan at many of the Boston area meetups and can tweet him at @RyanWallner.
results.name: Docker Boston April Meetup: Flocker & a Bioinformatics Use Case

results.description:
While women have made great strides in science it has not come without a cost. Women come in to science later, leave earlier and express more discontent with their choices than their male counter parts. Why? A large part is the hold over culture from early days helps people avoid the burn out that all people experience in high end careers are more geared towards men. While this was not intentional, it is just that men were the entire crowd back then, women need ways to tackle the burn out factor that are specific to the way they live their lives. Planning the career track, working their way up the ladder and being a productive and valued team member are done differently between men and women. This talk focuses on how women can take steps in their journey to identify their specific areas of burn out, how to tackle them and how to move forward in the face of burn out.

Learning Objectives
- Setting a career plan
- Using your mentoring network
- Identifying common “burn out” causes and what to do about them
- Working around, through and past difficult steps
- How to relax and have fun in your career

About the Speaker
Heather S. Duffy, JD PhD is an internationally known cardiovascular researcher who began to develop trainee career development workshops as a way to enhance her student's career trajectories. The workshops were so successful, with her students winning top prizes in academic competitions, that she expanded the series to other groups. To date these workshops have been presented locally, nationally and even at international conferences. Dr. Duffy got her PhD in neuroscience from Albert Einstein College of Medicine in the Bronx, NY. She went on to her first independent faculty position at Columbia University College of Surgeons and Physicians where she worked on cardiac arrhythmias. After being recruited to Harvard Medical School Dr. Duffy became involved in the Harvard Leadership Program and was active in the development of workshops and curricula designed to maximize student and postdoctoral potential in the Cardiovascular Department. Additionally, as co-chair of the Early Career Committee for the Basic Cardiovascular Science council for the American Heart Association, Dr Duffy has helps hundreds of students and postdocs become better scientific professionals. In her latest adventure Dr. Duffy received her JD degree focusing on technology transfer, intellectual property protection and development of discovery for inventors interested in commercializing their discoveries.

Dr. Duffy is the author of over 50 publications and is a renowned speaker both nationally and internationally with dozens of talks under her belt. Date and Time:
April 28, 2016
6:00 - 8:30 PM

Agenda:

5:50-6:10pm: Registration, mingling, and light dinner
6:10-6:30pm: Facilitated networking
6:30-8:00pm: Workshop
8:00-8:30pm: Optional networking

Location:
Novartis Institutes for BioMedical Research, 220 Massachusetts Avenue, Cambridge, MA 02139

Cost:
Members: $35; Non-Members: $55, Workshop and Annual Membership: $120

A light dinner will be served. http://www.westorg.org/2016-04-28-burnout
results.name: Women in Science and the Burn Out Factor

results.description:
For our first Meetup for 2016, we’re excited to host special guests from the U.S. Patent and Trademark Office to discuss protecting your idea in its infant stages, and allowing you to enjoy the fruits of your labor.


The goal of this Meetup is to have an in-depth discussion about the patent and trademark processes. To address the how-to’s, the importance of submitting a clear, sensible, and sound application, and the cost of protecting your intellectual property. 

We'll also hear first hand from Boston entrepreneurs who have been approved for patents, what that meant for their business, and the long-run health of their operations.

Food - We will have pizza and salad available. 

Parking - While the T is close by, if you need to park there are three lots of garages available around the area. Click here to see the results.

___________________________________________________

We'll begin with presentations from both the patent and trademark offices. 

As part of the panel discussion, we'll cover -

·  When is the right time to apply for me to apply for a patent or trademark? 
·  What are the different kinds of patents available? Which should I apply for? 
·  What are the best practices for applying for a patent or trademark? 
·  What is Intellectual Property worth today? How do I protect it? 
·  How soon should I apply for a patent? 
·  Will “Patent Pending” protect my business?
·  Is speed the new IP?

Guests + Panelists: 

Elizabeth Dougherty is the Director of Inventor Education, Outreach, and Recognition in the Office of Innovation Development at the United States Patent and Trademark Office (USPTO). In this capacity, she develops, implements, and supervises programs that support the independent inventor community, small businesses, entrepreneurs, and the intellectual property interests of colleges and universities. Elizabeth has spearheaded a number of special projects with federal, state and local governments, and private organizations to promote and support invention and innovation in the United States. She oversees a portfolio of ongoing and future initiatives designed to assist independent inventors, entrepreneurs, and underserved communities.

Scott Baldwin is a trademark attorney in the Office of Trademark Quality Review and Training (OTQRT).  Prior to joining the OTQRT, he was an attorney in the USPTO’s Global Intellectual Property Academy (GIPA) where he conducted capacity-building programs in the United States and around the world on intellectual property protection and enforcement.  Prior to that position, he served as a trademark attorney with the USPTO’s Office of Policy and International Affairs (OPIA) where he handled policy matters relating to trademark issues in the United States and abroad and provided technical assistance to foreign governments that wanted to develop or improve their trademark systems.  Scott also was a Trademark Examining Attorney at the USPTO.  

Nancy Dussault Smith started her career in consumer technology in 2001 when she joined a small robot company in Somerville, MA.  She quickly fell in love with the fast paced start-up environment where ideas quickly turned to products. After successfully launching Roomba in 2002, she went on to lead iRobots global marketing efforts for more than a decade. In 2014 she left the robot world behind and co-founded Lineage Labs, makers of Bevy—a smart photo system designed for families, where she continues to create and market new technologies designed to change our world. A list of her patents can be found here. 

Schedule

6:00 - 6:30: Mingle + Food

6:30 - 7:45: Presentations

7:45 - 8:30: Q+A


8:30 - 9:00: Mingle + Thank You's


Sponsors

Thank you to The Grommet for their support in marketing and sponsoring food for this event. The most innovative, exciting products—and the Makers, inventors, and entrepreneurs behind them—deserve a voice. That’s where The Grommet comes in. The Grommet is your online shop for discovering independent Makers. Every weekday they reveal innovative new products, hand picked by our experts for you.


Thank you in part to C Space for allowing us to use their space!

results.description:
Join us for a fun, stimulating evening of group critique and discussion. All attending this session are encouraged to bring in a response to the assignment given out at workshop on April 15th: to translate a poem from another language into English. (This can be widely interpreted; for example, you might translate an excerpt from a prose text from Spanish into an English-language sonnet, by adding new line breaks. "Translations", "versions", "adaptations", and "trots" are all welcome.)

New members are always welcome. We'll be prepared to discuss work in any genre, prose or verse. Bring enough copies of the text you’d like to discuss for each workshop attendee to have their own. If you do not have the means to make copies, send the text by attachment to bostonpoetryunion (at) gmail (dot) com not later than the night before the workshop.

Occasionally, the moderator will invite a member or guest speaker to open the session with a brief talk on some literary topic. If you’re interested in delivering such a talk, email the organizers and let them know! We are similarly open to suggestions for writing exercises, discussions at members' homes, visits to readings or bookstores, and other events of interest to writers.

ABOUT THE WORKSHOP: Now in its 14th year, the weekly Boston Poetry workshop (formerly “Charles River Writers”) is an open, accessible, and welcoming forum for literary fellowship and discussion. Please note: In 2016, our Thursday night workshops will run in six-week blocks, in winter, spring, summer, and fall.

results.description:
Register today to receive an advance purchase discount: http://bit.ly/160428mtup


Whether you're a marketer or a product manager who wants to learn about marketing trends, this event is for you. Marketing is undergoing unprecedented change and vibrancy in organizations. From the “arts and crafts” department not so many years ago, today’s modern marketing organizations are data-driven and technology-enabled teams that are the engines of growth for their companies. It’s no time for marketers to get comfortable. Change is everywhere and organizations that embrace modern marketing practices are leaving their competitors in the dust.

Join Brian Kardon, one of the most successful Chief Marketers in the country, for a discussion on the what and how of modern marketing:

- How do Boards and CEOs measure the value and impact of marketing?
- What new technologies are most and least effective?
- What are the desirable skills and behaviors of successful marketers and marketing teams?
- What is the role of analytics in marketing success?
- How should marketing and sales team align? Timeline for the evening

6:15 pm: Registration opens
6:30 - 7:30 pm: Networking (light refreshments)
7:30 - 8:30 pm: Presentation
8:30 - 9:00 pm: Wrap Up and Additional Networking

IMPORTANT: There is a fee for this event. Please register in advance on the following page to receive the discounted advance price of $20 or no charge for BPMA premium members: http://bit.ly/160428mtup

About the Speaker

Brian Kardon, Chief Marketing Officer at Fuze


Brian is a results-oriented marketing executive with more than 20 years of experience creating and implementing successful growth strategies. His experience ranges from startups to global, billion-dollar organizations. Brian is a persuasive communicator with a proven history of accelerating revenue growth, penetrating new markets, and developing products people love.

He is a respected mentor and coach skilled in driving performance-based cultures and developing talent. Brian expertly leads globally distributed teams spanning North America, Europe and Asia.

Brian was recently named a Top 10 Global CMO for companies <$250 million revenue by The CMO Institute and Top 15 CMO on Twitter by Social Media Marketing Magazine. He is also among the Top 50 Most Influential People in Sales Lead Management, named by the Sales Lead Management Association.
results.name: Modern Marketing: A Blueprint for Success

Divorce Basics Monthly Series: Are you ready to date? Learn about finding love again through online dating in this fun and interactive workshop led by Susan D. Trotter, PhD, Therapist and Relationship Coach. You will come away with a variety of tools that you will be able to utilize immediately and in the future in your search for love. The focus of this workshop is how to have more fun and greater success with online dating. Learn how to approach dating again and in the online context including setting up a profile and managing responses. 

There is no cost for attendance. Complimentary refreshments and snacks will be provided. Space is limited, so RSVP to reserve your spot. Please change your RSVP right away if your plans change so that someone on the waiting list can take your spot.

This event is intended to be partly informational, partly social, and totally empowering. It will be casual/interactive and not formal, which is a setting that attendees of these events really like. The attendees have the opportunity to ask questions in the group setting, as well as ask the professionals questions one on one during the mix and mingle time towards the end. At this event, there will also be David Kellem, Divorce Attorney & Mediator; Bob Vona and Samantha Steer, Financial Advisors; and Sheila May, CPA and forensic accountant to answer your questions.

When: Thursday April 28th 6:30 – 8:30 p.m. & Saturday March 30th 12 – 2 p.m. Both dates are the same event (Meetups listed separately). Choose the time and date convenient for you.

Similar Divorce Basics Monthly Series events will be held at this location on the fourth Thursday and fourth Saturday of every month. Please check the calendar for these upcoming events:

Divorce Basics Monthly Series: Are you ready to date? Learn about finding love again through online dating in this fun and interactive workshop led by Susan D. Trotter, PhD, Therapist and Relationship Coach. You will come away with a variety of tools that you will be able to utilize immediately and in the future in your search for love. The focus of this workshop is how to have more fun and greater success with online dating. Learn how to approach dating again and in the online context including setting up a profile and managing responses. 

There is no cost for attendance. Complimentary refreshments and snacks will be provided. Space is limited, so RSVP to reserve your spot. Please change your RSVP right away if your plans change so that someone on the waiting list can take your spot.

This event is intended to be partly informational, partly social, and totally empowering. It will be casual/interactive and not formal, which is a setting that attendees of these events really like. The attendees have the opportunity to ask questions in the group setting, as well as ask the professionals questions one on one during the mix and mingle time towards the end. At this event, there will also be David Kellem, Divorce Attorney & Mediator; Bob Vona and Samantha Steer, Financial Advisors; and Sheila May, CPA and forensic accountant to answer your questions.

When: Thursday April 28th 6:30 – 8:30 p.m. & Saturday March 30th 12 – 2 p.m. Both dates are the same event (Meetups listed separately). Choose the time and date convenient for you.

Similar Divorce Basics Monthly Series events will be held at this location on the fourth Thursday and fourth Saturday of every month. Please check the calendar for these upcoming events:

• Thursday, May 19 & Saturday, May 21, 2016 (3rd Thursday & Saturday this month, because of Memorial Day). A Legal Overview of the Divorce Process. With David Kellem, Divorce Attorney & Mediator

• Thursday, June 23 & Saturday, June 25, 2016. The House -- Should you try to keep it or sell it; what to consider.

• Thursday, July 21 & Saturday, July 23, 2016. Emotional Issues in Divorce; Is there such a thing as emotional justice?
results.how_to_find_us: The event will be on the 2nd floor. Call or text Deanna at 508-333-3191 to RSVP directly or to ask questions/get directions.
results.name: Divorce Basics: Finding Love Again through Online Dating

results.description:
Customer Development in Practice

Knowing what customers want is critical for success.  Customer development is the process of finding this out.  Anyone who has tried this knows it’s not as easy as reading The Lean Startup.  As Yogi Berra said, “In theory, there’s no difference between theory and practice.  In practice, there is.” 

Join us as Tom Huntington shares his customer development journey as co-founder of Windshield.  You’ll hear about ways to collect data, ways to get inside customers’ heads and ways to get out of your own.

Customer development is a skill to be practiced.  Following Tom’s talk, we’ll use a speed dating format to practice customer development interviewing.  As a side benefit, this exercise will generate data for anyone that comes armed with an applicable market to research.

We'll be on 10th floor at NERD
results.name: Business Model Generation Monthly Meetup

Every Thursday evening at 6:30 PM we gather as a group for a nice nighttime "romp" at the Chestnut Hill Reservoir. It's a great way to wind down a busy work day, to catch up with Bulldogs friends, or to meet new people!

The Boston Bulldogs is a co-ed non-profit running club founded to support those battling addiction and in recovery, those who have been affected by addiction and their supporters.

We welcome and encourage runners of all levels – dreamers, beginners, as well as those with running experience, past or present. Our volunteer runners will be there to coach you at your current level, and help you meet your goals. We might even be able to help with running gear if needed. 

We meet twice weekly at the Reservoir (Cleveland Circle/Reservoir Green Line C or D train) -- on Saturday mornings at 10:00 am and Thursday evenings at 6:30 pm. We will first gather in front of the Starbucks in Cleveland Circle, before heading over to the reservoir. See you there! 

If you are interested in becoming a member or a volunteer, in making a contribution to the Club, in sponsoring a runner in recovery, or in learning more about the Boston Bulldog educational wellness/running program, contact us at:

• Website - BostonBulldogsRunning.com

• Email - [masked] 

• Phone -[masked]

results.description:
Boston’s Market District came into its own with Faneuil Hall in 1742, followed by Quincy Market in 1826. Today’s Haymarket began as an expansion of Quincy Market in the 1830s, and has since witnessed enormous changes in streetscape and demographics. Through it all, the district has served a constant stream of longtime residents, immigrant families, students and tourists. For much of the 1900s, Italian produce vendors’ pushcarts lined both sides of Blackstone Street. Today, Haymarket includes halal butchers, artisanal cheese mongers, and Cambodian fruit sellers. Don’t miss this illustrated lecture by Historic New England’s Kenneth Turino to learn about the vibrant Market District yesterday and today. Book sales and signing will follow the lecture.

Free but registration is requested.  To register click here.


Event by Old South Meeting House and Historic New England
results.name: Boston’s Market District and Haymarket: Yesterday and Today

results.description:
We'll learn about "4X" Games and play one: Settlers of Cataan

There's a particular genre of strategy games that is particularly fertile ground for discussing racism and whiteness. "4X" stands for a set of four game mechanics that often come together: explore, expand, exploit, and exterminate. The four "X" mechanisms are quite similar to the "strategy" of white colonialism. Let's spend some time thinking about race in the context of a 4X game.


Settlers of Cataan focuses on expand and exploit.


Plan for the time: we'll talk about the concept, play the game, and discuss our experiences. Possible questions to consider:


>>What kind of behaviors/thinking/priorities does this game reward? How does the game position the players in relation to colonialism and white supremacy?


>>Is whiteness visible in the game? How?

>>Is larger humanity visible? How? What assumptions does the game make about the identities of the players? What's the audience? Who is not included in the audience?

>>What does the game position as"valuable"? How is value measured? What does the game say about availability and use of resources? What might it look like to subvert/invert the 4x mechanisms?

Accessibility Information: Community Change, Inc. is wheelchair accessible with the following limitations. The door to the building is heavy and does not have a button to open it. The elevator doors are slightly more than 30 inches wide. The fourth floor bathrooms are not wheelchair accessible, but the first floor bathroom is. Please let us know your needs so we can help make the event accessible for you.

Note: We welcome bike riders, though there are not many good spots for parking bikes, and bicycles are prohibited in the building. We apologize for the inconvenience.
results.name: Expanding and Exploiting: All in the Game

Please RSVP for this game so we know we have enough people. We'll confirm by 3pm or earlier that the game is on.


6:45-7:00 pm - Warm up & practice, we'll work on some throws, passes & catches.

7:00 pm - Game starts.

General guidelines: Dress accordingly. Bring a white & dark shirt so we can easily divide into 2 teams. Have plenty of water. Sunscreen on a sunny day. Stretch & warm up. We'll provide discs and cones.

Weather: Rain in New England is unpredictable. We will send out a final notice one hour before start time if cancellation is necessary.

RSVP: Very helpful as this is how we contact you in case of game changes & cancellations.

About: Playing Ultimate is all about good sportsmanship, respect, and gracefulness on the field.  Fun & having a good time is a must above anything else. It's an easy game to pick up & we keep the rules minimal. No zones, no stall count, no scores, and players self-officiate on the field.  Open to all levels of players.  Beginners welcome.

Warning: Excessive fun & comradery developed from playing Ultimate may become addicting.

results.description:
Cambridge meetup is back! We are going to have this event every other week!


http://www.championscambridge.com/


As usual, please bring your driver's license or passport, if you would like to have alcohol. They are strict about IDs, No IDs no booze.  But people under 21 are welcome as well to this event  - Champions is almost as much a restaurant as a bar and you need not order a drink.


You are responsible for your own consumption and please start and settle your own tab. Please bring your Credit/Debit card or cash and start your tab with the waiter.    Please be sure to tip - we suggest 20% as it is a lot of extra trouble for them to do separate tabs, but it saves us work and allows people to leave at different times.  But first be sure that the tip is not included already - it usually is not but occasionally is, at 18%, if there is a large group, in which case you need not tip additional.  (If you know the price of what you ordered, and add 7% MA meals tax, and that is the total, they have NOT added in the tip.)

RSVP required. Please sign up. If you RSVP "Yes," but your plans change, please change your RSVP to "No" so others can sign up. Deadline for reservation is 3PM as we need to get an accurate head count for the reservation. On nights when we are expecting many people, we limit the RSVP number to 27. However, if you'd like to attend, but can't RSVP, send a message to an organizer, as we may be able to get you in.


Champions is located at MIT/Kendall Sq. station. If you come from Boston side, you will see right in front of the T exit. It is part of the Marriott. Even though the address is listed as 50 Broadway, you can really only see it from the Main street side.  We are usually either in the separate room toward the Marriott lobby, or else at two long central tables in the room to the right of the host station.
results.how_to_find_us: We usually make a reservation. Please RSVP by 3pm on the day of the event. Ask hostess for Japanese/English Meetup group.

results.description:
Amazing folk dance and drum performance !!

Let the beating up of ‘parai’ destroy dominance'
Performance by Orulai Dalit Art Cultural Group, Tamil Nadu, India
The Hindu caste system constructs parai drummers and their drum as polluted. The form is associated by many with the drummers' “degraded” caste name (Paraiyar). The Parai, until a few years ago, was an “untouchable" instrument. Despite a rich legacy, ‘parai aattam’ has been pushed to the margins as a polluted form of art.

But the art form has developed into a potent weapon in resurgent anti-caste liberation movements in India. "Orulai Dalit Art Cultural Group", from Tamil Nadu, India is an example. In their own words "This parai drumming is not for funerals but for liberation. Our performance is a message aimed at re-signifying ‘parai’ as a symbol of self-respect and assertion. Let the beating up of ‘parai’ destroy the dominance; let it break down not the parai but the Indian caste hierarchy."

The Orulai Dalit Art Cultural Group will perform music and folk dances like karagattam, kummi and oiylattam, oppari funeral lament, and drumming as well as feature the voices of the drummers. They will highlight the stunningly symphonic rendition of the traditional folk beat, the Thappattam. Perhaps one of the oldest of the indigenous folk arts, ‘parai aattam’ embraces life in all its forms — birth, puberty, engagement, marriage and death.
results.name: Parai: The Rhythm of Liberation

results.description:
Expected to be in attendance: Director James Demo, Producer Johno Mulrooney, and subject Padraig O'Malley

THE PEACEMAKER follows international peacemaker Padraig O'Malley, who helps make peace for others but struggles to find it for himself. The film takes us from Padraig's isolated life in Cambridge, Massachusetts to some of the most dangerous crisis zones on Earth—from Northern Ireland to Kosovo, Nigeria to Iraq—over five years as he works a peacemaking model based on his recovery from addiction. We meet Padraig in the third act of his life in a race against time to find some kind of salvation for both the world and himself.

See you at the Festival,

John

results.description:
This class combines two powerful tools, Energy Healing and Mindful Meditation, allowing us to reach a higher and more divine connection. Ron Crocco will demonstrate several techniques used in the practice of energy healing. These powerful tools are meant to assist you in your own sense well-being as well as to incorporate into your own practice. In addition, he will share some powerful meditation guidelines to enhance your meditation practice and bring it to the next level.

To learn more and registered (required): http://www.circlesofwisdom.com/workshops/sp/the-magic-of-energy-healing-mindful-meditation/

Energy healing is based on the principle that dis-ease is primarily caused by physical blockages interrupting the body’s natural flow, “chi” or prana. Together we will learn some of these techniques and discover how to release blockages and restore the body’s natural ability to heal. Following this we move into our Meditation or “sitting in stillness” where you will now find an increased or more profound state of relaxation. Combining these two practices often raises our internal energy or Life Force (Chi, Ki, Prana) allowing us to experience a deeper sense of serenity. This, in turn, can bring about a more insightful quality of consciousness, increasing our ability to give and receive healing, develop patience, compassion and increase our sense of wellbeing.

Join us for this wonderful class as we come together experiencing the power of our healing energy, connecting to the Divine and raising our vibration.

*Energy Healing practitioners do not diagnose, prescribe, promise cures or interfere with Traditional Medical Treatment. This is only meant to provide additional complimentary pathways to health.

results.description:
We have two talks for Django Boston tonight. 

Tom Achtemichuk: Testing Django Applications: Practices, Patterns, and Libraries

A whirlwind tour of libraries, patterns and best practices for testing Django applications. Including factories, unit & integration tests and BDD using pytest, factory_boy and pytest-bdd.

About the speaker:

Tom Achtemichuk, Technology Lead at Sonicbids. 10+ year Python dev, with a dozen or so large-scale, long-lived Django projects under his belt (dating back to Django 0.96) for a variety of startups, media companies and ecommerce operations. Current interests (besides testing) include Elasticsearch, AWS Lambda & Django Channels.

Bill Blanchard: Django ORM: Beyond the Basics

In this talk, we will be taking a look at how you can leverage the ORM to do more powerful queries using tools such as Q objects, querying across model relations, field lookups, and the QuerySet API.  The target audience for this talk is those who have 0 - 1.5 years experience with Django and have at least completed the tutorial.

About the speaker:

Bill Blanchard is a Django developer and partner at Plumb Development in Portsmouth, NH.  Coming from an infrastructure background, Bill made the switch to Django development 2 1/2 years ago.  By combining his skills, Bill provides IAAS and DevOps services in addition to developing web applications for Aviation, Localization, and Technology companies.

Sponsors:

Space and pizza provided by Akamai.

Social event sponsorship is still open for this event. Contact the organizers if you are interested in sponsoring drinks.
results.name: Two Talks: Testing Django Apps and ORM:Beyond the Basics

results.description:
Thursday, April 28
7:30 PM, Fox Library Community Room
The Top Ten Birding Locations in Central Mass: A Very Personal Countdown
Central Massachusetts is a huge region stretching from the eastern border of Worcester County to the Connecticut River Valley. Here there are numerous tracts of forest, quite a number of rivers, some premier grasslands and marshes, and the two largest freshwater bodies in the state. In fall and spring, hawks, nighthawks and passerines move through in large numbers and many species stay in the area to breed. Central Massachusetts offers the birder a wide variety of quality birding destinations yet remains almost unknown to many birders who live in the eastern parts of the state. Tonight, Mark Lynch and Sheila Carroll will reveal a very personal list of their TOP TEN BIRDING SPOTS IN CENTRAL MASSACHUSETTS arrived after almost 40 years of birding the area.
results.name: Meeting: The Top Ten Birding Locations in Central Mass

results.description:
Join us to eat, drink, write, share work, trade author/book recommendations, and more!

Thursday Format:
After a round of introductions, we start out with a general, unstructured freewrite to get everyone in the writing mindset. We continue writing to a series of three or so writing prompts that usually one of the organizers has prepared before hand. Members are encouraged to share their work, or what they wrote about, for each prompt. We spend the remainder of the group working on our own separate projects, continuing work from one of the prompts, freewriting, or just chatting with each other.

When we have a piece to workshop, we often will write to two or so prompts, and then will go into a discussion of that piece. The workshop may take up the rest of the group, or may conclude with time left at the end.


Read more about workshops here.

results.description:
Native Peoples, Native Politics

Event link HERE. This event is free and open to the public, however, registration is required (open in March).

Friday, Apr 29th, 2016, 9am

Knafel Center (Radcliffe Institute at Harvard)

10 Garden Street, Cambridge

:: :: ::

Politics requires more than voting and electoral mobilization. It requires knowledge of law, organization, identity, history, and culture. This reality is very much evident in Native American life today, where Native communities are sovereign nations within the United States, yet must still negotiate politically within a federal democratic system that inconsistently honors their rights, their land and water, and their ways of life. 


The Radcliffe Institute, in partnership with the Harvard University Native American Program, is hosting this conference to explore a range of mechanisms for political expression with leading members of Native communities, academics, policy makers, journalists, students, artists, and writers.
results.name: Native Peoples (conference)

Members (those paying the $25 monthly membership fee) may reserve a spot for $75, non-members for $90.    Four hours each Friday morning, 10:00- 2:00pm. You can come individual days by paying $20 (members) or $30 (non-members) for a single drop-in, but please consider paying for the full amount and committing to come!  It will help us to keep these long sessions going, and even if you pay for the whole session and don't come to all of them (often happens), you're getting a pretty square deal.  If you would like to pay online please do so at

PLEASE NOTE THE PRICES BELOW- They are deliberately a bit higher than for drawing sessions as we keep the studio less crowded for painting, and it's more work to put together a four week pose.

results.description:
What Is Islam? A Symposium in Memory of Shahab Ahmed

Free and open to the public. Event link HERE.

Friday, April 29th, 1-6:30pm

Fong Auditorium, Boylston Hall


:: :: ::

Committee on Medieval Studies, the Mahindra Humanities Center, the Center for Middle Eastern Studies, the Aga Khan Program for Islamic Architecture, the Committee on the Study of Religion, with support of the Rabbi Joseph S. Shubow Memorial Fund, the South Asia Initiative, the Department of Near Eastern Languages and Civilizations, the Prince Alwaleed bin Talal Islamic Studies Program, and the Islamic Legal Studies Program

Speakers: MIchael Cook, Noah Feldman, Cemal Kafadar, Gülru Necipoğlu, Parimal Patil, and Nicholas Watson

Contact: Committee on Medieval Studies: [masked] or[masked]

This symposium honors the memory of Harvard Religion and Islamic Studies scholar Shahab Ahmed. Despite Shahab's death in 2015, the subsequent publication of his groundbreaking and challenging book "What Is Islam? The Importance of Being Islamic" (Princeton University Press) offers a wonderful opportunity to consider his intellectual legacy from a variety of disciplinary perspectives.

Join Nourishing the North Shore for their first "Pitch In" event at <a>Mehaffey Farm</a> in Rowley, MA. 

Time has come to plant onions and the Mehaffey family has no shortage of them! So, Nourishing the North Shore's Pitch In program is here to lend a hand and make lighter work. We will be helping the Mehaffey family plant the season onion crop.

If you would like Pitch In please respond here or to [masked] so they can get a head count.

Spread the word - all are welcome! Wear work clothes, bring a water bottle, and sunscreen/hat are suggested. If you have any questions feel free to call Kailey the Program Coordinator at <a>[masked]</a>.


About Mehaffey Farm: The Mehaffey family has lived on the land since 1826. The house and barn date back to the early 1700s. The farm’s original 300 acres provided a sustainable living for several generations. With a new generation of farmers, we are combining new advances in agriculture with time-honored practices to provide our community with healthy alternatives to our broken food system.

About Nourishing the North Shore:  Nourishing the North Shore strives to build a strong community food system that integrates production, processing, distribution, and consumption in a manner that enhances the social, environmental, nutritional, and economic health across all income levels. They build and maintain community gardens, develop and lead educational programs, support local farmers, create access channels to healthy food, work directly with community members, Innovate and challenge the industrial food system

results.description:
Our schedule is now LIVE! 

Join us on Friday April 29, 2016 for the 15th UXPA Boston Annual Conference at the Sheraton Boston, Boston, MA. Hear and discuss critical topics in usability and user-centered design with practitioners, students, and experts in the field. Whether a newcomer, a seasoned user experience professional, or a member of a product team interested in usability, this conference offers unique content and one-of-a-kind learning opportunities.

We expect more than 900 industry professionals to attend and we will close registration when full. Sign up today! This is the place to be for learning about best practices for user-centered product development, usability research, and real-world case studies from website, mobile device, software, healthcare, globalization and other fields!

Over 30 speakers, plus many opportunities to make new professional connections. 

This conference has an unprecedented number of presentations going on to provide a greater diversity of session topics. The conference will have four simultaneous tracks + an unconference track, giving you a choice of almost 30 presentations. Topics are relevant to thought-leaders, designers, developers, usability professionals, usability novices, and others. There's something for everyone!

Amazing Sponsors!

This year the event will have even more sponsors giving attendees the opportunity to network and discover companies that are hiring, meet local design and usability organizations, and try out new technologies and products. Many sponsorships include conference admission as part of the package. We encourage large employers, agencies and recruiters to gain additional exposure by sponsoring. 

Joining UXPA International

UXPA Boston is a local chapter of UXPA International. While membership in the Boston chapter is free, we encourage you to join UXPA International to receive global benefits, discounts to UXPA chapter events, and to support the sustained practice of UX worldwide.

Financial Hardship

If you are a potential attendee of the conference and would incur financial hardship paying the registration fee, there are several options we may suggest. Volunteers and primary presenters have their registration fees waived so we invite you to sign up as a volunteer - sorry, call for volunteers is over. (We expect there will be 10-20 volunteer positions available.) If neither of these options is possible, email us at [masked] and we’ll see what accommodations can be made. All inquiries will be handled with discretion.

Refunds

Attendees may request a full refund through Eventbrite up to two weeks before the conference. Attendees can transfer their registration to another attendee up to the night before the conference.

Attendee changes made within two weeks of the conference will not be reflected on name tags. Please ask for a new name tag at registration.

Code of Conduct

Anyone attending a UXPA Boston event is expected to review and ahere to our code of conduct. 

<a href="http://www.eventbrite.com/e/uxpa-boston-15th-annual-user-experience-conference-tickets-21283518577"></a>

results.description:
JOIN US FOR OUR SECOND INSTALLMENT OF THE CANOPY STARTUP SESSIONS 

PRESENTED BY VELIR & GESMER UPDEGROVE

WITH ADDITIONAL SUPPORT PROVIDED BY 

APPLAUSE | BIGFISH PR | TRINET


The Canopy Startup Sessions feature the community's top startups--spanning technology, healthcare and social impact--in the heart of Somerville's Davis Square. 

Each startup has three minutes to demo their product in front of a live audience. It's not a pitch but an opportunity for each startup to explain (and show) what they have been working on. After each demo, there is a five min Q&A with the audience. The idea is to foster innovation, ideation and the cross-pollination of ideas.

Afterwards, grab a beer or wine upstairs for a tour of Canopy, a social impact-focused, community co-working space on the third floor!

Presenting Companies

bosWell is a digital health company that is improving the quality of care for the most vulnerable and highest risk individuals in our community, while reducing the cost of life saving interventions. 

MyOncampusChef is a peer-to-peer marketplace that connects students living on campus without a kitchen to students living on/off campus willing to host and cook traditional homemade meals.

Pillar Technologies is leveraging the internet-of-things to predict and prevent an array of costly damages that loom over the heads of property managers, general contractors and insurance companies alike.

PiraShield is an anti-piracy search engine that scans the web to find illegal copies of any given eLearning course and then tactically removes them.

Spatially seeks to understand, describe and predict the forces that influence us all socially, economically, physically and temporally in our urban environments to unlock the potential of every location.

Trext provides an easy and interactive way to reach large groups via responsive text messaging, thus helping to address customers inquiries, send out interactive surveys and more. No programming required.

Voatz enables citizens to vote in all kinds of elections or voting events via a smartphone in the most secure way possible, with the help of advanced biometrics for security and the Blockchain for irrefutability. 

Agenda

5:30 - Doors open in the ground-floor Velir space

6:00 - Demo and Q&A

7:00 - Networking

7:30 - Beer/wine and tours upstairs at Canopy

Directions and parking

By MBTA, take the Red Line to Davis Square Station. Then walk four blocks down Elm Street towards Porter Square, and we are on the right, in the Citizens Bank Building.

For those who are driving there are several surface lots located nearby.

Would you like to present at a future Canopy Startup Session? If so, please email [masked]
results.name: Canopy Startup Sessions

results.description:
Dear Boston Culture Lovers,


The Art in Bloom is back and celebrating 40 years of this exuberant spring weekend-long festival at the MFA.  This joyous rite of spring pairs fine art and floral design with offerings of free guided tours among MFA treasures, plus workshops, demonstrations, and lectures. Garden clubs and professional designers from across New England create floral arrangements inspired by the MFA’s works of art.

http://www.mfa.org/programs/special-event/art-bloom

This event will be for the Sneak Peek Friday event.   Let's be the first to peek at the freshly installed flower arrangements. Please note that the tours are self-guided for the Friday Sneak Peek evet.  The plan is to meet at 5:30 pm in lounge/couch area of the Sharf Visitor Center on the first floor.  Then after we meet and greet, we will explore the special exhibits. 


Since this event will be roaming , it will be very difficult for latecomers to connect with the group. If you are late, I can not guarantee that you will recognize me or fellow members or we  to be able recognize you from the crowds.  Once the event starts, I put away my smartphone and concentrate on enjoying the event with fellow group members. Please plan ahead and allow a little extra travel time to this event.

If you need to familiarize yourself to this location, here is a link to the floor plan: http://mfas3.s3.amazonaws.com/MFA_Map_Sep2015_Level1.pdf

The Art in Bloom events are free with Museum admission. The cost of general admission is $25 ($23 for seniors).  However, you may be able to get a discounted ticket at your local library.

Also, many employers may have discounted or even free tickets for their employees. You may want to check your human resources department if such discounted/free tickets exist for you.  Or consider getting a MFA membership and you have unlimited admission to the museum and skip the long lines.

I strongly recommend that you  take public transportation, the Green E line stops right in front of the museum. Also there are several buses that also stop in front of the museum. Check out these links for more information on getting to the museum:http://www.mfa.org/visit/getting-here, www.mbta.com .

Please only reserve "YES" if you are definitely attending and plan to meet members of the group.  If you reserve "YES" and have a change of plans, please update the attendance reservation.

I look forward to enjoying this event with the group.

Joana
results.how_to_find_us: Lounge/couch area of the Sharf Visitors Center on the first floor inside the museum
results.name: Friday Sneak Peek Event at the Art in Bloom Festival at the MFA

results.description:
The Nave, the organization that hosts Wrap Around,will be opening a fiber art exhibition this Friday. Please come on by and check out this great show!

Embroidered Truths & Woven Tales is the latest iteration of the Nave’s annual focus on fiber. This eclectic exhibition explores the way that 16 artists use fiber techniques–embroidery, crochet, knitting, weaving, soft sculpture–in combination with traditional or unusual materials – silk, salvaged or repurposed items, yarn, hair, and printed paper – to reveal a hint of a story or tell an elaborate tale. The work ranges from elegant to rambunctious; themes include family history, environmental activism, gender politics, and more. 

Full details: http://navegallery.org/wp/embroidered-truths-woven-tales/

NOTE: This is happening at our Davis Square location, right next to Red Bones.
results.name: Opening Reception: Embroidered Truths & Woven Tales

results.description:
For some time I was curious about a small place in Weymouth's Columbian Square. After reading about their unusual combination of offerings (pizza and sandwiches, but also specialties like shepherd's pie and beef bourguignon), as well as their careful attention to customer service, I found myself intrigued and wanting to know more. Finally one late afternoon I was in the area and stopped by for an early dinner to check them out.

I can now say that, based on my limited experience, the things I was reading online were pretty accurate: Cece's is a small place whose business seems to be mainly takeout and catering, but they do have just enough room for the occasional customer (or several) who wants to come in, sit down, and enjoy either a hot sandwich, a well made pizza, or a meal that is just a little bit out of the ordinary for its location and price range.


Anyone who'd care to join me as I broaden my knowledge of Cece's eclectic menu is welcome to do so on Friday, April 29th at 6:30. Park on the street, then poke your head into the restaurant. Our group should be easy to spot!

Special Note: I try not to limit attendance at events, but I'm going to limit this to six people for now. If many more people than that seem to be interested, I'll contact the restaurant and see just how big a group they can manage.


~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~

Cece's Pizza and Catering
Friday, April 29th, 2016 @ 6:30 PM
 4 Union St (in Columbian Square)
Weymouth, MA 02190
(781)[masked]
Website: <a>Cece's Pizza and Catering</a>


Organizer: Mike

Guests: 1 per member allowed: Contact me with questions about exceptions.


Price Range: A couple of their specialty pizzas are $14.95. Everything else is less. This is a pretty economical place to eat. Have a look at their online menu.


Event Fee: The single-event fee for members and guests is $2.00. No event fee for Annual Members.


Cash Only Policy: Please bring cash! Paying for all of our meals in cash has been SSDOMG'S policy for over nine years. It allows us to avoid the confusion of having the waitstaff run multiple credit card slips and generally helps to keep things simpler for everyone.

RSVP Deadline: Thursday, April 28th at @ 7:00 PM. Any changes made after this time may not be seen by the Event Organizer. Please see our no-show policy below.


No-Show Policy: We have updated and greatly simplified our no-show policy. People who RSVP "Yes" to events are expected to exercise common sense and common courtesy. That means making your best effort to keep any commitments that you make, but if necessary doing your best to notify the Event Organizer or (preferably, if it's the day of the event) the venue if something comes up after the RSVP deadline. If you find yourself unable to attend an event that you've RSVPed "Yes" to and you cannot either change your RSVP or let the venue know, please do contact the Event Organizer when you're able to, just to let us know that you're okay and that you're still interested in attending events.


~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~

Directions: Cece's is located in Columbian Square in South Weymouth, on the corner of Union St and Pleasant St.

results.description: Join our celebration as we project several of the films that will be highlighted in a National Museum of the American Indian Smithsonian in September. We invite you to discover these youth-produced films about Maya life. See rural Guatemalan culture through the lens of film students 12 to 18 years old. Witness videography, directing and editing learned in the workshops "Unlocking Silent Histories". We will join together at 6:30 PM for an introduction to Unlocking Silent Histories. Next, 3 short documentaries will be screened. Finally, we will engage in an open dialogue about the films and the USH educational process, that is a youth-led, peer-learning opporutnity. Through employing a video ethnography process, the youth produce short documentaries that capture, represent, and revitalize their disappearing cultural knowledges, traditions, and languages.

results.description:
Kangoo Jumps is one of the latest fitness crazes catching on across the country.  It's an amazing workout for people who are interested in losing weight and building strength. Great for those who want a high intensity cardio workout with far less impact to their joints. Kangoo jumps can burn up to 50% more calories than traditional workouts.

                                                    Meetup Details:


Organizer/Event Host:
Jenna  (SHC)

Kangoo Jumps Instructor:
Wendel C.

Sponsored by:
Kangoo Jumps Club - MA.


Choreography Level:
Easy, basic steps, entry level

Cardio Level:
High Intensity Workout

Location:
Abington

Cost:
$15.00 with Kangoo rental - $10.00 without rental, * Special rate pricing avail to SSH&B/SHC members only.


Attendance Limit:
10 members, limit may increase as needed later.

Gear/Clothing:
Bring 2 pairs of thick socks, similar to those you would wear hiking (wool or wicking). Wear supportive clothing, a good sports bra & bring water. 

Kangoo Rental Sizes:

Small - Womens 4-6 or Mens 3-5
Medium - Womens 6-9 Mens 6-8
Large - Womens 10-12 Mens 9-11
XLarge - Womens 12+, Mens 12-15

Action Required After RSVP:
Please add your Kangoo size to the comments board so that I can arrange to have them onsite for the class.


Communications:
I'll arrive on site early and will use the meetup board to communicate. I'll send my contact info to those that RSVP. Please use text when contacting me if poss.


Misc but Important:
- Don't video tape anyone the without their consent, pics are fine

- Don't eat a full meal up to an hour before class.

- Open lockers are right by the front door so leave your valuables in car or at home.

- Bring cash/exact change (if possible) to expedite 

- Bring a snack with you for the ride home.

- Zumba class lets out prior to the Kangoo classes, there may not be much room to in the foyer to wait around for Zuma to end. I like to wait until the Zuma class exits the building before entering.

- You can not just show up at this event without an RSVP. Kangoos are brought to the location based on your RSVP & size + class size must be controlled due to type of activity. 

Prereqs:
Anyone with basic concepts of aerobics, step, boxing or zumba/dance and enjoys a high intensity cardio workout.

Future Kangoo Jump Events:
Kangoo jump weekend hikes will be posted to meetup under Southeastern Hiking Club (SHC) starting in May. 

Disclaimer:
During all events, everyone is responsible for themselves. Meetup hosts, organizers, assistant organizers, leaders, guides and sponsors are not responsible for the safety of participants. By joining the group, you acknowledge and agree to this statement.
results.name: Kangoo Jumps Workout

results.description:
Each and every Friday, we're proud to open the doors of our music school in Central Square for a FREE seminar, demo or meet-up. Hell, we’ll even throw a classical music concert or two. What's in store this week? Let's find out:

Learn the basics of electronic music production in Ableton Live, from creating drum loops and bass lines, to effects, mixing, and even live performance. We will go over the layout of Live's interface and talk about easy to learn techniques to get a song started with instruments and effects included in Ableton Live. This will be a great learning opportunity for aspiring producers looking to make their own electronic music as well as experienced music makers of all styles and skill sets.

Mitchell Owens is a guitar player, sound designer, and electronic composer/producer from Durham, NC. He attended Berklee College of Music right here in Boston and has over 5 years of experience with Ableton Live producing and performing music under the moniker Subalias, as well as doing sound design and soundtrack composition for independent films and animations. Mitchell’s music blends the organic and synthetic for a balanced fusion inspired by sample based Hip­Hop, Downtempo, House, Funk and R&B. He believes in freedom of creation and expression and likes to cater to students’ specific needs in order to teach them the proper skills and techniques needed to achieve their musical goals.
results.name: Intro to Ableton Live [4/29] #FREE

See you there!

results.description:
Please RSVP! This Meetup will fill up fast! There are a limited number of seats in 395.

Technical tools to Scan for the Best Stocks in the Right Sectors at the Right Time

Join John Person as he shares some of his favorite technical tools and proprietary indicators on both Thinkorswim and TradeStation platform that he uses to successfully navigate the equity markets.

Topics will cover Seasonal analysis, Volume and Breadth analysis as well as selective scanning features on both platforms.  

JOHN PERSON, CTA

John Person is a 30-year veteran of the Futures and Options Trading industry. He started on the Floor of the Chicago Mercantile Exchange back in 1979.  John has been an independent Trader, Broker, Analyst and Branch Manager for one of Chicago's largest discount / full service firms under the direct supervision of a former Chairman of the Chicago Board of Trade.

John has shared his wealth of knowledge in the field of technical analysis, his trading style and system development and has taught thousand of traders including members of the largest exchanges. He is the author of three nationally and internationally popular trading books as well as two trading courses and a DVD seminar series.  John authored The Complete Guide to Technical Analysis for the Futures Markets, the first to introduce traders to a powerful combination of candlesticks and pivot point analysis, published by Wiley.

Here is a link to a map of building 6 at MIT: http://whereis.mit.edu/?go=E51  

There is free parking in the E51 lot and across the street in the Hayward St lot.

------------------------------------------------------------------------------------

If you have a friend you talk stocks with, bring them with you! Food or drinks are not allowed in any MIT meeting room. We strongly urge each person to make his or her own decisions about investing their money. Investment ideas and recommendations made during our meetings and in our online dialogs bear no liability by anyone. This is a free and open meeting. No membership is required, but please RSVP.
results.name: Special Speakers Meeting: John Person

• THE BOSTON DRUM CIRCLE

• A high-energy, FUN, celebration of drumming and community. For beginners who want to try something new, their friends, experienced drummers, dancers beginners to experts. NO EXPERIENCE REQUIRED!

• We celebrate the traditions - rhythms that have built energy for hundreds of years for celebration, dance, ritual - just plain FUN! As well as whatever you bring to it!

The cost is $10.00 and many people like to pay before coming. if so, you may use PayPal Here: https://www.paypal.com/cgi-bin/webscr?cmd=_s-xclick&hosted_button_id=D828CV9K4JFV8

We'll have drums to share, and support for newcomers, and energy for everyone.

Recent accolades!

“Great fun! Good rhythms. Very accommodating leader and group for this beginner. Will be back!”

Adrienne S 10/14

It was an amazing experience .. It was nice to feel free from the world and it's problems .. It's was so relaxing, can't wait to drum again ..thanks!

Justin 6/14

Was an awesome experience, I love hand drumming but really the main reason I came was to relieve stress due to family health situations and the circle definitely met my needs. Alan did a great job leading the circle with the drumming and the short history lessons about drumming and Africa. I will be coming back.

Paul 10/13

This Drum Circle is a great stress reliever after a long week of work and I wish it were every Friday night!! Boston Drum Cirlce attracts a wonderful , eclectic group of people that share the common bond of hand drumming. It is always wonderful to have the multi talented Fanta leading the Circle. Her singing, dancing, and drumming are all 5 star. Thank you for a great night of Drumming!

Carla 8/13

We can't wait to meet you! See you soon....

Alan and Fanta

DELICIOUS DINNER

(and Take-Out)

Prepared by

DAVID SNIECKUS

- MACROBIOTIC CHEF AND COUNSELOR -

At 7 p.m.

at David’s, Margaret’s and Abigail's home in Newton, MA

April 29, 2016 Menu

Pressed Cabbage, Red Radish, Ginger and Lemon

Fresh Green Salad
