(See dinner logistics below.)

*********************************************************

Followed by a presentation from 8 to 9:30 pm on

Non-violent Communication; The Language of Life - with Gail Carroll from http://www.nvcboston.org

This will be a brief interactive introduction to Nonviolent Communication (NVC).  NVC is based on the principles of nonviolence-- the natural state of compassion when no violence is present in the heart.

NVC begins by assuming that we are all compassionate by nature and that violent strategies—whether verbal or physical—are learned behaviors taught and supported by the prevailing culture. NVC also assumes that we all share the same, basic human needs, and that each of our actions are a strategy to meet one or more of these needs.

People who practice NVC have found greater authenticity in their communication, increased understanding, deepening connection, and conflict resolution.

Sliding Scale Fee: $10 to $15

Bio

As a core trainer with NVC Boston, Gail Carroll offers Nonviolent Communication introductions, workshops, and trainings in the Greater Boston area, sharing NVC with the transformative power of compassion as the foundation of her practice and teaching. She believes passionately in NVC as a tool for communication, as well as deep inner and outer transformation.

Gail is also a co-trainer for Mediate Your Life, a program for those wishing to use NVC to increase their ability to resolve personal and interpersonal conflicts.  

She is a certified trainer with The Center for Nonviolent Communication, the international organization established by Marshall Rosenberg, the founder of NVC.

*********************************************************

Most ingredients are organic and of the highest standards.

Come be in community and enjoy a healthy meal!

Call (617)[masked] or e-mail [masked]
for reservations and directions.

Please rsvp no later than noon on Friday.

results.description:
Don’t miss……. VOICES FROM THE MOUNTAIN
Join us on a musical journey to Appalachia to discovery the Celtic roots of American Folk and Country Music.

In Good Company presents two performances in Lexington MA, April 29 and May 1, 2016.


In 1907, in the wilds of Appalachia, a young girl’s song stuns outsider Olive Dame Campbell. Haunted and intrigued, Campbell begins to ask questions, discovering musical and cultural traditions from England, Scotland, and Ireland dating as far back as the early 1700’s. Hundreds of years later, these ballads were still being sung in the old ways, deep in the Appalachian wilderness.

Journey with her as she learns from the mountain community and collects their songs.

VOICES FROM THE MOUNTAIN
Written by Chris Jorie and Patrick Swanson
Music Director: Dan Ryan
Stage Director: Jonathan Carpenter

TWO PERFORMANCES!
First Parish Unitarian Church, 7 Harrington Road, Lexington, MA
• April 29, 8:00pm •
• May 1, 4:00pm •

Admission $20 adults, $16 children under 12
For more information including video clips, visit http://new.ingoodcompanytheater.org/

Partner Yoga Class (8:00-9:00 pm):
The night will start with a class open to all ages and experience levels, modifications will be made to fit your needs! We will warm up with basic stretching and get into groups of 2 for some partner stretching (no partner needed upon arrival, we will pair you up during class!). Here we will learn how to use one another's support to deepen the practice of stretching and basic yoga instruction. We will then progress to groups of 3 for an intro to acro-yoga beginning with L-Base positions. We will learn how to be birds, folded leaves, and even how to sit on a throne through our exploration of acro-yoga. Some thai massage and breathing techniques will also be incorporated.

results.description:
Fridays, March – mid-November | 8:30 – 10:00 pm
Offering Format: Public Event
Recommended for grades Pre-K – 12 and adults
Museum of Science
Free

Did you know that the Museum offers our starry-eyed public a free evening full of astronomy-themed fun on weather-cooperative Fridays?

Between 8:30pm and 10pm each Friday, weather-permitting, visit the Gilliland Observatory on the roof of the Museum’s parking garage. On clear nights, you can view stars, planets, the Moon, and other astronomical phenomena. On cloudy nights, tour the inside of our Observatory, and participate in astronomy-related activities run by our knowledgeable staff.

This program does not run on nights when the weather is inclement. For more details, and to find out if Astronomy After Hours is running on a given Friday, call our hotline,[masked]-0267. We update each Friday by 5:30pm with the evening’s plans.

Astronomy After Hours runs seasonally, from the first Friday in March to the last Friday before Thanksgiving. Admission is free thanks to the generosity of the Lowell Institute (parking charges still apply).

Thanks to Don Doughty for letting us know about the museum.

Source: http://www.mos.org/public-events/astronomy-after-hours
results.how_to_find_us: Please meet 15 minutes before the scheduled time and to the right of the line in front of the Astronomy building on the roof of the Museum of Science to be with the group. The Meetup group will wait for 10 minutes and then get in line.

results.description:
Let's get together for a sunrise shoot at Great Meadows National Wildlife Refuge in Concord, MA!

The main target species will be red-winged blackbirds which are typically the most numerous and most cooperative this time of year but other opportunities are certainly possible.

Longer focal length lenses will maximize your opportunities with these relatively small birds but shorter lenses will still allow you to create more environmental types of images.  The ideal set up would be a combination of digital SLR and lens that would give you a minimum 35mm equivalent of 600mm.  Some examples would include a Canon Rebel with a[masked] lens (640mm) or a Nikon DX body with an[masked]mm lens (600mm).  Please contact me if you have any questions about suitable equipment for this outing.  All levels are welcome from beginners to experienced shooters.

We will meet in the main parking lot around 5:15 AM so that we can get our gear together and make it out onto the Dike Trail in time for sunrise at 5:41 AM.  Depending on the light and the weather, we will likely shoot until around 8:30 AM.  If you arrive after sunrise, it should be fairly easy to catch up with us on the Dike Trail.

I will check the trail conditions and the weather forecast the day before and send out a cancellation notice if necessary.

I have set an attendance limit of 30 on this event, mainly due to the limited parking available.  There are only about 25 spaces so please consider carpooling if convenient.

Hope to see you there!

PLEASE NOTE : There is an entrance fee for the Concord impoundment of Great Meadows :


http://www.fws.gov/uploadedFiles/Rec%20Fee%20faq%20pics.pdf

results.description:
Surya Kriya is a potent yoga of tremendous antiquity, designed as a holistic process for health, wellness, and complete inner well-being. “Surya” means “sun,” and “kriya” means “inner energy process.” Surya Kriya activates the solar plexus to raise thesamat prana, or solar heat, in the system. It also balances a person’s left and right energy channels, leading to stability of the body and stillness of the mind. This strong foundation becomes the basis to explore higher dimensions of life. 

Traditionally available only to select groups of yogis, Surya Kriya is being offered by Sadhguru as a comprehensive spiritual practice that is ideal for the hectic pace of today’s world.

This is a hatha yoga program (physical postures) which will be taught step-by-step and guided by a teacher trained in India by Sadhguru.  Once you have completed the program, you can practice on your own at home. Surya Kriya does not require previous experience with yoga.

Benefits:

-  Develops mental clarity and focus

-  Remedies weak constitutions

-  Boosts vigor and vitality

results.description:
This is a cross-post of a ride Tom, one of our members, is leading:

We are going to be cycling a road loop starting in Topsfield, following a somewhat hilly route along mostly country roads through Boxford, North Andover and Georgetown and back to the cars in Topsfield. The expected route is just short of 30 miles.

***** On all rides this year there will be a donation envelope to collect contributions to help offset the Meet-up hosting charges. $1 is suggested, but not required. The organizers thank you in advance for your support ***** This course is entirely on the road, which includes some occasional heavy vehicle traffic and some climbing. This is NOT a rail trail ride. We hope to maintain a consistent pace at around 14 mph. This isn't a good ride for hybrids unless you've been pedaling a lot of miles and can spin with a group. This is a NO DROP ride but please be considerate and join only if you have been comfortably riding at this pace and distance with a group.

The itinerary and cues for this ride are available here: https://ridewithgps.com/routes/13208068

*****

Start point will be the bike shop off Route 1 in Topsfield, near the rail trail.

*****

If you cannot find us, or are running late, text or call one of us:

Tom:[masked]
Richard:[masked]
results.name: Crosspost  from Boston Area Cycling - 30 on the 30th

venue.name: Parking lot... ~ 100 yards in off Sudbury Rd

results.description:
This event is for those how like to hike and also want to use their Polish. The date has been slid because of weather and cancellations from original April 23 schedule.

DESCRIPTION

The 6.5  mile hike starts from the parking area identified when you click on "edit map". My blog link below also identifies the area where we will meet and hike:  https://sites.google.com/site/fairhavenhike/

The trail runs through some deep pine woods close to the Concord river for the first two miles.  Much of the trail is carpeted by a thick soft layer of pine needles.  After two miles we will reach Fairhaven Bay, from there the trail wiggles its way to Misery Mountain (a very small hill in Lincoln) .  The return path will necessarily retrace some of the out path, except for our approach to Fairhaven Cliffs.  The term "cliffs" here is again a bit of a misnomer, they are easily surmountable and provide a wonderful viewing spot on top !

Jacek (aka Jack)

DIRECTIONS

The parking area is only about 200 yards away from the Route 2 intersection with Sudbury Road (with traffic lights) towards Sudbury. 

If you are coming out of the Boston area the intersection is the next one after the Walden intersection.

If you are coming from the other direction on Route 2 the intersection is the next one after the traffic intersection at Emerson hospital.

OTHER INFOS

• My green Volvo wagon will be parked at entrance. 

• Total time est ~ 3 hrs.  Pace hopefully at least 2 mph.

• Sneakers or boots, (not regular shoes), bug repel.

• Lunch/drink option after event.

• Car pooling offers/requests on bulletin board.

• Change to Sunday same time if it rains. 

DISCLAIMER

Disclaimers usually do not appear for meetups like ours, but they do appear for most hiking Meetups.  Therefore...

As a condition of your voluntary participation in this activity you acknowledge that you have the necessary fitness level to participate and you also agree to assume all risks of injury associated with this activity.
results.name: Hike Fairhaven Bay & Cliffs

results.description:
Their major issue is that they have tons of donations, and not even close enough amount of volunteers, to sort useable vs. recycle goods.  

http://thewishproject.org/ 

The Wish Project is a non-profit dedicated to providing free furniture, home goods, baby goods, and clothing to people in need in the Merrimack Valley, primarily through reuse and recycling. They serve thousands of people each year, and rely on the help of many volunteers. Let's be some of those volunteers! We'll take on whatever task they need on this day, but generally it involves sorting and organizing donations so they can be given out to clients. Children ages 8+ are welcome to join the effort. It's a great opportunity to teach your kids compassion in a very hands-on way. 

IMPORTANT:

If you are bringing children, please make a note in the comments section so I can give the Wish Project an accurate count of adults and kids who will be attending.

http://thewishproject.org/

 *PLEASE NOTE:  When you RSVP 'yes' it becomes a commitment. I am in contact with the volunteer coordinator, Patty, whom is now a member, giving her a head count. She then creates a list of things that need to be done -relying upon the number of volunteers. If your plans change, please be considerate -take a moment to update your RSVP to 'no.' It's very simple- and greatly appreciated! Thanks :)

This is a par 3 course so you can practice your short game.  The fee to join is $40 and it covers your handicap fee.  You can play 9 or 18 but have to decide which option when you sign up each week.

Come paddle at one of our practice sessions with Living Root, your 2015 Boston Dragon Boat Festival Grand Champions! We're a social and friendly co-ed team who enjoy the sport of dragon boat paddling. 

Are you new to paddling? No problem! We'll show you everything you need to know to paddle on a dragon boat. This is a great way to meet people, get in shape, and do something fun in the sun.

We meet at 6pm at the docks behind the Barking Crab (88 Sleeper Street in Boston), a short walk from South Station.  We paddle rain or shine, so dress for the weather.  Wear comfortable workout clothing and footwear that you don't mind getting wet. Bring a bottle of water, and we'll provide all the paddling equipment you'll need and a place to lock up your belongings.  We often head out for a quick bite to eat after practice. So come join us!  Send questions to: Dave Parker at [masked].

PLEASE NOTE: You must sign up for this event on Eventbrite!

The Power and Promise of Biodiversity: 
Visions of Restoring Land, Sea and Climate

Distinguished speakers from across New England!

We will explore the interconnections of life forms we see around us in the New England landscape, seascape and beyond, and discover the origins of those relationships in the past. Human restoration of biodiversity can regenerate rich and abundant eco-systems - we know how and now is the time to start!

Our speakers are scientists, visionaries and practitioners. Their stories will illuminate ways in which many species working in partnership can, with our help, regenerate a robust community of life - and a livable climate. Join us for a day of hopeful and realistic planetary solutions. 

Please pass the word, and bring a friend!

Additional Details and Registration at:


<a>http://bio4climate.org/harvard-2016</a>;

results.description:
The Annual Earth Day Charles River Cleanup brings together over 3,000 volunteers each year to pick up litter, remove invasive species and assist with park maintenance. Residents are drawn to the popular Charles River Cleanup from a desire to give back to their community while enjoying the beauty and wildlife along the Charles River. Volunteers build on the connections they establish during this day of stewardship by returning to the Charles to exercise, play and enjoy nature throughout the year.

The Annual Earth Day Charles River Cleanup builds on a national effort as part of American Rivers’ National River Cleanup®, which to date, has removed over 20.7 million pounds of trash from America’s waterways.

This event will be hosted by Sara! 

Update:

Our group will be responsible for cleanup along Greenough Blvd in Cambridge. We'll meet in the American Legion parking lot as a starting point. You can view the area where our group will be working in the yellow BYPV layer here: https://www.google.com/maps/d/viewer?mid=z1-3230-KLC0.kBqPsrUGgPF8. 

I will have T-shirts and supplies (trash bags, gloves, volunteer waivers) with me for the group, and I'll send out my cell number closer to the day of the cleanup. Please bring your own water and snacks, and be prepared for the weather. This event will take place rain or shine.

There is a volunteer appreciation picnic from 12-2pm by the Hatch Shell. If you're interested in attending, your volunteer T-shirt will be your entry ticket.
results.name: Earth Day Charles River Clean Up

results.description:
Are you curious about programming or thinking about pursuing a career in software engineering? 

Then RSVP on this meet-up page for this 2-hour Intro to Coding class happening in the Boston area at CIC Boston. Learn the basics of programming, do hands-on exercises, and meet new people. All for free!

The class is being taught by MakerSquare, which runs some of the top coding schools in the country.

Class officially starts at 9:30am, but please arrive at CIC Boston by 9:15am to mingle with your fellow classmates and settle in. We will end at 12noon, with the last 30 minutes being an optional Q&A session.

What will I learn during the class?

This beginner ­level class will contain several instructor-guided exercises. The class will cover the following topics:

   1. Overview of programming 

   2. Intro to data & data structures

   3. Basics of functions

We ask that you read the Prerequisites section before the start of class and bring your own laptop (Windows, Mac or Linux) with Google Chrome installed.

What is MakerSquare Boston?

MakerSquare is a three-month full-time school for software engineering. By teaching computer science fundamentals and modern web languages like JavaScript, we prepare students to join top flight engineering teams.

We have campuses all over the country, and are excited to be opening a campus in Boston. The free Intro to Coding class is to introduce more people to the wonderful world of programming and to get the community excited about the launch of our full-time class in Boston in July 2016!

Questions? Email us at [masked].
results.name: Free Intro to Coding Class (Sat April 30, 9:30am-12noon)

results.description:
Join Chiltern Mountain Clun for its annual Spring Activities Day at Hopkinton State Park in Hopkinton, MA. This will be a fun day of hiking, exploring, and fun games of croquet (no experience or skill required). Everyone welcome, bring friends and guests.

Our event begins at 10 AM with coffee (small donation accepted) then go out on a hike of the ten miles of loop paths in this beautiful park in central Massachusetts. Bring a pack lunch and water to have on the trail and return after lunch for some fun games of croquet.  Dress according to the weather, hiking boots suggested.

There is no charge to get into the park until May. 

 Your host, Steve Pinkham[masked] [masked]

Directions from Exit 21A off I-495

From Boston, take Route 90 (Mass Pike) to I-495, then go south on I-495 to Exit 21 and head toward Hopkinton Center. At the third traffic light (in downtown Hopkinton) turn left and go north on Route 85 and go two miles. The entrance to Hopkinton State Park is on the right.

Enter the park, pass the gatehouse (no fee until May) and go the next intersection (island). Turn right on Birch St (to beach) and pass the boat ramp and concession stand, then drive to the end of the parking lot at Reservoir Beach.

We will be using a picnic table for registration and coffee. There are bathrooms here that are open this time of year.

If we need a sheltered picnic table that day, we have access to the Split Rock Picnic Pavilion, but the road to it will not be open. It is a ten minute walk up the Caesar Trail. The trailhead is across the road from the parking lot. No bathrooms at the pavilion.

ABOUT CHILTERN

Chiltern Mountain Club (CMC) was founded in 1978 by Sturgis Haskins.  At the time he lived in Boston.  He posted an ad in a local paper asking follow gay men and lesbians to join him for a hike up Mt. Wachusett in central Massachusetts.  Since then, the club grew into New England's largest and only gay and lesbian outdoor recreation club.

Our trips page lists a variety of events, including hiking, biking, canoeing, kayaking, camping, skiing, and many other outdoor-related activities club members are leading. Chiltern events are open to members and non-members alike, and activities range anywhere from an easy garden walk to a strenuous backpacking trip in the White Mountains.  We welcome people of all abilities and backgrounds, so there's no need to feel intimidated if you're new to an activity.

Chiltern is an all-volunteer group that strives to create a relaxed environment for people to experience the outdoors together and bond as a community.
results.name: Chiltern's Spring Activities Day, Hopkinton State Park

results.description:
Volunteer @FPR for $2 Bag of Vegetables - or get a $2 Bag for Yourself

Of ALL the $2 baggings, this is the one that has the MOST young persons' enthusiasm!

Do you want OTHER people to eat fresh produce?  Then help us - each Wednesday late afternoon - bag vegetables (and some fruit) for the neighbors in Roxbury (Roxbury Crossing and Fort Hill).  Usually there are also freshly-baked loaves of bread, also (baked that morning - Jessica's Bakery).

It's an assembly line, then take home a bag (or two) of produce for yourself. 

Bring your business cards, smartphone, or notepad, and prepare to exchange contact info with other volunteers you like.  Volunteers come from several sources (not merely from this meetup or others: Craigslist, Pharmacy School, School of Public Health, etc.) 
~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~ 
VOLUNTEERING for $2/bag of produce in Mission Hill 

First Church of Roxbury - Outdoors in good weather 
10 Putnam Street, John Eliot Square, Highland Park, Roxbury, Boston, MA

Each Saturday, from 10:00 am - 2:00 pm (indoors in bad weather)

We will be VOLUNTEERING for the weekly Saturday mid-day $2/bag of produce in Roxbury.

When you volunteer, 
YOU will ALSO TAKE HOME one or two of those "$2 bags"! 
We've had 55 volunteers, and we've had 7.  Workloads vary!

Fair Foods provides a 20-22 bag of produce for the Roxbury neighbors so they can eat like me - on produce. The neighbors only need to pay' $2 for the bag. 

Volunteers unload the truck, set up 3 banquet tables, set up the food in order of density (potatoes on bottom - tomatoes and bananas and berries and kale on top), then fill each bag (and 'stack' them upright by one another - for the 'paying neighbors' to pick up (for $2).

We arrive around 10 am and work until 2 pm.

In FRONT of the 

First Church of Roxbury - Outdoors in good weather 
10 Putnam Street, John Eliot Square, Highland Park, Roxbury, Boston, MA

Each Saturday, from 10:00 am - 2:00 pm (indoors in bad weather)

the Roxbury Crossing Orange Line T stop - is only a few blocks away; we are behind the Mosque, which has a $2 bag distribution from 1-3 pm that same afternoon.

Wear comfortable clothing that allows you to move flexibly and to actually work, lifting heavy bags of food. 

~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~ 

First Church of Roxbury - Outdoors in good weather 
10 Putnam Street, John Eliot Square, Highland Park, Roxbury, Boston, MA

Each Saturday, from 10:00 am - 2:00 pm (indoors in bad weather)


THERE IS PARKING - BUT IT'S BEST FOR THOSE WHO LIVE IN BOSTON AND TRAVEL IN ON THE MBTA

THERE IS PARKING IN THE NEIGHBORHOOD

Every Wednesday, from 10:00 am - 2:00 pm 
~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~ 
Bring friends!  Forward the invitation to others! 

Please e-mail organizer with your e-mail address and cellphone (in case we need to converse about this more, or contact you before the event). 

Invite FRIENDS through the Facebook, LinkedIn, and Twitter 'share'

Question: 
This sounds like a great deal, but is it meant for those in need, as is the case with food banks? 

Answer: 
No qualifications - no limits 
We have way more - far more - lots more - much more than AMPLE food for any intended audiences, and the operation is bettered if MORE people take the food than if FEWER take the food. 

Therefore, there is NO QUALIFICATION (no test of need) and no limit to how much you can cart off (just pay $2/bag and $1/loaf of bread).  That's why I post it on a meetup like this. 
Make us busy - very busy.

results.description:
Volunteer for $2 Bag of Vegetables at First Parish Roxbury

Do you want OTHER people to eat fresh produce?  Then help us - each Wednesday late afternoon - bag vegetables (and some fruit) for the neighbors in Roxbury (Roxbury Crossing and Fort Hill).  Usually there are also freshly-baked loaves of bread, also (baked that morning - Jessica's Bakery).

It's an assembly line, then take home a bag (or two) of produce for yourself. 

Bring your business cards, smartphone, or notepad, and prepare to exchange contact info with other volunteers you like.  Volunteers come from several sources (not merely from this meetup or others: Craigslist, Pharmacy School, School of Public Health, etc.) 
~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~ 
VOLUNTEERING for $2/bag of produce in Mission Hill 

First Church of Roxbury - Outdoors in good weather 
10 Putnam Street, John Eliot Square, Highland Park, Roxbury, Boston, MA

Each Saturday, from 10:00 am - 2:00 pm (indoors in bad weather)

We will be VOLUNTEERING for the weekly Saturday mid-day $2/bag of produce in Roxbury.

When you volunteer, 
YOU will ALSO TAKE HOME one or two of those "$2 bags"! 
We've had 55 volunteers, and we've had 7.  Workloads vary!

Fair Foods provides a 20-22 bag of produce for the Roxbury neighbors so they can eat like me - on produce. The neighbors only need to pay' $2 for the bag. 

Volunteers unload the truck, set up 3 banquet tables, set up the food in order of density (potatoes on bottom - tomatoes and bananas and berries and kale on top), then fill each bag (and 'stack' them upright by one another - for the 'paying neighbors' to pick up (for $2).

We arrive around 10 am and work until 2 pm.

In FRONT of the 

First Church of Roxbury - Outdoors in good weather 
10 Putnam Street, John Eliot Square, Highland Park, Roxbury, Boston, MA

Each Saturday, from 10:00 am - 2:00 pm (indoors in bad weather)

the Roxbury Crossing Orange Line T stop - is only a few blocks away; we are behind the Mosque, which has a $2 bag distribution from 1-3 pm that same afternoon.

Wear comfortable clothing that allows you to move flexibly and to actually work, lifting heavy bags of food. 

~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~ 

First Church of Roxbury - Outdoors in good weather 
10 Putnam Street, John Eliot Square, Highland Park, Roxbury, Boston, MA

Each Saturday, from 10:00 am - 2:00 pm (indoors in bad weather)

Kim Sullivan would like to organize a group to visit Art in Bloom at the Museum of Fine Arts in Boston on Saturday, April 30.

“I would arrange a carpool and, depending on the amount of interest, lunch as well or a group tour.”

Art in Bloom 2016 at the Museum of Fine Arts in Boston is celebrating 40 years of this exuberant spring festival. This joyous rite of spring pairs fine art and floral design with offerings of free guided tours among MFA treasures, plus workshops, demonstrations, and lectures. Garden clubs and professional designers from across New England create floral arrangements inspired by the MFA’s works of art.

Bring your group of ten or more. Opt for a self-guided or guided visit, add a lecture or join us for elegant tea. Reserve today!

April 30, 2016 – May 2, 2016
10:00 am – 5:00 pm
http://www.mfa.org/programs/special-event/art-bloom

Seniors (65+) $23

results.description:
We practice L'Arte D'Armizare (The Art of Bearing Arms), a historical European martial art. Our main sources of interpretation are the books (circa[masked]) of Fiore dei Liberi, a fencing master from Friuli (thus the non-standard Italian spellings!).

Our students work on a combination of longsword, abrazzare (grappling), daga (dagger/knife) and other weapon skills. These skills are drawn from direct translation from historical sources, developed through multiple physical interpretations and tested at speed. Though we emphasize historical technique, our training sessions are a blend of warmup, interpretation, drill, and for men and women who've passed our safety standards, both focused and open sparring.

New students should take our beginners' class first, or contact our instructors for more information.  We're happy to have visiting scholars from other programs come and play!

See you there!
results.how_to_find_us: Come around to the right side of the school (left side of the church), enter under the green awning, then up two flights to the gym!

results.description:
Please note the new location and time.

Group run logistics: Please come prepared for a short run (or run/walk). Leave your bags, etc. at home or in your car so that you can run easily. Please make sure to arrive 10 minutes early to look for parking, find the location, etc.  


Coach will brief you at the beginning of the run about the distance and direct you through stretching exercises. It is absolutely OK to run/walk in the beginning. Many of us are first-time runners. So please don’t be shy :-). 

Proposed mileage: 3-5 miles, depending on your last Saturday's long run

Parking: Please arrive 10+ minutes early to find parking near Davis Square. You can find free parking spots on the Holland Street if you drive a few blocks from Au Bon Pain towards Hodgkins Park. You can also find metered parking spots near Au Bon Pain. Remember to feed the meter to avoid getting ticket.


Program details:  TeamAIDAsha is a beginner-friendly marathon/half-marathon training and fund-raising program. We train runners for their full or half marathon races and runners raise donations for AID and Asha. Both beginner and experienced runners are welcome. Anyone is welcome to RSVP and join us for the group runs up to four time with no obligations. We request formal registrations after attending four group runs.

If you missed the information session you can get an overview of this training and fund-raising program from here.

Looking for more runners: We are always looking for more runners. If any of your friends, family members or colleagues to give us a try and join this meetup group.


Waiver: Lawyers make us do this :-).  By running with TeamAIDAsha program you are agreeing to our official waiver at: http://www.teamaidasha.org/waiver.html
results.how_to_find_us: Look for a group of runners and volunteers
results.name: Beginner-friendly marathon/half-marathon training run

results.description:
Whether you are interested in fine art photography or street shots, monochrome is the way to go.   Getting a good black and white image from a color digital camera requires a degree of skill and knowledge. You need to be able to see the scene in black and white, because not all images male good black and white subjects .  A stunning color image can look flat and drab in black and white, whereas an image that would look awful in color can produce a great contrasty black and white fine art print.

In this workshop you will learn the secrets of "seeing" in black and white as we take a stroll through the streets of Boston and the North End.  We will cover the techniques for recognizing the tones and contrast that produce good monochromatic images.

On top of that we will explore some of the back alleys and passageways of the North End which are sure to provide excellent subject matter for our shooting.

A great workshop packed with excellent information and instruction for just $65. The workshop will run from 10am - 3pm and will be limited to 6 participants.
results.how_to_find_us: Meet inside  the Amtrak Concourse of South Station by track 6 and the Au Bon Pain kiosk.
results.name: Black and White in Boston

results.description:
A big thank you to Robert McCauley, and Chad Wright, Director of IT at Amazon Robotics, for helping approve and arrange the event - hosting this "Hackathon and Tour of Amazon Robotics"

Limited to 50 attendees. Confirmed RSVP members with legal names registered in their profile.


Schedule:


10am-11am: Intro to Amazon Robotics
11am-noon: Shop Floor tour
Noon-1: pizza/salad lunch with soda/waters.
Alexa intro during lunch - get hands on practice with Alexa and AWS Lambda service.
1-5pm: Hackathon teams form, projects begin
5-6pm: Demos and prizes

More Info:
All registrants must sign a non-disclosure form (available in the lobby), and agree to no photographs within the factory.

Amazon Robotics is located at 300 Riverpark Drive, North Reading, MA 01864. From Boston or 128: Take Route 93 North to exit 39 (Concord Street). Turn right at the exit ramp, then take next right at the Riverpark complex. Our building is 1/4 mile on the left.

As you approach the 300 building, the main entrance is on the far right (southwest) corner, at the bottom of a flight of stairs from the guest parking lot.

Preparation:

• Bring a laptop (Windows or Mac). Only requirement is an internet browser and some basic experience with coding or scripting.


• Guest Wifi and power outlets will be provided.

• Bring your own Amazon Echo device, or borrow one of the 10 loaners that will be provided. OR develop within the web browser only.  Here's a review/comparison of different Echo devices.


• In advance - create an account on https://aws.amazon.com (credit card is required but Alexa coding is free)

• In advance - create an account on https://developer.amazon.com


• In advance - review instructions on https://developer.amazon.com/ask , setup one of the sample skills (voice apps).


• Complete the NDA in advance and bring it with you - form located here.

results.description:
Wanna try us out? Come join us at our water training sessions! No prior experience necessary.


• First two practices are $10 (The $10 can go towards the full membership of $110 for the rest of the season). Pay via Paypal here: "Boston 1 - Join us"

• Also you will not be allowed on the boats if you do not sign the waiver: "Boston 1 e-waiver"


• Make sure to check our Facebook, </a><a href="http://bit.ly/Boston1facebook">http://bit.ly/Boston1facebook for practice announcements and cancellations -- especially in the early and later parts of season with potentially colder night practices. 

Weekly practices are every Monday, Wednesday and Saturday unless a race is scheduled or practice is cancelled.

Mon & Wed: 5:45pm - 8pm, meet 5.45pm on the grassy patch near the Barking Crab.
Sat: 10:45am - 1pm, meet 10.45am on the grassy patch near the Barking Crab.

Optional dinner/lunch or social activity afterwards!

Outdoor paddling means exposure to the weather and water! Be prepared to get wet!

• Clothing: Wear workout clothes, synthetic fibers that dry quickly are highly recommended. Bring dry clothes to change into afterwards.


• Footwear: Sandals or flip flops recommended. Some people go barefoot. Shoes and socks are not recommended.


• Other: Bring plenty of water and sunscreen. Expensive glasses or sunglasses are not recommended. 


All paddling equipment is provided (paddles, pfds). Locked locker provided on-site. Please bring as little as possible to practice as space is limited.

In the event of inclement weather, announcements will be made through the comments area of each meetup event, also in Twitter, Facebook and email alerts.

Sign up for our weekly emails and email alerts

Twitter: @Boston1Dboat

Facebook: http://bit.ly/Boston1facebook

Parking: Channelside Parking at 284 A Street. Enter at 29-41 Necco Street, off Melcher Street. Weekend $6 flat rate.

Restroom: Do not use the restrooms in the Barking Crab, use the public restrooms near the Daily Catch

Public Transport: Closest T stop is South Station on the red line.

Hope to see you there!

results.description:
How would you like to let go of some of the anger, resentment, worry, fear, and sadness that have been building up inside of you this past winter?

How would you like to tap into your inner child and remember what joy and peace are like? How would you like to harmonize your body and emotions... experience forgiveness... and be in the present moment... all without having to sit through long and painful therapy sessions? :)

How about just taking 90 minutes to tap back into YOURSELF... BREATHE... RELAX... and let go? That would be pretty darn special, wouldn't it?

Well, that's exactly what we'll be doing - in a very simple, safe, and powerful way - at our "Let It Go: Using Essential Oils for Emotional Release" workshop. Held in a beautiful, nurturing studio setting, we will walk through Gary Young's Feelings Kit Protocol together as a group. We'll hold the space for each person to have their own individual experience, while also creating the kind of powerful connection that happens when a group comes together like this.

To register for this event and reserve your spot, click here: Things to bring:

- your own Yoga mat

- a pen (and if you have a special journal, feel free to bring that along, too)

Can't wait to welcome you to the workshop - it's going to be a pretty special morning!

Early Bird Registrations receive raffle tickets for prizes!
Remember, you must register for this event through the eventbrite link to reserve your spot:

https://www.eventbrite.com/e/let-it-go-using-essential-oils-for-emotional-release-workshop-tickets-24532334874
results.name: "Let It Go! Using Essential Oils for Emotional Release" Workshop

results.description:
Somerville Open Studio Group tour on April 30th. Updated  May 22, 2016

Park cars/get off T stop. 11:30AM meet at 86 Joy St Somerville parking lot 

Group introductions, meet your fellow art lover for 5 minutes. I'll explain what we'll be doing for 6 hours, including what to see/not see, important tips to maximize your art experience, how SOS art weekends works and pass out maps that I made for you all so if you can give me a $1 for it great if not its OK. Takes 5-10 minutes.

11:45AM Board trolley across street to tour other studios all around Somerville, MA. If you come late there'll be NO easy way to find us. We can’t wait, sorry.. Please come early as we’re going to look +enjoy ART not wait for latecomers.

Getting around, use FREE Trolley service is available 12 noon to 5:30PM to help visitors get around. FREE parking at Joy Street Art Studios parking Lot.

Somerville Open Studios (SOS): Visit Somerville's Diverse + Vibrant Arts Community. Over 400 artists in over 100 venues will open their homes and studios. See emerging artists working across a broad spectrum of fine art styles/media including painting, photography, printmaking, sculpture, glass, fiber, jewelry, furniture and ceramics.

SOS Web link http://www.somervilleopenstudios.org/artists/location.php
You can also find links with Maps, MBTA info, parking even Directions.

Please make sure you are at Joy St Studios 86 Joy St by 11:30AM!  Jump on trolley at 11:45AM to start our long, but FUN ART day. All trolleys only go one way (One direction in a loop, Counter Clock Wise in 2016).

We’ll NOT stop at all stops, but you can if you like. We’ll hit the MAIN LARGE Art Areas except for Vernon which you can hit on Sunday.  If there is any time left we’ll hit Brickbottom Art Studios (Brickbottom Artists 1 Fitchburg St) down the street from Joy St Studios too.

If you miss us at Joy Street then try to find us at the next few stops till you find us.

Please make sure everyone catches the last Trolley to Joy St around 5PM so you don’t get left behind!

Here is the order --Updated official SOS 2016 Social Fun Meetup path!

Start at #92 Joy St Studios 86 Joy St , park, meet the group do intros and pick up free Trolley stop #A.

Off at Trolley stop #C. for #70 (Gilman SQ) Mad Oyster Studios 2 Bradley St 23 Artists here 20 minute stop

Then walk to #69 Pearl Street Studios 226 Pearl Street (nearby + 15 minute stop)

Back on Trolley at Trolley stop #C. & off at Trolley stop #D walk up Central St, right to 9 Browning Rd #62 Hilary Scott & his Eclectic Sculpture, Fantastic Machines & Creatures (my most favorite SOS stop) 20 minutes

Walk back Central St, left down hill, right onto Medford St, right onto Bartlett St for #61 Skunk Skunkadelia 75 Bartlett St. apt #2, Robots, ray guns, rocket ships. House full of fun! crazy cool bikers, it’s my 2nd favorite stop of SOS! You’ll be amazed what in here, this is a must do for all!!!! (15 minute stop, due to all the walking)

Walk down Bartlett St., left onto Medford St to get back to Trolley stop #D get on Trolley,

Note: We Skipped #58 and #59 Vernon St Studios since there is NOT enough time for this long stop. You’ll need 2-3 hours for this stop. (yes it’s that big, over 50 Artist), but NOTE: If you cannot go to Vernon St on Sunday then you might want to see Vernon St now on Saturday if you have time!

Off Trolley at Trolley stop #G walk to #16 Blue Cloud Gallery 713 Broadway color photographs, special treat Biagio has some of his art on display. Take a coffee/snack break area next door. (15 minutes).

Walk down Willow Ave, right onto Morrison Ave to #20 Mix it Print Studio 32 Clifton St (15 minutes). This is a great stop to relax outside and on the balcony on the 3rd floor.

Walk right onto Morrison Ave, right onto Willow Ave, left onto Highland Ave for Trolley stop #K get on Trolley if Trolley is late/slow late then walk to Trolley stop #M

Off Trolley at Trolley stop #M, #46 Arts at Armory 191 Highland Ave 20 minutes. Coffee/snack/bathroom

On Trolley at Trolley stop #M, off Trolley stop #O, #51 Artisan's Asylum 10 Tyler St for 20 minutes). This is an Awesome Art Studio + you can take classes here.

On Trolley at Trolley stop #O, off Trolley stop #P #80 Washington St Art Center 321 Washington St, for 10 minutes)

On Trolley at Trolley stop #P, off Trolley stop #R #91 Brickbottom Art Studios 1 Fitchburg St which is down the street from Joy St Studios. 20 minutes

Walk to #92 Joy St Studios 86 Joy Stif you have any energy left check out Artists at Jot St Studios 30 minute

If you’re tired you can hop on  Trolley at Trolley stop #R, off Trolley stop #A #92 Joy St Studios 86 Joy St

Disclaimer: Please realize there are over 400 Artist to see in all which would take about 80 hours to see. I’m trying to fit this into 6 hours in 1 day. If you get tired and need to rest we’ll understand, but we will not wait too for you. I’ll try you budget in some rest stops. Saturday is a long day 6 hour day so please wear comfy shoes (Sneakers) and be prepared to walk a lot inside and outside!.... I realized we skip many of the cool, smaller Artists which sucks, but we only have time to see so many on Saturday. Plan on seeing Vernon St on Sunday for 2-3 hours and then if you have time hit the smaller Artists too. We’ll play it by ear and I’ll listen to any ideas. Lastly, take time to enjoy the art!

Below are pictures I took from previous events by Ralph-


<a href="http://www.meetup.com/SocialFun/events/230173178/#"></a>

results.description:
Please join us for April's Divorce Basics Monthly Series: Are you ready to date? Learn about finding love again through online dating in this fun and interactive workshop led by Susan D. Trotter, PhD, Therapist and Relationship Coach. You will come away with a variety of tools that you will be able to utilize immediately and in the future in your search for love. The focus of this workshop is how to have more fun and greater success with online dating. Learn how to approach dating again and in the online context including setting up a profile and managing responses.

There is no cost for attendance. Complimentary refreshments and snacks will be provided. Space is limited, so RSVP to reserve your spot. Please change your RSVP right away if your plans change so that someone on the waiting list can take your spot.

This event is intended to be partly informational, partly social, and totally empowering. It will be casual/interactive and not formal, which is a setting that attendees of these events really like. The attendees have the opportunity to ask questions in the group setting, as well as ask the professionals questions one on one during the mix and mingle time towards the end. At this event, there will also be David Kellem, Divorce Attorney & Mediator; Bob Vona and Samantha Steer, Financial Advisors; and Sheila May, CPA and forensic accountant to answer your questions.

When: Thursday April 28th 6:30 – 8:30 p.m. & Saturday March 30th 12 – 2 p.m. Both dates are the same event (Meetups listed separately). Choose the time and date convenient for you.

Similar Divorce Basics Monthly Series events will be held at this location on the fourth Thursday and fourth Saturday of every month. Please check the calendar for these upcoming events:

• Thursday, May 19 & Saturday, May 21, 2016 (3rd Thursday & Saturday this month, because of Memorial Day). A Legal Overview of the Divorce Process. With David Kellem, Divorce Attorney & Mediator

• Thursday, June 23 & Saturday, June 25, 2016. The House -- Should you try to keep it or sell it; what to consider.

• Thursday, July 21 & Saturday, July 23, 2016. Emotional Issues in Divorce; Is there such a thing as emotional justice?
results.how_to_find_us: The event will be on the 2nd floor. Call or text Deanna at 508-333-3191 with any questions or for directions.
results.name: Divorce Basics: Finding Love Again through Online Dating

results.description:
Let's enjoy the Boston Museum of Fine Art's : Art in Bloom! 

This is the MFA's exuberant SPRING display of Fine Art and Floral Design featuring: Guided Tours/Workshops/High Tea/Japanese Flower Arranging Demonstration. 

Garden & Flower Clubs and professional floral designers create floral arrangements inspired by the MFA's works of Art. Thus this exhibition is called "Art in Bloom".

The Highlight for our visit to the MFA on Saturday is : The Japanese Flower Arranging Demonstration from 3--4pm in the Alfond Auditorium. 

Prior to this, there is lots to see and do:


*Guided Tours 10am--3pm Tours circulate continuously throughout the galleries. STRONGLY recommended! These Tours bring not only the Art but also the flowers that are inspired by the Artwork---to life.

*Designing with Flowers 12--3pm Continuous demonstrations of western flower arranging for your home

*Outdoor Walking Tours of the MFA's Gardens 1--2pm

Art in Bloom is open during regular Museum Hours from 10am--4:45pm. Art in Bloom is FREE with Museum Admission. Adult Admission is $25.


PLEASE NOTE: You should be able to get Discount Passes to the MFA from your local Library.

Don't worry if you do not make it to the Museum at Noon on Saturday. We will be there until it closes. There is a LOT to see and do!

Please do try to attend the Highlight at 3pm in the Alfond Auditorium for the Ikenobo Japanese Flower Arrangement Demonstration.

This yearly event is lots of FUN! And you will learn to appreciate flowers in a whole new way!

We will meet OUTSIDE of the Huntington Entrance.  I will have a Meetup sign with me.
results.name: Enjoy MFA's: "Art In Bloom" Enjoy Spring!

results.description:
An intermediate level beekeeping workshop with Dean Stiglitz. Basic hive inspection & smoker manipulation tips will also be covered.

Location: Fenway Victory Garden Apiary; refer to the Google map at: https://www.google.com/maps?cid=1704224708794287105 and enter at Path Q. Then ask around -- almost anyone in the garden will know where the apiary is.

This workshop is FREE, but donations are gladly accepted. Space is limited so PLEASE PRE-REGISTER via EventBrite, HERE. If you do not register your name on the EventBrite list you may be unable to attend.

This intermediate level beekeeping workshop will discuss:

• the causes of and reasons for honeybee swarms

• how to manage and reduce the swarm impulse in your own hives

• what to do if you notice swarming behavior in your colonies

• making swarm control splits 

Please wear long pants, closed toe shoes, and bring your veil if you have one. Gloves are also recommended -- you may have a chance to handle and observe activity on populated frames. Please be advised that live, populous hives full of tens of thousands stinging honeybees will be opened. By showing up to this workshop, as with almost any workshop held in an apiary, you might be stung.

Instructor: Dean Stiglitz: beekeeper, author, and owner of Golden Rule Honey in Leominster, MA

Dean will also have Golden Rule raw honey for sale, as well as copies of his book, The Complete Idiot's Guide to Beekeeping, so bring some spending money if you're in the market for either.
results.name: Swarm Management & Making Splits

results.description:
The first EA Global X conference, EAGxBoston, is being held at MIT on April 30th, 12:30-6:30pm. Boston EAs have created an incredible lineup bringing together a who's who of researchers, EAs, EA orgs, and up-and-coming orgs including:
Dean Karlan (Yale, Innovations for Poverty Action)
Joshua Greene (Harvard, Moral Cognition Lab)
Rachel Glennerster (MIT, Poverty Action Lab)
Piali Mukhopadhyay (GiveDirectly)
Bruce Friedrich (The Good Food Institute)
Julia Wise (The Centre for Effective Altruism)
Ian Ross (Hampton Creek, Facebook)
Allison Smith (Animal Charity Evaluators)
Elizabeth Pearce (Boston University, Iodine Global Network)
Cher-Wen DeWitt (One Acre Fund)
Rhonda Zapatka (Trickle Up)
Elijah Goldberg (ImpactMatters)
Jason Ketola (MaxMind)
Lucia Sanchez (Innovations for Poverty Action)
Sharon Nunez Gough (Animal Equality)
Bruce Friedrich (The Good Food Institute, New Crop Capital)
Jon Camp (The Humane League)
Victoria Krakovna (Harvard, Future of Life Institute)
Eric Gastfriend (Harvard Business School EA, FLI, and formerly 80,000 Hours)
Dillon Bowen (Tufts EA, formerly 80,000 Hours and Giving What We Can)
Jason Trigg (earning-to-give at a startup and formerly as a hedge fund quant)
and more

The day will be filled with talks, panels, and networking opportunities. The program will address the major effective altruist cause areas of global health poverty and development, animal agriculture, and global catastrophic risk, as well as movement concerns like conducting research, building community, and choosing a career direction. We will also be introducing some up-and-coming organizations.

More information and registration can be found on the conference website:
http://eagxboston.com

All proceeds after our minimum costs will be donated to EA charities. If you need a tax-receipt, please contact Randy Carlton <[masked]>. Please note that the early bird special ends on April 19th.

We have a limited amount of space, so if you’d like to join, please register today and share this invitation with interested friends via our Facebook group:
https://www.facebook.com/EAGxBoston/

Let’s get together, and learn what we can do even better together!

EAGxBoston Team from MIT Sloan EA, MIT EA, Tufts EA, Harvard EA, HBS EA, Animal Charity Evaluators and The Commonwealth Market
http://eagxboston.com
results.name: EA Global X Boston Conference

results.description:
Come out and enjoy an afternoon of rock climbing at Central Rock Gym in Watertown. We will meet at the large cubby area near the front.
Day passes are $22 and $8 for gear rental. Monthly Memberships are also available that allow you to climb unlimited.
If you do not know how belay (hold the rope for others) there is a class that starts at 12:00pm and is about an hour long if you would like to learn. I'll keep checking back at the front for anyone showing up late but if you get there late and can't seem to find us I will have my phone on me so just shoot me a message.
It's Tradition for me and a few friends to go and get Pho after climbing so feel free to join us. We usually go to Pho n Spice in Waltham.
results.name: Top Rope Rock Climbing @CRG and pho

results.description:
Note: 

There will be no face to face meetup unless we reach 50 RSVPs by Thursday of the week. You must be enrolled in one of the 10 FREE courses below or similar courses. 

Our past experience is that 20% of the RSVP shows up in the weekend meetings. Considering that, unless we have about 50 RSVPs, we cannot have a face to face meeting. Please use the questions / answers / discussions below for now. While asking questions, please make reference to the name of the course and the related module within the course. 

Cousera offers the following classes towards obtaining highly valuable knowledge/skills in Data Science Specialization. It is sometimes hard to work on the exercises and homework without the help of an expert.  Receiving one-on-one help from an expert can improve the commitment of finishing the program with accelerated learning. With that in mind, we are experimenting with the following service.


An expert (MS or PhD in Statistics) will answer any question free that takes less than 10 minutes to solve. There are nominal fees for one-on-one interactive help.  Please use the following link to request for help, or just email [masked] or call[masked]-8864.

http://www.tutorteddy.com/courses/coursera-course-help.php 

You can get help for the following Data Science Specialization Classes:  (from https://www.coursera.org/specialization/jhudatascience/1?utm_medium=courseDescripTop )

The Data Scientist’s Toolbox

R Programming

Getting and Cleaning Data

Exploratory Data Analysis

Reproducible Research

Statistical Inference

Regression Models

Practical Machine Learning

Developing Data Products

Data Science Capstone
results.how_to_find_us: Depending on the interest level, we may meet @CIC or HackReduce or Microsoft NERD
results.name: In-depth R Programming Using Coursera (with  1-on-1  expert help)

results.description:
Part 3! Note: We do not have an event on 4/23. 

This session is designed for students who have already taken an intro to Python, Java, C/C++, or Javascript course (programming beyond HTML/CSS or Scratch). Exceptions may be granted with instructor permission. Students should be familiar with variables, if statements, and loops. Please arrive prepared with a laptop that already has Python (including scipy, numpy, and matlplotlib packages) installed and running: https://www.python.org/downloads/. If you are new to Python and don't have an environment like Spyder or PyCharm already set up, please use IPython Notebook (http://ipython.org/notebook.html).

The focus of this session will be making music with Python. Depending on student interest and ability, we may cover how computers play music files, how we can create our own digital music, how we can use the computer to distort existing music in cool ways, and ultimately how to make our own music using Python. Under the broader umbrella of digital signal processing, we can also explore topics from speech recognition to medical imaging.

When signing up, please indicate the number of kids you will be bringing. For example, if you are bringing one child, please RSVP "Just Me". If you are bringing two kids, please RSVP "+1". Accurate headcounts are very helpful for planning purposes, and help us deliver the best learning experience possible.

If possible, please email [masked]a brief summary of your student's programming experience and interests. Students are encouraged to explore the online documentation themselves and experiment with running their own code before class.

Spring session dates:

• <spring break no session 4/23>

• 4/30

• 5/7
results.name: Advanced Python (3 of 4)

results.description:
Part 3! Note: We do not have an event on 4/23. 

Intermediate track: web development (JavaScript)


This course is progressive, so if you haven't attended the first 2 weeks, it could be tough to catch up (depending on your kids’ previous experience with these languages). 

When signing up, please indicate the number of kids you will be bringing. For example, if you are bringing one child, please RSVP "Just Me". If you are bringing two kids, please RSVP "+1". Accurate headcounts are very helpful for planning purposes, and help us deliver the best learning experience possible.


Prerequisites: Kids should have completed a Scratch (or Scratch equivalent) programming course, and be comfortable with basic programming concepts. Weeks 3 and 4 assume prior knowledge of HTML/CSS (from previous weeks).

What to bring: Laptop (+ charger) with a text editor for coding installed. I recommend Sublime Text 3 (it’s free to try indefinitely). Notepad++ is another good option. 

Location: We’ll be at the LogMeIn office in Seaport. The address is 320 Summer Street, Boston 02210. Map: https://goo.gl/maps/vMvDj. There should be some street parking (bring quarters) as well as a few lots in the area. The nearest T stop is South Station.

Note: We're always looking for mentors, and also non-technical volunteers. If you’re interested in helping out, let us know at [masked], or sign up for the Mentor Mailing List.

Spring session dates:

• <spring break no session 4/23>

• 4/30

• 5/7

results.description:
This meeting is for all beginning investors and those wanting to learn more about buying multifamily homes as well as other investment properties. This 2 hour seminar will walk you through all the basics of buying & managing 2-4 unit residential buildings. The concepts you learn will<a> apply to</a> any area of Mass. The topics covered will include:

• Evaluating your target market and determining property values
• Evaluating your local rental market & why you must understand your tenant base
• Preparing yourself to <a>apply for</a> a multifamily <a>home loan</a> and what to expect
• Finding the right financing for you purchase and government <a>programs</a> that can help
• Calculating your property cash flow numbers
• Creating a long-term wealth building plan and staying the course

The key to success in real estate is "buying right"....and we're going to show you how to do that!

Hosted by


The Mandrell Company, Sierra Pacific Mortgage & Mahoney Law Group

https://liquidspace.com/Picture/Index/82b73f5f-1c1d-4c47-8ad9-ad353338a186?etag=IRMa3lO9UitzpGV9qQObJQ==&crop=true&maxWidth=450&maxHeight=350

results.description:
Are you curious about programming or thinking about pursuing a career in software engineering? 

Then RSVP on this meet-up page for this 2-hour Intro to Coding class happening in the Boston area at CIC Boston. Learn the basics of programming, do hands-on exercises, and meet new people. All for free!

The class is being taught by MakerSquare, which runs some of the top coding schools in the country.

Class officially starts at 1:30pm, but please arrive at CIC Boston by 1:15pm to mingle with your fellow classmates and settle in. We will end at 4pm, with the last 30 minutes being an optional Q&A session.

What will I learn during the class?

This beginner ­level class will contain several instructor-guided exercises. The class will cover the following topics:

   1. Overview of programming 

   2. Intro to data & data structures

   3. Basics of functions

We ask that you read the Prerequisites section before the start of class and bring your own laptop (Windows, Mac or Linux) with Google Chrome installed.

What is MakerSquare Boston?

MakerSquare is a three-month full-time school for software engineering. By teaching computer science fundamentals and modern web languages like JavaScript, we prepare students to join top flight engineering teams.

We have campuses all over the country, and are excited to be opening a campus in Boston. The free Intro to Coding class is to introduce more people to the wonderful world of programming and to get the community excited about the launch of our full-time class in Boston in July 2016!

Questions? Email us at [masked].
results.name: Free Intro to Coding Class (Sat April 30, 1:30-4pm)

results.description:
I'm not sure what the theme for this week will be yet, but come join us for swimming! All levels are welcome, but you should be comfortable swimming at least a couple of lengths continuously.


We go across the street for pizza (or other food if you don't eat pizza) every week after the swim. Save time to join us! We usually finish up by about 4:30pm.


---------------


The pool opens at 2pm, so we meet to go in at 1:45 so that we can be out on the pool deck by 2. $6 to get in, Cambridge residents $5 (or you can buy a 10-pack for an approximate 10% discount, and we do these weekly so you'll have the opportunity to use them up).

Street parking is available but stressful, and the 69 bus drops off down the block, or you can bike or run there and do 2/3 of a triathlon :)
results.name: Saturday swimming

group.name: Boston LGBT Triathlon Group (Swimmers, Cyclists, or Runners)

results.description:
Lets sketch the Esplanade park along the Charles river! 

We will meet at 2pm at the outdoor seating near the Charles River Bistro, just south of the Hatch Shell. We will disperse down along the river to sketch, and reconvene at the Bistro tables at 4pm to share our work and discuss. Note that it may be too crowded for us to get a table, so it may be adjacent to the tables somewhere. Look for the sketchbooks!

Sketch Challenge: shadows and reflections

If you want a challenge, focus on capturing shadow qualities and reflections in your sketching and we'll have a common struggle to chat about. This site is full of bridges and water and trees, and presents many qualities of shadow and reflection.

Note: Saturday meet because of weather forecast
results.how_to_find_us: Chris will have a bright orange jacket (206) 349-3669
results.name: Let's Sketch! The Esplanade & Hatch Shell (SATURDAY)

results.description:
Not to leave roleplayers with nothing to do TnT is hosting Vault of the Dracolich D&D scenario as part of our ITTD celebration. Vault of the Dracolich was originally written for the 2013 D&D Game Day, is designed for four tables of players and run by five Dungeon Masters. Imagine playing D&D not with a table full of your besties, but a room of them.

In the course of one afternoon of gaming, the four groups of fourth level characters must fight their way into the lair of an undead dragon. Each group starts at a different entrance to the dracolich’s lair, but to survive such a harrowing foe, they will have to help each other along the way, passing information via telepathic circlets, and even joining up to pass important magical items between them.

An adventure with so many players facing a single dire adversary in unison is a once-in-a-lifetime gaming experience. Those interested in DMing feel free to post or PM for details.
results.name: TnT's ITTD 5E Scenario: Vault of the Dracolich

group.name: The Boston Dungeons & Dragons Meetup Group

results.description: What does it mean to be masculine, feminine, both or neither? Four gender nonconforming poets (CA Conrad, Joy Ladin, Steven Riel, Pilar Quintana) will read from their works as they discuss how poetry interprets otherness, revealing the individual behind outward appearances and actions, and enabling us to define who we are for others, and for ourselves.
results.name: Massachusetts Poetry Festival- The Poetry of Gender Nonconformity

results.description:
We will have green tea and Japanese snacks.  (Special treat this week from our Japanese members)  Everyone will be encouraged to make origami cranes.  Don't worry we will show you how to do it!

And then we will have some readings on select excerpts from various world scriptures, including the Bible.  You will be amazed by the commonality of the major religions! There is no reason to fear or hate the believers of other faiths.  Each culture offers a unique view.  At this meeting you will meet believers from various countries and cultures.
results.how_to_find_us: The FFWPU building is a brownstone that faces the Boston Common.  There will be an A-frame sign in front.  We will meet in the Function Room on your right just past the main entrance.  If the main door is closed, just ring the bell on the right.
results.name: Special treat of green tea and snacks from our Japanese members

results.description:
NOTE CHANGED TIME, DAY, AND LOCATION

Murray will focus on a new theory of the origin of life, up to and including the evolution of the bacterial and Archaea cells, and then briefly outline the evolution of the Eukaryotic cell by the endosymbiosis of these two, two billion years later. These theories are brilliant, and amazingly detailed and evidenced by Nick Lane in his new book The Vital Question: Energy, Evolution, and the Origins of Complex Life. Handouts supplied. You can read the introduction and chapter 1 as a free sample on Google Books.

Robin Harper has posted notes on his talk last month on UFOs and ALIENS. Go to MORE, then FILES.
results.how_to_find_us: We will be in one of the compartments of the store, hopefully the front left room (They take no reservations, but I'll get there early).
results.name: NICK LANE'S THE VITAL QUESTION origin of life and simple cells (Murray Denofsky)

results.description:
Are you separated, divorced, considering divorce, or in the process of divorce?

You are invited to a Divorce Open House Mix & Mingle. Please join us for an evening hosted by our divorce professionals in the fields of law, real estate, parenting, finances, nutrition, relationship coaching, career coaching, therapy, accounting, interior design and more. You will have a chance to meet others in the same situation, as well as speak individually with our divorce professionals, in a friendly and casual setting with complimentary drinks and appetizers.

As a group of experienced professionals, we understand the complexities of divorce and separation and the need for a holistic approach to make the process smoother for everyone. We provide important resources that can help to educate and empower you throughout the process. This evening is intended to provide one-on-one interactions in an informal environment with experts in various fields at no cost. Bring your curiosity, questions, or concerns! 

This is a joint event with other meetup groups. There is no charge for attendance, and discussions with professionals are kept confidential. The event starts at 3 p.m., but feel welcome to come anytime between 3 and 5 p.m. You will be able to go in and out at your convenience. 

Complimentary light bites, wine and other refreshments will be provided for your enjoyment throughout the event.
results.how_to_find_us: RE/MAX Leading Edge is in Lexington Center on the corner of Massachusetts Ave and Waltham Street. Call/text Deanna at 508-333-3191 with any questions or for directions.
results.name: Divorce Open House Mix & Mingle

meta.description: Searches for recent and upcoming public events hosted by Meetup groups. Its search window  is the past one month through the next three months, and is subject to change. Open Events is optimized to search for current events by location, category, topic, or text, and only lists Meetups that have **3 or more RSVPs**. The number or results returned with each request is not guaranteed to be the same as the page size due to secondary filtering. If you're looking for a particular event or events within a particular group, use the standard [Events](/meetup_api/docs/2/events/) method.
meta.title: Meetup Open Events v2
